title: Bridge - The feeling was wrong
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The feeling was wrong

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are certain plays that bridge experts make because they "feel" right. It is called experience.Take, for example, today's deal, which I spotted in a magazine. According to the author, many declarers at a tournament missed the best play. Unfortunately, so did the author!In the modern tournament game, North could rebid a forcing two spades. However, if your two-over-one response may be made with only 10 or 11 points, you must jump to three spades on the second round to force to game.If the defenders begin with one heart and two club tricks (in any order), followed by a third club from East, South has a nasty guess. Why, though, should West lead a club (or the heart king)?Many Wests led a trump, which ran to South's seven.Apparently, the unsuccessful declarers immediately played off four rounds of diamonds, discarding three hearts and ruffing the last in the dummy. They cashed the spade ace and led a heart off the dummy. However, East won with the ace, gave his partner a diamond overruff and collected two club tricks to defeat the contract.The writer recommends ruffing the diamond six at trick two. Then he cashes dummy's last top trump and leads a heart. However, if East has the nerve to play low, West can win with the king and switch to clubs.The third round of clubs promotes West's spade jack as the fourth defensive trick.Attacking clubs immediately works, but an expert would almost subconsciously lead the heart queen from hand at trick two, opening communications. Given the initial spade lead, now no defense can cause problems. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Improve price of selling home
content:
Improve price of selling home

 October 31, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Selling soon? You're about to learn that when it comes to selling a house, you can judge a book by its cover. Some call it curb appeal. I call it the little things that get potential buyers through the front door, and that's what matters most.If you have a limited budget - and these days, who doesn't? - here are home improvements to help you sell your house for the highest price.Refresh the landscape. Spread new mulch in flower beds and around the base of trees. Lay down new sod; swap out failing bushes with fresh ones. Introduce color, either in the flower beds or with potted flowers. Even a small touch can make such a big difference.Spruce up the entrance. Invest in a new front door or give the current one a fresh coat of paint. Make sure the porch is immaculately clean. If your house number and mailbox appear worn, consider replacing them.Swap your light fixtures and plumbing fixtures. If yours are no longer in style, change them out. Let your local home improvement store be your guide for what is most popular now. Updating old ceiling lights and bathroom faucets can give your home a modern look without breaking the bank.Clarify space to clear up confusion. Make sure to fix any areas that might leave potential buyers puzzled. If you have an unusual alcove, consider adding a desk or a dresser to show how the space can be utilized most effectively. Many homes have quirks or issues that can be fixed visually, so don't leave potential buyers wondering.It goes without saying, but let me say it anyway: You won't get a second chance to make a first impression!Mary Hunt is the founder ofEverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living. "

content:
Sticker removal and other tips

 Page: 11A | Section: News

 I hope you enjoy the following tips from your fellow readers as much as I have.There's just something satisfying about discovering even the smallest ways to do better while saving time and money.SAFE, NOT SORRYA clever way to avoid a possible carjacking is to be always aware of what's going on around you. If you think someone is following you, make four right turns, which will in essence have you driving in a circle.If that suspicious car makes the same turns, immediately drive to the nearest police station, busy store, or service station to seek help. - TomDECALS, STICKERSRemove a decal or any type of sticker by first softening the adhesive with a hair dryer. Use a medium heat setting for a few seconds until the adhesive softens and the sticker starts to peel. Continue with the heat until the entire sticker peels off easily. - BarbCLUTCH FIRSTOn standard or manual-shift cars, get into the habit of always pushing in the clutch before starting the engine, regardless of whether the car is in gear. Besides being an obvious safety practice, holding the clutch in while starting the engine lets it turn over just a bit more easily, lessening the power required from the battery and starter motor. - BradIVORYTo clean anything ivory, like piano keys or carved objects, wipe with a solution of 1 tablespoon hydrogen peroxide and 1 cup water. No need to rinse. - SherylONE BITE AT A TIMESet aside 15 minutes each day to clean one area of your house. By the weekend, you won't have much more cleaning to do. - Sylvia Got a tip you'd like to shareft You can send it to tips@everydaycheapskate.com. Who knows? You just might see yourself in print in an upcoming column. Please be sure to include your full name, although only your first name will be published.CO PYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Said before, but rarely
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Said before, but rarely

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Who wrote: "Nothing has yet been said that's not been said before."?Today's critical suit combination has appeared in print before, but only rarely. Most players get it wrong. Without peeking at the East-West hands, how would you play the club suit for at most one loser in notrump?North's sequence showed four hearts, at least five clubs and game-going values or more. He announced the "or more" when leaping to six no-trump on round three.South starts with 10 top tricks: two spades, four hearts, two diamonds and two clubs. Clearly, he can afford one club loser but not two. All plays work if the missing clubs are divided 3-2. So you must maximize your chances against a 4-1 break.It looks normal to play the club king and another club, winning when East has the singleton nine, jack or queen.However, there is a better play. You should win the diamond lead with dummy's ace and immediately call for the club 10! If East plays the two or three, you play low. If East plays the nine or an honor, you win with the king and return a club, planning to cover West's card.This line works whenever East has the singleton nine, jack or queen, and when West has the singleton nine.The opening sentence was penned by Terence, a second-century B.C.Roman comic poet who wrote in remarkably pure Latin. What I would like to know is: Who said it before Terence? ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Bridge - It's a sungular honor, you snob
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - It's a sungular honor, you snob

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man is introduced to a well-known snob - that is, the snob is a well-known person, not that he is well known for being a snob."This is a singular honor for me," says the man as they shake hands."Yes, it must be," the snob replies.There are deals in which a singular honor - sorry, a singleton honor - plays a key role. Today's is, of course, one of them. It is another of those deals on which many players would go down because they wouldn't carry out sufficient analysis.After a Stayman auction in which North upgraded his hand because of the singleton, West led the spade jack. Declarer, deciding, reasonably enough, that West wouldn't lead away from the king-jack into a no-trump opening, played low from the dummy. Up popped the king from East.Delightedly, South won with the ace and led a trump.However, West shot in with the ace and returned the spade 10. Declarer covered with dummy's queen, but East ruffed, of course. Back came a trump, and South couldn't avoid the loss of two more spade tricks for down one.When East plays the spade king at trick one, it must be a singleton. If South stops to consider his alternatives, he will realize that ducking his ace is a good play. Then, when West wins with the heart ace and leads another spade, declarer plays low from the dummy. If East ruffs, he is trumping a loser.The spade ace and queen remain to take tricks in a moment. If East doesn't ruff, South wins with the ace and ruffs his two diamond losers in the dummy. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Habitat Choptank celebrates World Habitat Day - Habitat for Humanity affiliate recieves award for $1 million tithe milestone
author: Contributed
content:
Habitat Choptank celebrates World Habitat Day - Habitat for Humanity affiliate recieves award for $1 million tithe milestone

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 497
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Habitat Choptank celebrated World Habitat Day on Oct. 2 with a build day and a block party in the Hill District in Easton.The Habitat for Humanity affiliate also celebrated surpassing its $1 million tithe milestone.In 1985, the United Nations established the first Monday in October as World Habitat Day to promote the importance of shelter.Habitat for Humanity affiliates worldwide celebrate World Habitat Day in recognition that everyone deserves a safe and affordable home.Staff, board members, volunteers, donors and partners spend World Habitat Day on Habitat for Humanity construction sites to build homes and to build a future where everyone has a safe and affordable place to live.This year, Habitat Choptank board and staff members spent World Habitat Day by building on a construction site on South Locust Street, located in the Hill District in Easton, and celebrating their $1 million tithe achievement to Habitat for Humanity.This historic neighborhood currently has four new Habitat houses under construction, as well as a historic home rehabilitation in progress.After spending the morning and afternoon on the construction site, Habitat Choptank hosted a block party in the neighborhood to celebrate World Habitat Day and to educate the diverse and bilingual community that resides in the Hill District about Habitat Choptank's programs and services.The affiliate provided free food, drinks and information and was joined by other partner organizations.Pickering Creek offered information about native plants and hosted a giveaway of various plants, and the Multicultural Center provided information about their services.While Habitat Choptank serves Talbot and Dorchester Counties, the affiliate recognizes the global need for safe and affordable housing.Habitat Choptank commits to tithing 10% of all unrestricted donations received to support housing needs and other relief efforts worldwide. As part of Habitat for Humanity International's Tithe Program, Habitat Choptank tithes to Habitat affiliates in Haiti, El Salvador and Guatemala."Our commitment to tithing is based on Habitat Choptank's Christian values," says JoAnn Hansen, CEO of Habitat Choptank. "We have a strong belief that when we operate in faith and steward the resources that we've been entrusted with well, God will take care of the rest." Habitat for Humanity International presented Habitat Choptank with the Sam Mompongo Award in recognition of their $1 million tithe goal.In June, representatives from Habitat Guatemala visited Habitat Choptank in gratitude for their tithe partnership and to discuss how Habitat Choptank's tithe has helped families in Guatemala.Habitat Choptank's tithe this past year helped Habitat Guatemala build six more new homes and distribute 40 more healthy home kits, which provide access to water, sanitation and hygiene."Donations to Habitat Choptank make far-reaching and lasting impacts," the organization said in a press release. "Your gift to Habitat Choptank helps families achieve their dreams of homeownership in Talbot and Dorchester Counties and worldwide." Visit habitatchoptank.org/donate to make a donation or for other ways to give. 
 
 Caption: HABITAT CHOPTANK
 
Staff members from Habitat Choptank, Pickering Creek, and the Multicultural Center gather for a group photo in front of a Habitat house under construction.

title: Wants more information about father's family
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Wants more information about father's family

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 17 | Section: Advice 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: Growing up, I was raised by my mother in a single-parent household after my father passed away when I was a baby. Now that I am older, I have a desire to find my father's side of the family.I am concerned that this may cause some issues or bring up past hurt for my mother.My mother never spoke much about my father's side of the family, which always left a void in my heart. I think it is important to tell my mom what I am doing, but I don't want this to cause any problems between us. Can you please help me with this situation? - Finding Myself DEAR FINDING MYSELF: You have every right to learn about your father's family. Your mother may be uncomfortable about the idea at first, but it is OK to let her know your intentions.Thank your mother for all that she has done to care for you for your whole life. Point out how hard it may have been at times, especially since your father passed away so early in your life.Tell her that you are curious about him and his family, and you want her help in learning about them and finding them.Listen to her thoughts on the subject. Find out if she knows how to reach any of his people. Probe to learn their names and any other clues about them.Do your research to put the pieces together. Also, ask her why she didn't maintain a relationship with them. There may be good reasons why she has kept her distance. Learn what you can, and proceed with caution.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: When do you play second hand high? - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
When do you play second hand high? - Bridge

 November 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 266
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In her poem "Sanctuary," Dorothy Parker wrote, "My land is bare of chattering folk;/the clouds are low along the ridges,/and sweet's the air with curly smoke/from all my burning bridges."At the card table, we try not to burn our bridges with partner. One of the best known ways of keeping them intact is "second hand low." Why rush up when your partner is last to play to the trick?This week, let's look at the times when your problem is deciding between second hand high and low.First, second hand low. A textbook example is in this deal. How should the play go in six spades after West leads the heart king?If North were a member of the Real Bridge Players Don't Need Blackwood Club, he would jump straight to six spades. Here, he uses Roman Key Card Blackwood to learn that his partner has either two aces or one ace and the spade king.Declarer wins the first trick with dummy's heart ace, cashes the three diamond winners, discarding his remaining heart, ruffs the heart four in his hand and leads a club toward dummy's king-jack.West must play second hand low -- and do it with no hesitation. He should know that his side needs two club tricks to defeat the contract. He must not give declarer the contract on a platter with caviar, lobster and toast points.Then, if declarer calls for dummy's king, West will say: "Sorry, partner. Next time I will lead a low club, which will surely cause South to misguess."©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Bridge - Make declarer guess correctly
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Make declarer guess correctly

 November 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are looking at second hand low and, later in the week, second hand high.It is important for defenders to make declarer guess well to land his contract. They must not make things easy for him.The heart suit in this deal is one example. How should South plan the play in six spades? West leads the diamond 10.After South opened one spade, North understandably launched into Blackwood, signing off in six spades when he learned that one ace was missing. He expected South to claim immediately, but the mirror distribution meant that play had to proceed.South, who can afford to lose only one heart trick, wins trick one in the dummy, draws trumps, cashes all of the minor-suit winners ending in his hand and leads a heart. If West wins with the ace, it is all over. So, let's assume West plays low. Now South calls for dummy's heart queen. (This is a better play than immediately finessing dummy's 10.) If East takes the trick, he is endplayed, forced either to return a heart into dummy's K-10 or to concede a ruffand-sluff. So, let's assume East also plays low.Declarer returns to his hand with a trump and leads another heart. Again, if West wins with the ace, South claims. When West plays low, though, declarer has a guess. He might or might not get it right, but at least the defender with the ace - whether it is East or West - did his best.Finally, note that both West and East must play low so smoothly that the kibitzers think the deck is missing the heart ace. Any hesitation gives the game away. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Keeping faith in times of trouble
author: Dartanyon Hines
content:
Keeping faith in times of trouble

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dartanyon Hines | Page: 5A | Section: News 
 
 384
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Looking at the negative, hateful and destructive things that are going on in the world around us and abroad, it makes one wonder about our future.I mean, it seems like every day we are being bombarded by some form of bad news. The continuation of wars and the rumors of wars, the rising cost of food and commodities used to create the products we hold essential to our way of living, the political gridlock that stems from our elected officials choosing to place party over principles, and the violence that has become too prevalent in our towns and cities.All of these things and more can conspire to disturb our peace of mind and break the tranquility of our lives.But there is something I have found that is able to keep us from falling into the pit of despair even amid the challenges of a world seemingly gone mad - something so powerful that it causes the light of hope to perpetually shine through the increasing darkness of fallen humanity.That something is faith.It is faith in the will of Almighty God to take care of His own. It is this faith that causes me to trust the sacred promise that "many are the afflictions of the righteous, but the Lord brings them out of them all."With faith, my friends, we who believe are able to see beyond the tests and trials of the day no matter how harsh or severe they may become to a reality that supersedes this world of shadows.That faithful reality is what inspired the Apostle Paul to proclaim in Romans 8:18 "for I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that shall be revealed in us." To paraphrase a quote from Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., with the power of faith, we are able to chisel the "mountains of despair into precious stones of hope." In these troubling days, it seems like we all take losses of some sort, but the one thing we cannot afford to lose is our faith in the Almighty to care for us.And no matter what uncertainties tomorrow may bring our way, let us continue to move forward trusting in the Lord. "For we walk by faith, not by sight" (2 Cor. 5:7).

title: Bridge - The singleton will be led
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The singleton will be led

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You are sitting over the dummy. It is a trump contract. Dummy has a sidesuit singleton, and in that suit you have the ace without the king or queen. You know what will happen. Declarer will get into the dummy and call for that singleton. Do you win with your ace, or do you play low smoothly?North, despite having six losers (one spade, two hearts, two diamonds and one club), blasted into Blackwood and then leapt to six spades. A four-club splinter bid would have been a wiser choice - if North-South were using that toy, of course. (Four clubs would have shown fourcard or longer spade support, at least game values and a singleton or void in the bid suit.)A diamond lead would have defeated the contract by two tricks, but West understandably selected the heart queen. Declarer won with dummy's king and called for the club seven.East was immediately on the spot. What should he have done?If the ace is the setting trick, he (almost always) should grab the trick. But far more often than not, second hand should play low, not win with the ace. This deal is a tough example. Although South has no guess in the suit, if East wins with his ace, the contract makes. Declarer gets two club winners, on which he discards dummy's two low diamonds. He takes five spades, two hearts, one diamond, two clubs and two diamond ruffs in the dummy.Luckily for the defense, East had been there before: He played low smoothly. That cost one club trick, but two diamond tricks come back in return. The declarer had no chance. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Delicious Thanksgiving sides
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
Delicious Thanksgiving sides

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 4A | Section: News 
 
 1230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 That big juicy turkey that just came out of the oven and is waiting to be carved does not get all the attention!Side dishes share the spotlight at many Thanksgiving dinners. Everyone loves side dishes and looks forward to piling them on their plates!The first dish that comes to my memory is when I go back to the country Thanksgiving dinner my mom would prepare. Mom always had her menu planned ahead of time, and the morning before Thanksgiving, she would get a basket and sharp knife and walk to the field on the farm where the fresh collard greens were growing.Mom loved cooking big dinners for family members, who came from afar to share the bounty of food that was mostly homegrown.She would cut the greens and mash them down in the basket until it was full.Returning to the house, we would chop the stems off, place them in a tub, pour cold water over them and sprinkle with some coarse salt. to bring any bugs to the top.After at least three to four times, we changed the water and shook the greens to ensure they were pest-free.In the house already on the stove was her largest pot, filled 1/4 of the way with boiling water and with either a ham hock or fat meat cooking for flavor.In came the clean greens that were gently dropped into the hot water. The lid was placed on loosely, and the rolling boil continued until the greens were tender. with us checking to see if more water was needed every so often.We'd sprinkle some table salt or coarse salt on top, and, during the last few minutes of cooking, sprinkle a very light amount of baking soda (yellow box) over top greens that will cause greens to steam up and fall back down.Recently, my daughter in law, Shannon, visited a local farm in Pittsville called Ard Brac Acres.While there, she picked up some bags of collard greens already cleaned as well as some ham hocks.Shannon put a "modern" touch on this dish, and let me tell you, they were amazing!Look up Ard Brac Acres on social media, as we will definitely be visiting them again soon for more country style dishes. Also, today, Nov. 8, is Shannon's birthday, so I'd like to wish her a very happy birthday!SHANNON's HAM HOCKS AND TURNIP GREENSUse a bag of collard greens purchased from the store. or two bags according to your crock pot size. Place one large or medium ham hock in a crock pot. season with 2 tablespoons minced garlic, 2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar, and 2 tablespoons sugar. Fill the crock pot to the top with chopped greens and pour a 32-ounce container of chicken broth or broth of your choice over greens. sprinkle top with salt and pepper to taste.Cover pot with lid and cook for 7 to 10 hours. Shannon (my daughter-in-law) cooked this and shared it with me. it is delicious and so much easier to make. try it and you will agree.GREEN BEANS WITH BACONThis is tasty, quick and easy. In a large skillet, cook four diced bacon strips with 1/2 cup chopped onion until the bacon is crisp. Meanwhile place 8 cups of fresh green beans, trimmed, in a large saucepan and cover with water. Bring to a boil and cook for 8 to 10 minutes, or until crisp-tender.Drain well and add the bacon mixture. Sprinkle top with salt and pepper and toss to coat. Serve immediately.This recipe is not the one grandmother or mom made, but it is great too.Give it a try.SWEET POTATON' MARSHMALLOWFor a Small casserole dish size. Mix together well with an electric mixer: 1 can sweet potatoes, 1 egg, 3/4 cup sugar, 1 1/4 teaspoons vanilla, 1/3 cup evaporated milk and 1/3 stick of margarine.Mix well and bake in a 350 degree oven for 30 to 40 minutes. Remove from the oven and top with one bag of large marshmallows and return to the oven just until the marshmallows turn golden brown. Remove from the oven and let set for a while before serving.CORNBREAD DRESSING WITH OYSTERS2 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more for greasing the dish, 1 diced yellow onion, 3 diced stalks celery, 5 minced cloves garlic, 8 cups crumbled cornbread, Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, 3 1/2 cups chicken stock, 6 large eggs, 1/2 cup chopped Italian parsley, 1 bunch fresh tarragon with leaves stripped and chopped, 2 cups shucked oysters with their juice. Heat the oven to 350 degrees. Butter a 9-by 13-inch baking dish.In a large skillet, melt the butter over medium heat.When the butter is foamy, add the onion and celery, and cook, stirring frequently, until softened, 6 to 8 minutes. Stir the garlic and cook until aromatic, about 1 minute.Stir in the crumbled cornbread and cook, stirring, until lightly browned, then remove from the heat. In a large bowl, beat the eggs until smooth. Whisk in the chicken stock, parsley and tarragon. Stir in the cornbread mixture and the oysters. Pour the dressing mixture into the prepared baking dish and bake until the dressing is set and golden brown, about 1 hour. (Alternatively, cover and refrigerate overnight before baking; see note.)Let rest for 5 minutes.GREEN BEAN CASSEROLEHeat oven to 350 degrees.In a large bowl, stir together 2 cans of green beans with 1 can of golden mushroom soup, half a can of water, and 1 cup grated cheddar cheese.Lightly mix and transfer to a 2 quart casserole dish. Sprinkle top with one can of fried onions. Cover with foil and bake for 30 minutes. Remove foil and bake for another 15 minutes until bubbly.ASPARAGUS CASSEROLEGoes great with baked ham. In a buttered casserole dish place a layer of asparagus and then a layer of crumbled cheese nips crackers.Wet with cream of mushroom soup mixed with water according to directions on the can. Finish the casserole with a few more crushed cheese nips. Bake in a 350 degree oven until asparagus is tender.OLD FASHIONED BREAD DRESSINGIn a skillet, cook 1 1/2 cups finely chopped onion in 1/3 cup butter with 1 1/2 cups chopped celery until tender.Add this mixture to 8 cups of dry small bread cubes which have been placed in a large pan. Sprinkle with 1 1/2 teaspoons salt, 1/8 teaspoon black pepper, 1/2 teaspoon poultry seasoning, 1/2 teaspoon sage, and combine well. Add 1/4 cup water and 1 beaten egg. Toss together with a fork. Stuff a thawed bird immediately and bake according to directions on the turkey label.ITALIAN GREEN BEAN CASSEROLE6 ounces Parmesan cheese, grated (about 1 1/2 cups), 1. cups Italian-style breadcrumbs, 4 garlic cloves, minced, 1 teaspoon kosher salt,. teaspoon black pepper, divided, 3 (28-oz.) cans Italian-style green beans, drained, 2 (9-oz.) pkg. frozen artichoke hearts, thawed, drained well and chopped,. cup extra-virgin olive oil, chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley.Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Combine Parmesan, breadcrumbs, garlic, salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper in a large bowl. Reserve 1/3 cup of the breadcrumb mixture then set aside. Add green beans, artichoke hearts, and olive oil to bowl with remaining breadcrumb mixture, and fold to combine well. Pour green bean mixture into a lightly greased 13-x 9-inch baking dish. Sprinkle reserved breadcrumb mixture evenly over the casserole.Cover with aluminum foil, and bake until heated through, about 30 minutes. Uncover and bake until lightly golden and bubbly, about 10 minutes. Sprinkle with remaining 1/4 teaspoon pepper, and if desired, chopped parsley. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES
 
Marie Savage said side dishes share the spotlight with the turkey at Thanksgiving dinner.

title: How I feel about Groupon
author: Mary Hunt
content:
How I feel about Groupon

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Cheapskate: What do you think about Groupon and similar coupon plans?The deals are often very good, but they generally are not for items that I have planned to purchase.They seem to encourage unplanned spending, but perhaps they can be used prudently? - Melissa Melissa: This is my opinion on Groupon: This company flat-out preys on weak people who are prone to react impulsively, tricking them into buying stuff because it looks like such a great deal, not because they really need to eat out at a fancy restaurant, hire four hours of maid service or have an exquisite family portrait taken at the beach.Groupon and other similar social networking coupon companies that load your email box with daily offers of everything from spa treatments to knitting lessons are clever, albeit somewhat devious.Do not ask me how I have become so knowledgeable on how this Groupon thing works, and how it's impossible to have a normal relationship with Groupon.Just don't. And believe me when I tell you that the only way to deal with this monster known as Groupon is to unsubscribe.Do you have a question for me? You can land it in my virtual mailbag when you follow the guidelines at EverydayCheapskate.com/contact.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services. Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/, "Ask Mary." This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually. Mary Hunt is the founder of Everyday-Cheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Bridge - When sould he play second hand high?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - When sould he play second hand high?

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 283
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Phillip Alder So far this week, we have looked at the classic situations for second hand low by a defender. However, there are three critical positions when second hand must play high, like it or not!With that enormous hint, it shouldn't be hard to work out in this deal how the defense can defeat three no-trump after West leads the heart queen.When someone opens two no-trump, his hand will usually contain seven controls, an ace being two controls and a king one.Here, South had eight controls, with which he might have upgraded and opened two clubs. However, he had no five-card suit or good intermediates (nines and 10s). He sensibly started with two no-trump.South had seven top tricks: one spade, two hearts, three diamonds and one club. So, even if diamonds were 3-3, declarer needed to make something of dummy's club suit.South won the first trick with his heart king and immediately led a club.West's big moment had arrived: He had to play second hand high, putting his king onto the table.Note that if West had played his low club, declarer would have called for dummy's nine. Whether East won with his queen or ducked, South would have gotten four club tricks and 10 in all.However, when West played his club king, declarer was caught between a rock and a hard place. If he had ducked in the dummy, another heart would have established West's suit. Instead, when South won with dummy's ace and played another club, East ducked, holding declarer to a pair of club tricks. With the diamonds 4-2, not 3-3, the contract had to fail. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Bridge - Partner's suit is nearly established
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Partner's suit is nearly established

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Luciano Pavarotti said, "Am I afraid of high notes? Of course I am afraid. What sane man is not?" Today's deal illustrates a time when a player sitting second hand must not be afraid to play high.South is in three no-trump, and West leads the spade queen. What happens after that?Opposite a 15-17 notrump, when responder has 10 points, no interest in the majors and no singleton or void, he should just blast straight into three no-trump.(When your minimum combined count is 25, bid game. When your maximum combined count is 25, settle for one no-trump unless you also have a five-card suit.)South has seven top tricks: two spades, three hearts and two clubs. He must establish two diamond tricks to get home.When declarer has two stoppers in the suit led and two high cards to dislodge, normally he should duck the first trick. (He could win the first trick here as long as he ducks the second round of spades.) After taking dummy's spade ace at trick two, South calls for a diamond.East knows that his partner's suit is one lead from being established. When this is the situation, he should do his utmost to win the next defensive trick. Here, East must play his diamond king. Then, when he holds the trick, he can lead his last spade. West's suit is established, and West has the diamond ace as his entry card. The defenders take two diamonds and three spades.Note that if East does not play his diamond king, West's ace will be gone before his spade suit is ready to run. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: 'It's about the JOURNEY' - Retired Marine Capt. Mike Oldham takes on the Pacific Crest Trail
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'It's about the JOURNEY' - Retired Marine Capt. Mike Oldham takes on the Pacific Crest Trail

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - Mike Oldham loves hiking.It's a hobby he picked up as a young Marine in California, but the formidable Pacific Crest Trail beckoned him once he retired. After months of planning and preparing, he launched his odyssey last year.When an injury sidetracked him, he left the trail, but resumed his trek a year later.On Sept. 3, he completed his over 2,550-mile hike with an emotional coda he recorded on YouTube, a platform he used to record many of the highs and lows of his journey, along with his philosophical musings.Mike Oldham, 60, of Centreville, credits his 26-year career as a U.S.Marine for helping him prepare and especially, to apply an all-important lesson: Carry plenty of water.He's not sure if his ability to plan and prepare is innate or was formed as part of his Marine experience and persona, but it was probably a combination of both.Oldham recalled his service in the Marine Corps, his childhood that propelled his love of the trail, the arduous training, the toll the hike took on his body and the sublime moments that took his breath away.A LOVE OF HIKING IS BORNOldham grew up in Roseville, Michigan, spending time on his grandparents' farm and tramping their 15 acres of woods."I just love being out in the woods. I loved hiking," he said. "My brother likes hunting and I tried to hunt, but I didn't like it as much as just walking around the woods. I thought it was great." In high school, Oldham "concentrated on football and girls, and I got a 100% scholarship to the United States Marine Corps" in 1981, he said.That decision landed him in a first tour of duty that was "very fortunate." As a Sikorsky CH-53 Helicopter mechanic and crew chief, he was stationed with newly elected President Ronald Reagan's helicopter squadron Marine One."We would fly into the White House and pick them up or take them to Andrews Air Force Base," Oldham said. "And then when he was overseas, we would break down our helicopters and put them in a C-5, go overseas and put them together and pick them up at whatever airport." Oldham has since visited the Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, California, and viewed a photograph of himself with Reagan that's hanging on the wall in Air Force One.He remembers the late president as a person "as genuine as you could imagine. He was truly the guy that you saw on TV," he said.He eventually went to warrant officer school, served a series of assignments and retired with the rank of captain after 26 years."I got a great job at General Atomics Aeronautical Systems, and I worked in support of the MQ-1 Predator and the MQ-9 Reaper unmanned aerial vehicles," he said. During the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, they were the UAVs "dropping bombs and killing bad guys." He retired from General Atomics on March 29, 2022, and two days later he started hiking the Pacific Crest Trail."I was ready for a break from aerospace and everything," Oldham said. "You go through life 100 miles an hour, and this was the way to get away from everything and just enjoy God's country."FOREST BATHING"Forest bathing," a form of ecotherapy, is something Oldham has come to appreciate and advocate.Whether "in the desert, the mountains or forests, it helps you psychologically, and there is nothing better than being away from everything - no cell phones, no cars, no roads, no email, nothing. Just you and the trail," he said.The PCT is one of three long distance hiking trails in the U.S. "They don't have these trails in other countries," Oldham said. "We're very fortunate to have these national parks and these trails." As he "started romancing and fantasizing" about hiking one of these trails, he took a "deep dive into the history of (long distance hiking) and researching and watching other people's videos about it" for about five years.The PCT captured his imagination.Near his home and work, Oldham had hiked in the mountains near San Diego. A year before he launched out on the PCT, he began hiking seven or eight miles after work, carrying 25 pounds of water. On weekends, he'd hike twice as far.Still, the PCT is arduous on the best of days. In fact, long-distance hikers must apply for one or more permits.There are also campfire, campsite and "weather window" restrictions.Besides all-essential water, Oldham equipped himself with a small Garmin inReach GPS satellite communicator for unlimited texting and emergency notification. An app called Far Out "works in airplane mode and shows you exactly where you are and where the trail is," he said, and he never got lost. For treacherous walking on snow and ice, he strapped microspikes on his boots. He wore out a pair of hiking boots about every 400 miles."You get to eat as horrible as you want, because you're losing weight," Oldham said. "You're literally at a 1,000-calorie deficit a day, and you're still eating like crazy. I lost 25 pounds, and I did not have 25 pounds to lose. When I got back, I was so weak in the upper body.Now, legs-wise, you're climbing 4,000 to 5,000 feet a day with a 30-pound pack, and you are crushing it, but your upper body is taking a toll." Still, rather than push himself beyond his physical limits, he did what he jokingly called the "Oregon resort challenge," seeking out RV resorts that had food, beer and places to recharge battery packs. If the weather forecast called for several days of heavy rain, Oldham would opt to stay at a nearby hostel or hotel.Oldham's trail name became "Marine Mike" after a hiker finally caught up with him after five days, bearing the hat Oldham had lost. His brother David had given him the hat that identified Oldham as a Marine. "I've been chasing you for five days," the hiker gasped. "How can an old man hike so fast?" Oldham embarked from the southern terminus in Campo, California, on the Mexico border March 31, 2022, and made it to Lake Tahoe. Although he had experienced some hard falls and broken packs all along the trek, on June 16, he landed in the emergency room with foot and knee injuries he sustained on the trail at 1,100 miles."Welcome to the PCT," he quipped.SIDELINED, BUT BACK ON THE TRAILHe spent the rest of the year in physical therapy, and ventured back into the gym.Oldham got back on the trail June 15, 2023, at mile 1,236 in Quincy, California, a year minus a day from his exit in 2022.According to the Pacific Crest Trail Association, California comprises the lion's share of miles at 1,692. The PCT in Oregon is 455 miles long and Washington is 506 miles.The vistas on the trail were worth the effort, Oldham said. "The Sierra Mountains were just amazing," he said.He climbed Mount Whitney - at 14,505 feet, the highest mountain in the contiguous U.S. and the Sierra Nevada."You definitely feel the low oxygen, (but) the views are just amazing. You think you're in a National Geographic film all day long.Also the state of Washington is just gorgeous. I mean, gorgeous." From freezing temperatures to scorching heat or gale-force winds, from heavy snowfall to treacherous snow to fallen trees, sheer slopes, rocks, desert and rivers - and even a stubborn bull blocking the trail - Oldham encountered the gamut of terrain, weather and obstacles.But "trail angels" and "trail magic" - surprising grace notes along the way - were "a blessing to have," he said."Trail angels just truly love supporting hikers." "You're out there hiking, and then you come across somebody who is cooking burgers for you or has fruit and and sodas" or a cold drink hikers crave, he said. They even came across a cooler containing beer in the middle of the woods marked with the sign "trail magic." The day Oldham reached the terminus on Sept. 3, he was filled with emotion. "I didn't see it coming either." "That was a goal that I had had for several years, and you're out there pumping 20-plus miles a day all to reach this goal," Oldham said."But it wasn't about the destination because the destination was a bunch of wood stuck in the ground. It was about the journey. You know, our life is about the journey.It's not about the destination." While Oldham remains an always faithful Marine, he carries with him the indelible memory of his odyssey that pushed him to his limits in the Great Outdoors.To see videos of his trek, visit Mike Oldham's YouTube channel at youtube.com/@mikeoldham4023. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY MIKE OLDHAM
 
Mike Oldham on Mount Whitney, the highest summit in the continental United States.
 
COURTESY MIKE OLDHAM
 
In 1983, President Ronald Reagan shakes hands with young Marine Mike Oldham at Camp David. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Detecting problems with old plumbing and pipes
author: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors
content:
Detecting problems with old plumbing and pipes

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - From providing a hot shower at the end of a long day to taking the wastewater out of our home without a smell, the indoor plumbing system is an unsung hero of our everyday lives.We rarely stop to think about the complexities involved in providing a clean glass full of water from our sinks until we step in a puddle on the floor.The indoor plumbing systems in our homes have been constructed throughout the past 150 years of many different materials, and some of those materials have lasted better than others.Daniel Morris, a certified master inspector with Blackwater Home Inspectors, is a preferred partner with Mid-Shore Board of Realtors and will relay some of the materials that throughout the years have shown to be deficient and how to identify them.When referencing residential plumbing, we generally are talking about our supply piping and drain piping. Let's talk about two materials found in the Mid-Shore area that have common issues, polybutylene piping and galvanized steel.Polybutylene piping was introduced in the late 1970s and used through the mid-1990s. Gray in appearance when installed in a home, the lettering "PB-2110" is often printed on the pipe.It was a flexible, cheap and easy to install material. The piping was installed in millions of homes throughout the U.S. because of those qualities.However, polybutylene piping has shown that it is more prone to leaks and deterioration of the pipe material itself. Several class action lawsuits against the manufacturers have taken place, and at this point, the pipe is considered obsolete and in need of replacement.Mobile homes and manufactured homes were often plumbed with this piping material, and it is still common to find these materials today. If you live in a home built in the 80s or 90s, take a second to look under your sink to see if you see any exposed gray piping.Galvanized steel was a product introduced in the 1940s. It consisted of a steel pipe that was dipped in a zinc coating to prevent corrosion.However, over time, with water running through the pipe, the zinc coating on the interior of the piping can wash away. This leads to the piping corroding on the inside and slowly closing the pipe in.Oftentimes, rust particles are introduced into the water running through the pipe, contaminating the water. It often will restrict the flow of water and result in a loss of water pressure.This piping can be identified by a dull, grayish/silver appearance.When the pipe is scratched it will be shiny, as opposed to lead, which will be dull in color.To best test the performance of this pipe, it is recommended you run multiple water fixtures for two minutes and watch for noticeable dips in water pressure. This piping material is past its lifespan at this point, and replacement of the material is recommended.All water pipes can leak, not just the two that are described above.Plumbing leaks are not just a minor inconvenience but can often lead to structural damage to a home if the leak is not caught quickly.There are several pieces of technology now that can help detect these leaks before they become an issue.There are small water alarms that can be placed in areas to detect any leaks and whole house leak detection meters that are installed on your water main and can shut off the water to the home if a leak is detected.Even some water heaters are coming installed with leak detectors.If you have questions about your plumbing system, a plumbing contractor or even a local home inspector can often be of assistance.Morris can be reached at 443-528-1633. The company website is Blackwaterhomeinspections.com.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors is happy to partner with many firms related to the real estate industry. For more news and information check out our website, midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
 
The zinc coating on galvanized steel pipes, such as those shown above, can erode over time, causing the pipe to corrode.
 
MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
 
Polybutylene piping was often used in mobile and manufactured homes in the 1980s and 1990s. It is more prone to leaking than other materials. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: More on planning at trick one - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
More on planning at trick one - Bridge

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every beginner is told to pause before playing from the dummy at trick one.He should form a plan of campaign before continuing the battle. You might think that experts never fall from grace in this respect, but you would be wrong.Today's deal comes from a match between two different countries. How should South play in six hearts after West leads the diamond five?At the other table, North-South stopped in four hearts, making five. This pair was more adventurous. Three diamonds was a transfer bid, East doubling to show good diamonds. Throwing caution to the winds, North rebid a quantitative four notrump.(If he had wanted to ask for aces or key cards immediately, he would have used a Texas transfer at the four-level.) South, despite having minimum count and two diamond losers, took a shot at the slam.The declarer won the first trick with his diamond ace and drew trumps in three rounds. Then he paused to assess the situation - too late.He should have noted that he had only 11 winners: three spades, five hearts, one diamond and two clubs. It was necessary to capture a third club winner.The right line is to draw only two rounds of trumps, keeping an honor in the South hand. Then declarer plays off his three top spades, discarding one of dummy's clubs. A club to the ace, a club to the king and a club ruff follow. South, thankful to see the 3-3 split, plays a trump to his jack (or king) and cashes the club nine, discarding one of dummy's diamond losers. He concedes just one diamond trick. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Filing auto insurance claims
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Filing auto insurance claims

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Car insurance is a funny thing. You pay a small fortune to get it and keep it.Then, if you have the blatant audacity to actually file a claim, the company either increases your premiums or cancels you altogether.OK, that may be a bit extreme, but you get my point.While the world of insurance can at times be so confusing as to be maddening, going without basic automobile coverage is simply not an option. The financial risk is just too great. But there are some things you can do to make sure you don't stand out to the company as an intolerable risk.You should file an auto insurance claim if: There are injuries, even minor ones. It's crucial to report the incident to your insurer to ensure your coverage applies, preventing unexpected bills and safeguarding you from potential lawsuits by injured drivers.Another driver is involved.Contact your insurance company whenever you're in a crash with another driver, especially when fault isn't clear. Reporting the incident to your insurer helps make sure the blame is assigned fairly and shields you from excessive liability.There is damage to vehicles or property. Insurance is there to help you with costs when things get damaged, so you don't have to pay a big lump sum. That's why you pay monthly premiums.You shouldn't file an auto insurance claim if: You are the only person involved. If the incident is your fault and does not involve injuries, not telling your insurance company will help protect your premium.There is only a small amount of damage. Even if you have collision coverage in your car insurance, you might decide not to file a claim if your car has only minor damage.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services.Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/, "Ask Mary." CO PYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: God is a constant in all seasons of life
author: Kevin Randolph
content:
God is a constant in all seasons of life

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kevin Randolph | Page: 5A | Section: News 
 
 311
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I love this time of year, with all of the amazing fall colors.Having grown up in West Virginia, it was incredible to see the mountains come alive with color during the changing of the season.It reminds me of what David wrote in Psalm 19:1, "The heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament shows His handiwork." So as you enjoy the changing of the seasons, give thanks to God for the awesome display of His color palette as we move toward winter.The seasons remind us of the continual changes that take place in life.Each season has certain characteristics that highlight that time of year.As we live our lives, we are constantly encountering change.Each season of our lives brings unique characteristics that help prepare us for the seasons that are to come.One important thing about handling change in our lives is that we also need a constant (something that does not change) that we can anchor to that will enable to handle us handle change.That constant is found in God alone. Scripture tells us in Malachi 3:6, "For I am the LORD, I do not change" Without God as our source of stability because He does not change, we will find many difficulties in handling the changes that come in our lives. He is the steadfast rock that gives us a sure foundation to be able to walk through all of the changes in this life.As we approach the Thanksgiving holiday, take time to reflect on the various seasons of your life, and I believe you will see a constant source of strength that has enabled stability through the seasons and changes of life.Take time to give thanks for His grace and mercy and all of the blessings He gives through each season.I hope each of you have a blessed Thanksgiving holiday and an amazing Christmas season! 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - The passion was powerful
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The passion was powerful

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There is a strong desire to take a finesse. If it wins, an extra trick is in the bag.However, you should always consider what will happen if the finesse loses. Would it be better not to finesse?In today's deal, North might have passed over two notrump, but he decided that that contract was unlikely to make exactly. Either the hearts would be useful and nine tricks won, or they wouldn't and he would be conceding an extra undertrick by bidding game.West led the club king: four, five, two. (Yes, leading the seven would have worked much better, but with two apparent entries, leading the honor looked preferable.)West continued with the club nine: eight, jack, 10.East switched to the spade two. How should South have continued from thereftThe first declarer finessed the spade queen, but West, feeling relieved, won with the king and played another club. When South led a heart, West grabbed his ace and cashed the clubs for down three.The second declarer rose with the spade ace at trick three and led a heart to dummy's nine. When that won, South played a diamond to his queen and led his second heart. With the favorable lie, nine tricks were there for the taking.The first declarer claimed how lucky the other declarer had been to find both heart honors onside tripleton.However, if East holds the heart queen, the contract is probably doomed. For one thing, West is likely to hold the spade king and heart ace for his vulnerable two-level overcall. Also, if West has the heart queen, the spade finesse can wait. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Perfectionist gets stressed at work
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Perfectionist gets stressed at work

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 21 | Section: News 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE:I'm a perfectionist, and it's causing me a lot of stress. I recently accepted a job that proved to be overwhelming to me.I thought I would be good at it, but I had to stretch a lot, and it just seemed like I was not doing anything right. I ended up quitting after one week. I felt like such a failure.My boss didn't say that I was doing a bad job, but she kept pointing out things that I needed to work on. I just couldn't take it. Now I am unemployed and feel like even more of a loser. How can I regain my confidence when my perfectionism is probably what landed me here in the first place?-Crippling PerfectionismDEAR CRIPPLING PERFECTIONISM:Give yourself credit for recognizing that you may be too much of a perfectionist. In our culture, being a high achiever - being the best■is lauded.Know that you are not alone in your desire to do everything right and likely better than others. Know, too, that this is unhealthy and can lead to situations like you described where you feel compelled to walk away rather than face whatever situation is before you.According to VeryWell-Mind.com, signs of perfectionism include: all-or-nothing thinking, being highly critical, having unrealistic standards, focusing only on unmet goals, fear of failure, procrastination, defensiveness and low self-esteem.You can work to combat those feelings by establishing daily affirmations that speak to your talents and goodness. Give yourself a break. Showing up and doing your best are good. And good is just fine.You may want to see a therapist to help you navigate the current crisis and help you develop strategies for managing your expectations and outcomes.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist andfounder ofDREAM-LEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions toaskharri-ette@harriettecole.com. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: The finesse was avoidable after all - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
The finesse was avoidable after all - Bridge

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 20 | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here are a couple of signs spotted in Canada. In Vancouver, "For your added convenience, this Post Office will be closed on Saturdays." And on Highway 11 in Ontario, "You are now halfWay to the North Pole." That reminds me of the famous two-liner:"Do you know the way to Town X?""Yes, but you can't get there from here."Today's deal was played in a Canadian event, and South showed that he could circumnavigate the apparently unavoidable diamond finesse.After a takeout double of a preemptive opening bid, the advancer - -as the doubler's partner is called - is assumed to hold 6 points. He makes a simple response unless holding noticeably more than that. However, after North cue-bid to show a very strong hand with spade support, South was happy to control-bid his top heart card. North needed no more encouragement.Maybe West should have led a diamond, which would have killed the contract. However, he led his singleton, optimistically hoping his partner had the heart ace.After East allowed dummy's heart 10 to win the first trick, declarer cashed the spade king (hoping West had a singleton honor) and followed with a trump to his ace, getting the bad news.South continued with a heart to dummy's ace, ran the heart jack, played a heart to his nine and cashed dummy's top clubs, eliminating the rounded suits. With his preparations complete, declarer cast adrift with a trump. East won with the queen and had to lead a diamond away from his king into dummy's ace-queen tenace.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Idon't believein superstition  but - Out to Pastor
author: Dr. James L. Snyder
content:
Idon't believein superstition but - Out to Pastor

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Dr. James L. Snyder | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I don't believe in any of the superstitiousnonsense? thatseemsto be going aroundthese days. Some people have a fear of numbers like 13 and 666. What in the wor l ddoes anumberhavetodowith anything?Not being superstitious, there are times I am slightly confused about life. Something happens that I don't feel I'm in charge of.For example, the other morning, the gracious mistresslof the parsonage entered the living room, where I was sitting on myl easy chair drinking coffee. With alhuge smile, she said, "I got you an apple fritter for this morning." And she gave it to me, smiled at me and then walked away.The following day, I got up and got my coffee, went out to my easy chair in the living room, and started to sip it very carefully.As I was getting situated, the gracious mistress of the parsonage walked in, and I saw in her hand another apple fritter.Again, I got up the following day, went and got my coffee, and sat in my easy chair. In a few mo me nts, in walks lthe grfccio Bs mistress of the parsonage, and in her hand is another apple fritter."Here's an apple fritter for you this morning. I think you'll enjoy it today." She smiled at me, turned around, and returned to the kitc hen.It's not that I can't handle an apple fritter because I can. It's the fact that someone is bringing these apple fritters to me who does not like apple fritters. Something is happening behind the scenes, and I'm anxious to find o ut.The next day, the same thing happened. Now I'm getting to be suspicious. What in the world am I missing here?Not wanting to sabotage my good luck the last four days, I kept silent and enjoyed the fritter. Whatever is behind this, I may never know, but I w ill enjoy it for whatever it is worth.I couldn't help thinking of a Bible verse, "And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not" (Galatians 6:9).Sometimes, the best thing to do is NOTHING and let God have it.Dr. James L. Snyder lives in Ocala, FL with the Gracious Mistress of the Parsonage. Telephone 1-352-216-3025,e-mailjames-snyder51@gmail.com, websitewww.james-snyderministries.com.

 Caption: Meet Sheba, a beautiful 5-year-old spayed female pitbull mix who's ready for a loving forever home. Sheba is a resilient girl who has spent her entire life living outside, so she's eager to experience the comforts of indoor life. She's hoping to find a family who will give her a warm bed, plenty of toys, and lots of love. Although Sheba can be a little shy at first, she is a very friendly dog who loves cuddles and pets once she gets to know you. Her charming smile is just irresistible, and it's hard not to fall in love with her gentle disposition. She is also very playful and loves to chase after toys, making her a great companion for anyone who wants an active and affectionate pet. Because Sheba hasn't had much experience with new environments, it can take her some time to adjust. But with patience and loving support, she will soon blossom into a confident and happy dog who will bring joy to any home. She would do best in a quiet and loving household that will give her the attention and care she deserves. If you are interested in adopting Sheba and giving her the warm home that she deserves call 410-822-0107 or email info@talbothumane.org.

title: Giving thanks by giving back, all year long - Salvation Army prepares for upcoming holiday season
author: Debra Messick; Special To The Star Democrat
content:
Giving thanks by giving back, all year long - Salvation Army prepares for upcoming holiday season

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Debra Messick; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 1179
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - "It takes this whole community for us to be able to do what we do, and they've been so generous, but the need is growing as the economy changes; the need is greater than I think I've ever seen it in all my years serving in the Salvation Army," Captain Wendy Parsons said.The familiar sights of red kettles and ringing bells have returned, again ushering in the season of giving. But for the Salvation Army and it's legion of community "angels," there's no beginning or end to the mission of lending a hand.As Parsons said, "we're always, always busy here." There's the perpetual call to provide safe haven and meals for homeless residents at the Robert and Grace Bair Overnight Shelter, located behind the church and offices building at 200 Washington Street in Cambridge.It's a call often answered by individuals, businesses and organizations who selflessly step up, filling in the open dates on the shelter's meal calendar."We have several donors who make regular, standing commitments, on, say, the second Tuesday of the month, or the 18th of every month, or whatever fits their calendar, to make sure that those folks have a meal," Parsons explained.But in addition to the individual efforts, she's also grateful for the generous ongoing steady donations from local businesses Wawa, Starbucks and Chick-fil-A."Anything left over from that, when the food is available, we can offer as graband-go bags. And that's not just for the homeless. That's also for those who are at risk.There are people from around here who work, but money just doesn't go as far as it used to, so 'either I pack a lunch for my kid or pack a lunch for me.' They send their young one off to school with a lunch, but then go off with nothing.Those folks can come by here and have lunch," Parsons said.Next door, at the William and Carolyn Tyler Day Services Center, essential services, including showers, clean laundry and the graband-go food bags, offer a respite to many mightily trying, but struggling, to get by day to day."There are some people that aren't experiencing homelessness but don't have enough money to do laundry, to pay a dollar a load at the laundromat plus detergent.That's the other thing that people have been very generous about, donating detergent so we can continue to wash clothes for people; it also helps us keep our shelter bedding clean and allows our shelter residents to wash their clothes," Parsons said."Partners in Giving just made a very generous donation to support Matt Ministries, our street feeding campaign, enabling us to provide 400 meals, mostly to kids every Thursday. We take our food truck, our Emergency Disaster Canteen, which we use to support our first responders, out on large calls with snacks, coffee and water," she said.The Salvation Army also maintains and stocks a food pantry, though it's not currently affiliated with the Maryland Food Bank.On the group's Facebook page, shout outs and thank you's are regularly posted, honoring each group donating food, bottled water, cash and other vital needs.Recent "angels" publicly recognized include AARP Chapter 1278, which brought in bags of food; Bishop Weldon Johnson and New Life Christian Ministries and Church, who inspired his congregation, which includes Cambridge Police Department Captain Antoine Patton, to collect 1,000 cans of food; Palm Beach Willies, which shared boxes of russet potatoes; and the Cambridge Police Department's Chief Justin Todd and Captain Patton, who personally delivered truckloads of food.The Mushroom Company's employees voted to award over $1,000 raised from their first Family Fun Day raffle to the Salvation Army.Socks are the most requested item at homeless shelters. One hundred pairs of Bombay socks also arrived at the Tyler Day Services Center, delivered by Dwayne White, chairman of the Social Action Committee from Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Second District."We have food that comes in through a variety of ways, but we also have people that go out and raise funds or have canned food drives. We're currently well stocked with vegetables, but right now we especially need frozen or canned proteins. Just one of those one pound rolls of hamburger, that's spaghetti for a whole family. Canned tuna and chicken also work," Parsons said.The pantry is also currently running very low on nonperishable breakfast items, like cereal, oatmeal or grits.Shelf-stable milk is another ongoing need. Either the donated items or the cash to purchase them are welcome."We don't have a boundary here on food," Parsons said."If you're hungry, you need to come in. I've had somebody come in to get food for their own family and the older lady that lives in the apartment or townhouse next door doesn't have anything, so they share some of the food that we'd given them, it's essentially now feeding two households."We don't want kids to go to school hungry, and that's why we partner with Mid-Shore Meals Til Monday, providing them free space in our Thrift store warehouse.We make sure kids can get a meal on Thursday, and they're making sure they have food over the weekend," she said.Beyond supplying the basic critical crisis needs of food and shelter, Residential Programs Manager Shane Walker makes sure that people have access to information and other helpful resources to get mentally and physically healthy, like Avenues Recovery or Fassett Magee Medical Center."He has contacts, not just here, but in communities across the Shore," Parsons said. "So does our social worker, Mary Justice, who travels to the other counties once a week, working with other agencies to find solutions for people with specific problems including eviction prevention and utility assistance."We're not in competition to see who can do better; we come together to bring that person out of crisis into stability." The Red Kettle campaign, which supports the mission all year long, started Nov. 9 and continues through Dec.23, with both paid and volunteer bell ringers positions still needing to be filled. Individuals, or groups interested in "adopting" a kettle for a day while working in shifts, can find locations closest to them and sign up at registering.com.The other major holiday season initiative, the Angel Tree program, received 400 applicants this year. So far, though, 100 of those are still awaiting adoption. To help ensure these youngsters have a bright Christmas, people can check the QR code or direct link posted on the Salvation Army Cambridge MD Facebook page, or stop by 200 Washington Street and request an angel.The Salvation Army is also urgently seeking donated warehouse space to facilitate the Angel Tree distribution from Dec. 1 through approximately 16, in a location in or close to Cambridge.For more information, call 410-228-2442, or visit southernusa. salvationarmy.org. 
 
 Caption: WENDY PARSONS
 
Through a donation from Partners in Giving to Matt Ministries, the Salvation Army's street feeding campaign, 400 meals, are provided mostly to kids every Thursday. "The kids now know, when they see the red and white truck coming, that the hot dog lady is here. That's 1600 meals a month supported, thanks to Partners in Giving's generosity," says Caption Wendy Parsons.
 
DEBRA MESSICK 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bridge - A economy of spot cards
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - A economy of spot cards

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: 9A | Section: News 
 
 263
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I wish all of my American readers a very happy Thanksgiving. When we are enjoying our Thanksgiving feast, we do not worry too much about the calories being consumed.Sometimes, when playing in a bridge contract, you have to be economical with your cards. In today's deal, the declarer had to be particularly careful with his handling of the trump suit.Despite having only 5 highcard points, North's hand, with four trumps and a doubleton, was well worth a single raise.After winning the first trick with the heart ace, South saw that he had two logical lines of play. He could cash the spade ace, hoping to drop a singleton king, or he could play for East to hold the club king. The former chance being only 26% (a third of the 78% probability of a 2-1 trump split), the declarer opted for the 50-50 finesse.So, at trick two, South led the spade jack from his hand. (This had a secondary advantage: West, afraid his partner held the singleton trump ace, might have ducked his king.) No luck this time, though. West won with the king, cashed his two heart tricks and switched to a diamond.South won with his ace and led the spade seven to dummy's queen. After the club finesse had worked, South played the club three to his ace. Now came the spade three to dummy's five.The club jack was covered and ruffed. Finally, South led his carefully preserved spade four to dummy's six and cashed the club 10, discarding his diamond loser.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Best Friend Acting Rude To Service Workers
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Best Friend Acting Rude To Service Workers

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 18 | Section: News 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I'm having a dilemma with my best friend. Lately, I've been embarrassed by her increasingly rude behavior toward service workers. We recently went to a restaurant, and she was unbelievably disrespectful. She ordered her food, and when it came, she kept asking where her smoothie was. They said it should be on the way, but it wasn't because she never actually ordered it. She kept badgering the staff about it and eventually got the free smoothie she was angling for. Also, she went up to the line cook who made her burger and said that there wasn't enough sauce on it. I didn't hear the full exchange, but by the way he recoiled from her when he handed back her food, I could tell it wasn't a good one. I've tried addressing it subtly, but it doesn't seem to make a difference.How do I approach this situation without damaging the friendship, yet communicate how her behavior is affecting me? - Rude Friend DEAR RUDE FRIEND: Who says you have to be subtle? Your friend has proven that subtlety doesn't work for her. She needs you to be direct and illustrative.Tell her you need to talk to her about something that is bothering you. When you are together, describe how she has behaved with you out in public recently and how you feel about it.Make her understand what you observed about how her behavior impacted the service workers around her and how inappropriate you believe her actions and words were. Let her know she has been behaving in a rude and dismissive manner, and you need her to stop. If she is mad at you for a while, so be it.Friends have to stand up for what's right - even if the cost is temporary disconnection.Harriette Cole is a lifestylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com

title: Keeping things frugal pays off
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Keeping things frugal pays off

 November 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the cost of basic consumer goods continues to be much higher than a year ago, frugality is fast becoming its own art form. I hope the following encouraging tips from your fellow readers on how to be a frugal rockstar will inspire all of us to pay attention and embrace ways we can immediately begin to see more money left in our wallets.Over the past six months, I've been on a tear to declutter and get organized. It has made a huge impact on my spending.Basically, I've stopped spending money on stuff I have already but just didn't know where to find it. The key is knowing what you have and finding it when needed. If you can't find your stuff easily, you might buy something you already have or, even worse, believe you got rid of it, buy a replacement, and then find the original shortly after. - Millie, New Jersey We have a new weekly menu item at our house - Everything But the Kitchen Sink Soup. Basically, this is just throwing a bunch of whateveris-in-the-fridge to make a soup in order to get rid of stuff that's about to go bad or otherwise needs to be used up. You can put so much stuff into soups, and you can freeze leftover soup, too. Really helps to prevent food waste. If you need instructions on how to do this, look up Cotter-Crunch.com. When you get there, use the search function to find that "recipe." - Erica, California I started using grocery delivery during the pandemic. Even taking into consideration the monthly/annual delivery fee, I've stuck with it because it significantly reduces my impulse buys, which continues to save us money. And we have all but eliminated spending on junk food. - Molly, Pennsylvania
