title: 'And the sun was darkened': Eclipse sparking everything from a mass wedding to theories on signs of the Apocalypse
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
'And the sun was darkened': Eclipse sparking everything from a mass wedding to theories on signs of the Apocalypse

 April 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: News 
 
 854
 Words 

 Read News Document

 More than 4 million people — including teams of astronomers and researchers — are expected to travel to parts of the U.S. that will see the moon completely block out the sun during the total solar eclipse Monday.That path of totality stretches from Texas to New England and includes parts of Arkansas, Illinois, Ohio and New York.
Millions more will watch partial versions of eclipse across the country donning protective glasses at local events and outside their homes, schools and workplaces.
The celestial event will be visible across the continental U.S. It's the biggest eclipse in America since 1806 — and there won't be another one until 2044.
But others are looking to the heavens for other reasons.
A quick scan of social media shows a keen and ramped up interest in the eclipse on the spiritual, astrological and metaphysical levels.
That also includes plenty of conjecture and postulation to whether the moon darkening of the sun will bring with it some kind of cosmic event or spiritual upheaval. The curiosities extend to clues or indicators of biblical End Times or other prophecies — including the Rapture, Tribulation and Judgment Day referenced in the Book of Revelation.
Spiritual interests in eclipses are not new, according to theologians.
"Throughout human history people have tried to explain and get a degree of control over things that make us feel very small and out of control," said Erik Thoennes, a professor of theology at Biola University, a private Evangelical college near Los Angeles.
"Cataclysmic events like an eclipse are awesome and can be scary to people, so all cultures have tried to interpret events like this through religious and spiritual lenses," he said.
Events like the April 8 eclipse have spiritual significance across cultures and faiths. Chinese folklore recommends banging pots and pans or making other noises to make an eclipse — which symbolizes a dragon eating the sun — go away. "It has never failed," Thoennes joked.
The focus on events such as a total eclipse and its potential "End of Days" and Armageddon scenarios are especially prevalent among some Christians.
Thoennes said there are nine references in the Bible of the darkening the sun with ties into "divine judgment." That includes when Jesus died on the cross on Good Friday. "And the sun was darkened" reads the Gospel of Luke's account of the crucifixion.
"Unlike some religions that have a cyclical view of time, the biblical view is linear and is heading to a day when God brings his kingdom once and for all and judges people for how we lived our lives, especially in relation to Him," Thoennes said.
"The end of human history on Judgment Day is described in the Bible with dramatic and apocalyptic imagery which includes awesome effects on the natural order. These events include the sun going dark which is why people think about these end time events when there is an eclipse," he said, stressing the importance of enjoying the eclipse as a wonder of creation.
Dave Robbins, vice president of content for End Time Ministries (a Texas-based Pentecostal group), does not expect anything spiritual will happen "during or after the eclipse", pointing to Old Testament scripture saying "be not dismayed at the signs of heaven."
"The Bible does say there will be signs in the sky, but we are not to use them to predict future events," Robbins said.
RAPTURE, ROCKETS & WEDDINGS
But that is not stopping plenty of others from trying to read the tea leaves and connect the spiritual or metaphysical dots related to the eclipse.
The war in the Holy Land between Israel and Hamas in Gaza is helping stoke some of that interest in the Second Coming and prophecies across the Abrahamic faiths.
Social media theories focus on the April 8 eclipse and previous Oct. 2023 eclipse both crossing in an area of southern Illinois named Rapture.
There is also plenty of interest in the restarting of the Large Hadron Collider particle accelerator operated by the European Council for Nuclear Research (CERN) on eclipse day.
NASA is also launching three sounding rockets from Wallops Island on Virginia's Eastern Shore on April 8 "to study how Earth's upper atmosphere is affected when sunlight momentarily dims over a portion of the planet," according to the U.S. space agency.
The three rockets will be launched in 45 minute intervals before, during and after the eclipse and follow up on similar launches during an eclipse in October 2023.
Astrologers are also zeroing in on the eclipse along with other planetary events tying them to current and expected world events. A number of astrologers and End Times prognosticators did not respond to requests for comment about what they are expecting for the eclipse.
Others are taking the plunge — literally on eclipse day.
The Total Eclipse of the Heart Music Festival in Russellville, Arkansas is in the path of totality for the eclipse that cuts across North America.
The music fest is hosting a mass wedding on April 8 along with other events including a worship service on Sunday.
Event organizer Rodney Williams said there will be approximately 5,000 people at the three-day festival and 331 couples have signed for the free Elope at the Eclipse event.
"We have a lot going on," Williams said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Medieval Europe was far from democratic, but that didn't mean tyrants got a free pass
author: Joelle Rollo-Koster The Conversation
content:
Medieval Europe was far from democratic, but that didn't mean tyrants got a free pass

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Joelle Rollo-Koster The Conversation | Section: News 
 
 1157
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My students tend to imagine the Middle Ages as something like the "Kingdom Come" or "Total War" video games: an age of utter political chaos, when swords and daggers ruled, and masculinity and physical strength mattered more than governance.As a historian of the Middle Ages, I believe this turbulent image has less to do with reality than with medievalism – a term for how modern people have reimagined life during Europe's Middle Ages, from roughly 400-1400.
Medieval Europe may have been violent, and its standards for governance would not win praise today. But people could certainly recognize dysfunctional politics, whether in a royal court or in the church, and proposed solutions.
At a time of rising authoritarianism, and when U.S. politics seem mired in chaos, it's worth looking back at how societies centuries ago defined bad governance.
Tyrants, kings and bad bishops
Authors in the Middle Ages thought about politics in terms of leadership and often called bad politics "tyranny," whether they were criticizing one leader or a whole system. In any case, tyranny – or autocracy, as it's often called today – is a concept great thinkers had been discussing since antiquity.
For ancient Greeks, tyranny meant ruling single-handedly for the benefit of one. Aristotle, the foundational thinker on the topic, defined tyranny as the antithesis of perfect rulership, which he believed was kingship: a single ruler ruling for the general interest of all. In his view, a tyrant was controlled by desire for "power, pleasure and wealth," while a king was driven by honor.
Modern political theorist Roger Boesche observed that tyrants tend to decrease the population's leisure time. According to Aristotle, free time allowed people to think and "do" politics – that is, to be citizens.
During the Roman Republic, political thinkers compared tyranny to a diseased limb that needed to be cut off the body politic. Ironically, certain Romans eliminated Julius Ceasar for fear he was becoming a tyrant – only to get Augustus, who eventually became an emperor.
Types of despots
In late antiquity, political writers began to think about tyranny in religious leadership, as well.
In his "Sententiae," a set of books on theology, the seventh century archbishop Isidore of Seville broached the subject of bad bishops. These men conducted themselves like "proud pastors," he wrote, who "tyrannically oppress the common people, they do not guide them, and they demand of their subjects not the glory of God but their own." In general, Isidore criticized political incompetence grounded in the leader's anger, pride, cruelty and greed.
Centuries later, European leaders and writers were still debating the nature of tyranny – and what do to about it.
John of Salisbury, a bishop and philosopher in 12th century England, proposed quite a radical solution: tyrannicide. In "Policraticus," writings about political theory, he wrote that it was a duty to redress the order of things and kill a tyrant who was evil, violent and oppressive.
In John's organic conception of tyranny, however, a tyrant (the body) could exist only with the support of society (its limbs). He was one of the earliest authors to argue that tyranny survived not simply by the whim of the tyrant but with the support of his followers.
By the 14th century, the leading legal thinker of the time, Bartolus de Sassoferrato, differentiated between two types of tyranny. Despots came to power through legal means but acted unlawfully. He defined usurpers, on the other hand, as rulers who assumed power illegitimately, wallowed in pride and did not follow the law.
Taking down a tyrant
At times, disliked or "inconvenient" leaders were deposed, such as England's Richard II. The record of his deposition itemized almost three dozen charges against the dethroned king: from rejecting council, defaulting on loans and exhorting religious authorities to murdering, disinheriting and impeaching rivals. We know that he did not end well: He died during imprisonment in 1400, though exactly how is a mystery.
In Germany, King Wenceslaus of the house of Luxembourg was deposed on Aug. 20, 1400, on grounds of being a "useless, indolent, careless divider and unworthy owner of the empire." The German newspaper Die Welt ranks him as the worst king of Germany – fond of drink and his hunting dogs, and possessed by fits of rage.
Violent disposals of supposed "tyrants" were not always done in the shadows. In 1407, Louis of Orléans, brother of King Charles VI of France, rode unknowingly into a deadly trap. He was assaulted by a large group of men who escaped and chased onlookers away.
Louis was not only brother to Charles "the Mad," but a political rival of John the Fearless, Duke of Burgundy, with both men vying for control during the king's bouts of mental illness. John assumed responsibility for ordering the murder.
He and the lawyer he hired, a theologian named Jean Petit, argued that Burgundy had acted in the interest of the nation by ordering the death of a treasonous and greedy tyrant, and that Louis' killing was therefore justified.
Men of the cloth
Medieval politics did not differentiate much between the secular and religious worlds. Popes were political leaders and could be considered tyrants, too.
During the Great Western Schism of 1378-1417, a split in the Catholic Church when multiple popes competed for the throne, all parties insulted each other with claims of illegitimacy and usurpation.
Enemies of Pope Urban VI, for example, argued a telltale sign of tyranny was his uncontrollable anger, which disqualified him for leadership. Dietrich of Nieheim, who worked at the papal chancery, noted in his chronicle, "The more he spoke, the more Lord Urban became angry, and his face finally became like a burning lamp or fiery flame from anger, and his throat was filled with hoarseness." French cardinals deposed Urban in 1378 on grounds of illegitimacy and tyranny.
He was not the only pope unseated for being tyrannical, even if that exact word was not used. The Council of Constance, a council of European clergymen convened to end the schism, deposed Pope John XXIII in 1415 on grounds ranging from disobedience and corruption to poor administration, dishonesty and obstinacy. Two years later, the same council deposed Pope Benedict XIII, accusing him of persecution, disturbing the peace, fostering division, promoting scandal and schism, and unworthiness.
Medieval bishops and kings are hardly role models for democracies today, but their political world was not so chaotic as we often imagine. Even a world ignorant of democracy attempted to define what bad leadership was and set limits on the authority of the ones they considered irresponsible. Rules of adequate political conduct were established, though the law did not always take precedence over violence.
But it's worthwhile to remember the ways people have viewed bad leadership, hundreds of years before our own era's fractured politics. Today, however, we have a big advantage: We vote our leaders in and out.
The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts. The Conversation is wholly responsible for the content.
Joelle Rollo-Koster is a professor of Medieval history at the University of Rhode Island 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Crafting the perfect spring salad
author: Kristen Wood Food Drink Life
content:
Crafting the perfect spring salad

 April 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Kristen Wood Food Drink Life | Section: Life 
 
 804
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Celebrate the season's vibrancy with this guide to assembling the ultimate spring salad. From choosing fresh greens to mixing in flavorful proteins and homemade dressings, discover how to construct a dish that captures the essence of spring in every bite.Transitioning into spring, the seasonal shift introduces a variety of fresh produce perfect for revitalizing meals. The art of assembling the ultimate spring salad involves constructing a harmonious blend of textures, colors and flavors.
With an emphasis on freshness and seasonality, combining these elements into a salad creates a dish that is not only beautiful and flavorful but also maximizes the nutritional benefits of seasonal produce. This approach not only enhances the taste experience but also supports sustainable eating habits by utilizing ingredients at their peak.
Setting the foundation
At the heart of every great spring salad lies its foundation: the greens. Spring brings an array of tender and flavorful greens that can transform a simple salad into something extraordinary. Choosing the right mix of greens is the first step in crafting the perfect spring salad. From the buttery softness of Boston and bibb lettuce to the peppery bite of arugula and the earthy richness of spinach, each type of green offers its own unique flavor and texture.
The key to a perfect base is variety. Mixing different types of greens enhances a salad's visual appeal with varying shades of green and creates an abundance of delicious flavors in each bite. For a truly spring-inspired salad, consider incorporating some of the season's first tender greens, such as baby kale, sprouts, mâche and watercress. These greens are not only packed with nutrients but also have a freshness that can only be found in the spring.
Fruits and vegetables
Leafy greens provide a tender, flavorful base, creating the perfect backdrop for the bright, crisp textures and sweet, tangy flavors of delicious spring produce. Radishes add a peppery crunch, while sweet peas and asparagus bring a delicate, earthy, unmistakably spring flavor.
For a touch of sweetness, strawberries, mangoes and citrus fruits can be sprinkled throughout a spring salad, creating a delightful contrast with the more savory elements. Selecting the freshest produce and combining these elements thoughtfully ensures a salad is as beautiful to look at as it is to eat.
Proteins and crunch
Adding protein to a spring salad adds substance, making it a satisfying meal on its own. Grilled chicken or fish can be marinated in herbs and lemon for a zesty flavor that complements the greens. For vegetarians, chickpeas, black beans or tofu are excellent protein-rich additions that bring a pleasant texture to the mix.
A crunch factor is essential for adding depth and interest to a salad. Sliced almonds, pumpkin seeds or homemade croutons can be sprinkled over the top for a satisfying bite. These elements not only add a protein boost but also introduce a variety of textures that keep every bite interesting.
Dressing it up
The dressing is the final flourish that ties all the salad components together. Light and zesty dressings are preferred for spring salads to heavy, creamy ones. A basic vinaigrette made with extra virgin olive oil, lemon juice, a touch of honey and fresh herbs can be whisked together in just minutes.
For something a bit more adventurous, a blend of avocado, yogurt and lime creates a creamy dressing without the heaviness. Fresh herbs, such as basil, mint or dill, can be blended into dressings for an extra pop of spring flavor. The key is to dress the salad lightly just before serving to maintain the freshness and crispness of the ingredients.
Serving and presentation
How you serve a spring salad should be as colorful and inviting as the ingredients it contains. Start with a large, shallow bowl or platter to allow all the components to be displayed. Layer the greens first, then artfully arrange the vegetables, fruits and proteins on top. A sprinkle of edible flowers or fresh herbs just before serving adds a gourmet touch that can elevate the salad to a show-stopping centerpiece. The beauty of a spring salad lies in its simplicity and the natural appeal of its ingredients, so let them shine.
Final thoughts
Crafting the perfect spring salad is an art that celebrates the best the season has to offer. The joy of salad-making lies in the freedom to experiment with flavors and ingredients, always resulting in a dish as nutritious as it is delicious. Embrace the creativity and freshness of spring in every bite, and let your salad reflect the season's best.
Kristen Wood is a photographer, food writer, recipe developer and the creative force behind MOON and spoon and yum, a vegetarian food blog. She is also the author of Vegetarian Family Cookbook, Fermented Hot Sauce Cookbook and Hot Sauce Cookbook for Beginners. Kristen's work has graced the pages of Elle, Healthline, Martha Stewart, Chicago Sun-Times and more, establishing her as a trusted voice in the food industry.

title: 'Absolute devastation': Wars, violence in Haiti, Sudan overshadowed, overlooked
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
'Absolute devastation': Wars, violence in Haiti, Sudan overshadowed, overlooked

 April 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1690
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With the U.S. poised to allocate $95 billion in new war focused on Ukraine and Israel and global eyes glued to Gaza and Iran, wars, violence and worsening strife in Sudan and Haiti — two of the world's poorest countries — have been overshadowed.The violence in Haiti and Sudan includes mounting death tolls from gang, mob and paramilitary bloodshed, sexual assaults against women and girls, surges in refugees and worsening food situations.
U.S. Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, both Maryland Democrats, and others are trying to bring attention and resolution to the violent conflicts that have ravaged Sudan in Africa and Haiti in the Caribbean.
GANG VIOLENCE, 'MOB JUSTICE'
A new United Nations report released Friday shows more than 2,505 people (including 82 children) were killed and more than 438 people kidnapped in Haiti's gang violence during the first quarter of 2024. The death toll is up 53% from the previous quarter.
"More than 4,600 inmates escaped from the two main prisons in the capital, and at least 22 police stations, sub-police stations and other police buildings were looted or set on fire, and 19 police officers were killed or injured," the UN report said of the anarchy also referencing gang continued use of sexual violence against women and girls.
"Mob justice" incidents in Haiti killed 141 persons during the first three months of 2024. There have been an estimated 7,300 deaths in the gang wars since 2023, which have worsened since the assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse in July 2021.
There have been more than 362,000 Haitians displaced in the violence, and the Biden administration faces criticism after it resumed deportation flights back to the ravaged island nation.
'ABSOLUTE DEVASTATION'
The war in Sudan between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces marked a grim one-year anniversary on April 15.
The conflict between rival military factions has seen more than 15,000 people killed, more than 8 million others displaced and more than 2 million refugees.
There have been more than 150 Christian churches damaged and destroyed, and Christians have been attacked during the paramilitary civil war in overwhelmingly Muslim Sudan, according to the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom.
Cardin urged additional U.S. and international aid to Sudan in comments on the Senate Floor Friday.
"In the last year there has been absolute devastation in Sudan. And at every turn, unarmed Sudanese have been in the crosshairs. These armed groups have committed extrajudicial killings. They have indiscriminately bombed civilian targets like hospitals that have used rape and sexual violence against woman of certain ethnic groups as a weapon of war. They have razed cities and towns, killing inhabitants, strangling commerce and trade. They have destroyed farmlands and forced farmers to leave, preventing harvests," Cardin said.
He cited a World Food Program warning that Sudan is on the verge of "unprecedented levels of starvation."
Van Hollen spoke at an April 15 event in Washington on the Sudan war hoping to generate more interest in getting humanitarian supplies and a ceasefire forged.
"There are lots of crises around the world that we need to address. We need to address the crisis in Sudan right now," Van Hollen said at the Unite for Sudan event.
"However we do it, we need to get more humanitarian assistance to Sudan now as we work to end the war. The best way to help people of course is to get a ceasefire and end this war and hold people accountable," he said.
'WE NEED TO EXPAND THE PIE'
The Maryland lawmakers and relief agencies are calling for more U.S. and international humanitarian aid to Haiti and Sudan as Congress moves forward on a new $60.8 billion war assistance package for Ukraine in its war against invading Russian forces and a $26.4 billion outlay for Israel's war against Hamas and Gaza. The latter includes $9.2 billion in humanitarian aid for Gaza, Sudan and other global trouble spots.
Cardin — who chairs the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee — called for increased funding for the U.S. Agency for International Development, or USAID.
"We need to expand the pie, not shrink it. Otherwise, when we try to address one crisis, we have to take money from another emergency circumstance. We should not have to choose between saving starving Sudanese or saving starving Gazans. We should not have to choose between helping Haitians or helping Ukrainians," Cardin said.
The Biden administration's FY 2025 budget calls for $42.8 billion for foreign assistance budgets for USAID and the State Department. That includes $10.3 billion for USAID humanitarian and refugee programs.
Some baseline budget numbers for U.S. aid have been down amid partisan budget fights, but they have been bolstered by supplemental spending packages.
The U.S. has sent $1 billion in relief aid to Sudan since October 2023, according to the Commission on International Religious Freedom. The U.S. has moved $171 million in humanitarian funds to Haiti since October 2022. There are also questions to continue regarding the $13 billion in money raised for Haiti — including by prominent U.S. celebrities and the Clinton Foundation — after the devastating 2010 earthquake.
The Biden administration has already sent $75 billion to Ukraine, and Israel gets $3.3 billion annually in U.S. weapons and other military aid.
The Pentagon has sent additional munitions and weapons to Israel since Hamas' Oct. 7 terror attacks sparked the Holy Land war. The conflict has caused significant civilian casualties and dire conditions and has seen more than 13,000 and 10,000 women killed, according to the United Nations.
The U.S. spends close to $1 trillion on its military and national security annually.
'WORLD'S LARGEST HUNGER CRISIS'
U.S. Rep. Sydney Kamlager-Dove (D-California) said the conflict In Sudan is "the world's largest hunger and internal displacement crisis."
"The international community must step up to push for an end to the fighting and contribute to the grossly under-resourced humanitarian response," Kamlager-Dove said.
Mostly Christian South Sudan became its own country in 2011. Sudan, which has a population of more than 49 million people, is overwhelmingly Muslim.
Rosemary DiCarlo, the United Nations under-secretary-general, said the Sudan war is "a crisis of epic proportions."
In Haiti, the situation has gone from bad to worse. Criminal gangs control much of Port-au-Prince, which has a population of more than 2.6 million.
The Biden administration sent a special anti-terrorism Marine Corps unit to Haiti in March to protect the U.S. Embassy.
U.S. Army Gen. Laura Richardson, who is head of the Southern Command, said the Pentagon has a range of contingency plans related to Haiti, including a mass migration.
Richardson told the Atlantic Council in March as of now, the U.S. doesn't have plans to send troops into Haiti but the situation needs to be addressed internationally, according to the Defense Department.
There are also concerns about U.S.-made guns, ammunition and other weapons making their way to Haitian gangs via smuggling and shipments into privately owned ports.
The U.S. has been trying to get a special police force from Kenya deployed in Haiti, but that has been delayed by the ongoing violence and the resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry in March. Jimmy Chérizier, a former Haitian police officer known by the nickname "Barbecue," has become a central figure in the island's crime and chaos.
On April 12, a Transitional Presidential Council was established to structure new elections, a new prime minister and deployment of an international police force.
But relief efforts have been challenging beyond the violence. A UN appeal to raise $720 million to help the situation raised 34% of that goal last year. Humanitarian groups have launched a new $674 million relief effort.
'OUTRAGED'
The situation in Haiti has resulted in more refugees heading to the U.S., some via boat to Florida and others entering the U.S. and seeking asylum via the border with Mexico.
U.S. Sens. Rick Scott and Marco Rubio, both Florida Republicans, wrote Biden last month voicing worries about the administration "opening the floodgates" to a mass migration from Haiti.
On the other side of the immigration issue, Haitian advocates and their U.S. allies slammed reports April 18 that the Biden administration had restarted flights to deport migrants.
"I am deeply outraged about recent reporting that the Department of Homeland Security has resumed deportations to Haiti. A country facing a political crisis of epic proportions, where basic human rights can no longer be protected, women and girls are being sexually abused on a daily basis, young boys are recruited into becoming child soldiers, over 5 million are heading towards famine, and 80% of the capital is controlled by gangs," said U.S. Rep. Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick (D-Florida).
"The reality is that life in Haiti is currently unbearable. Deportation, under these circumstances, is simply an act of atrocious cruelty. We are either the leader of the free world who welcomes all refugees seeking safety, or we're not. I urge the Biden-Harris Administration to reverse this misguided decision and stop deportations immediately," she said.
ROUGH HISTORY
The current situation in Haiti has seen relief workers in peril, and Haiti has long been a haven for human and sex trafficking. The Dominican Republic has also fortified its border and cracked down on Haitian refugees and migrants.
Haiti has long been the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. Its history has been littered by violence, poverty, coups and corruption. The U.S. occupied Haiti from 1915 to 1934 — 18 years. That came after a violent mob killed Haiti's tyrannical president in 1915 and President Woodrow Wilson sent in U.S. Marines at the behest of National City Bank of New York (which is now Citibank / Citigroup), which had taken the reins of Haiti's central bank.
The Caribbean nation's economic development has further been stunted by a series of payments it made to France over the years as part of its independence agreement. Haiti's debt totaled $21 billion and was financed by Citibank and French banks.
While Florida, in particular Miami, and New York City have the largest Haitian populations in the U.S, Maryland's Eastern Shore and Baltimore areas are home to a number of residents of Haitian ancestry.
Northern Virginia, Phoenix and the Dallas-Fort Worth areas have the largest Sudanese populations in the U.S. Van Hollen said efforts to draw attention to the Sudanese conflict need to continue.
"We're going to need to grow our numbers. We're going to need to make sure we are calling out injustice in Sudan," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on international conflicts in Haiti and Sudan, humanitarian crises, and U.S. foreign policy responses. While 'National News' could marginally apply due to U.S. involvement, the content is primarily about global events rather than domestic U.S. news. Other topics like 'Public Safety' or 'Health' address partial aspects but not the core focus on international warfare and displacement.

title: Reporting election results can get colorful
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Reporting election results can get colorful

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 728
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In November, the every four-year routine of counting votes to determine who has been elected as the U.S president will, as always, generate intense and widely followed media coverage.While much attention will be focused on the popular vote results nationwide, the most important and meaningful results are which candidate carried enough states to win in the electoral college. Accordingly, media reporting on election night will focus largely on which states went red and which states went blue.
For this commentary, I did a deep dive into the history on the origins, uses, and perhaps some largely forgotten practice changes over time on red and blue color labeling in the American political arena.
There are several thoughts on how color labels came to be used in American politics. Some suggest they came from Britain's Parliament where blue has long been associated with their right leaning political party (the Conservative Party) and red has long been associated with their left leaning political party (the Liberal Party).
I suggest a more plausible explanation were decisions by American television networks to use color images in their coverage of presidential election results.
The late 1950s and early 1960s included a wide range of changes in American culture. One was a massive shift in how Americans received entertainment and news in their homes.
After World War II, steadily increasing numbers of Americans stopped listening to radios and started watching televisions. That trend accelerated when color televisions became more affordable and more widely found in American living rooms. By 1972, a majority of American households had color televisions.
Then, as now, the most important measure of success for television broadcasters is attracting and retaining viewers. The more viewers the more revenue from commercials. What better way to do that than use colorful and easy to understand updates in news broadcasts for election night coverage of presidential elections.
For almost 50 years, presidential election results coverage by the three legacy networks (ABC, NBC and CBS) had no uniform protocol on which colors to use to identify state results for presidential election candidates.
In some presidential election cycles, ABC, NBC and CBS used blue to designate states won by the Democratic presidential candidate, in other years they used red. The color pattern was reversed with designating state states won by the Republican presidential candidate. In one election cycle, for unexplained reasons, ABC used yellow to designate states won by the Republican presidential candidate. The unintended outcome was confusion especially with viewers who were "channel surfers" continuously searching for the most recent results.
No small wonder that veteran journalism observer Jodi Enda wrote the following in a 2020 Smithsonian Magazine article "When Republicans Were Blue and Democrats Were Red." "In the beginning, blue was red and red was blue, and they changed back and forth from election to election and network to network in what appears, in hindsight, to be a flight of whimsy."
Uniformity and continuity with color assignments finally became the norm starting with the 1996 presidential election cycle.
Presently ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, Fox and MSNBC all use the same color guidelines. They use blue for identifying states won by Democratic presidential candidates and red for identifying states won by Republican presidential candidates.
Beginning in the 2000 presidential election cycle, the use of colors expanded greatly beyond being used to display state by state presidential election results.
Since then, red and blue labels have been used and are routinely used to label political candidates and elected officials at all levels; campaigns, and where partisan elections are held — states, counties, cities and, towns.
No doubt that will continue but one major change may be in the future due to steadily increasing numbers of unaffiliated voters and independent candidates.
Despite the fact that no third-party or independent presidential candidate has had success in winning states in presidential elections since George Wallace won five states and 46 electoral votes in 1968, it may happen again. It may happen as soon as this year.
In recent years two current U. S. Senators have already been elected after running as independents — Bernie Sanders in Vermont and Angus King in Maine.
If or when an independent or third-party candidate wins a state or states in a presidential campaign, the new color used to record that may be purple, reflecting a new normal when blue and red are no longer the exclusive options.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes the historical evolution of color coding in election reporting, focusing on media practices and political symbolism rather than current events, entertainment, or cultural topics. While related to national politics, it is a historical/analytical column rather than traditional news.

title: Keep bridge name neutral
author: Staff Writer
content:
Keep bridge name neutral

 April 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 131
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Concerning your pinion article in the April 17 issue of the Dorchester Star where you support renaming the Frederick C. Malkus Bridge as the Gloria Richardson Bridge, I suggest that if you truly want to contribute to the end of divisiveness in our society, then just call it the Choptank River Bridge. Don't name it after anyone. Someone will always be offended. The same applies to the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore. Just call it the Patapsco River Bridge.Why do we have to name everything after people, like airports and highways and buildings. It's a sign of the times, and times change.
Keep it neutral, like the Empire State Building. Now there's a great name that should last forever, unless somebody feels that it should be named after someone.
DAVE THATCHER
Cambridge

title: 'Go, and from now on, sin no more'
author: Paul Twining
content:
'Go, and from now on, sin no more'

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Paul Twining | Section: News 
 
 274
 Words 

 Read News Document

 King David said it well: "Blessed is the one whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered." (Psalm 32:1)As I contemplate this truth, I am reminded of the forgiveness Jesus extended to the woman caught in the act of adultery. The religious leaders who brought her to Jesus, reminding Him that the law of Moses commanded her to be stoned, demanded Him to give His opinion.
He said to them, "Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at her." One by one, they all walked away.
Then Jesus asked her, "Where are your accusers? Has no one condemned you?" She said, "No one, Lord." And Jesus said, "Neither do I condemn you; go, and from now on sin no more." (John 8:11)
This is essentially what Jesus says to every forgiven sinner — "Go, and from now on, sin no more."
The apostle Paul elaborates concerning this truth in Galatians 2:20: "I have been crucified with Christ. It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me. And the life I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave Himself for me." What gets crucified with Christ is our old self — in other words, the way we lived before we experienced the saving grace of God. (Romans 6:6)
The world we live in is in desperate need of seeing people that are truly transformed by the power of God. This really is possible. To find out how, I challenge you to read Colossians 3:1–17.
Paul Twining is the Caroline County coordinator for National Day of Prayer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Replacing fear with love

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Bretheren | Section: Columns 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There are many scriptures that tell us to "fear the Lord." My early Christian experiences certainly taught me that. I remember a pamphlet that showed sinners drowning in a literal lake of fire for all eternity. Scary stuff.Author and pastor Rob Bell presents us with an interesting thought though — do we really believe that God, who loves us so much, is going to condemn billions of people, and reward only a select few with heaven? Will He really condemn these billions, throughout history, with eternal torment for things they did in a few short years of their life on Earth? It's not a question I would presume to know the answer to.
I do know this, just as well as you do — our God is a God of love. He loves us so much that He gave His only begotten Son. Therefore, I prefer to substitute "fear" with "love." For instance, Proverbs 1:7 tells us, "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge. Fools despise wisdom and instruction." I like to think that "the love of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge."
I must admit, I have no fear of the Lord. Instead, what I have is respect, reverence, awe, love and an appreciation of His love for me. The love He shows us cannot not be compared to anything else. The angels who appeared to the shepherds, in the Gospel of Luke, gave us good advice: "Don't be afraid, because a savior is born."
Jesus came to us — God in the flesh — bringing love and salvation.
If we live a life of righteousness, following Christ, what do we have to fear? Nothing. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Baked beans: a year-round favorite
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Baked beans: a year-round favorite

 May 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Baked beans are a favorite any time of the year but most definitely during the summer.These beans are a picnic favorite, and who can have hot dogs without some baked beans. People around the world love these beans — each culture having their own version of cooking them. T
he American baked bean originated back to the Native American Eastern tribes. Their method of cooking — soaked beans mixed wirh bear fat and maple syrup, placed in earthen pots or deer skin pots and hung-over open fires and slow cooking until tender.
The early pilgrims who were Puritan Christians did not allow working on Sundays, which also meant no cooking on Sundays. The cooks would prepare these beans on Saturday to be slow cooked on Sunday over the low wooden fires.
Extra bread was made and set aside for the Sunday meal over the low wood fires. When they returned from church, the meal was ready.
The great Boston bean connection occurred when Boston became popular for its rum production, salt pork availability and molasses production. In 1919 there was a molasses tank explosion.
One of the Purity Distilling Company tanks exploded near Boston's Harbor. Almost 12,000 tons of brown sticky thick molasses gushed from a storage tank. Plenty of molasse was to be had.
Therefore, the Boston baked bean was born.
Whether you like your baked beans slow cooked with brown sugar, molasses or honey, there is no doubt they are delicious with some BBQ sauce. Try some of today's recipes and enjoy those baked beans.
OLD FASHIONED BAKED BEANS
1 lb navy beans, 1 tsp baking soda water to cover, 1 tsp salt, 3 oz ham or 3 oz cooked bacon, 1/4 cup dark brown sugar, 1 medium onion (chopped). Add 1 tsp baking soda to 6 cups of water. Bring water to a boil. Sort through beans for debris. Add navy beans to water. Boil for 10 minutes. Turn off heat. Cover pot. Let sit overnight. Rinse beans well. Add beans and all other ingredients to an oven proof pot with a tight fitting lid. Stir well. Add water until the beans are just covered. Cover the pot with a lid. Bake for 5 to 6 hours at 300 degrees. Every hour, stir and add water to cover if beans are drying out. The final product should be thick and not runny.
HELEN'S SWEET AND SOUR BEANS
Using a large skillet — cook 8 strips of diced bacon until crisp. Place bacon on paper towels. Drain and reserve 2 tbsps of the drippings. In the drippings, sauté 2 medium onions (thinly sliced) until tender. Add 1 cup packed brown sugar, 1/2 cup cider vinegar, 1 tsp salt, 1 tbsp ground mustard, and 1/2 tsp garlic powder. Bring these ingredients to a boil. In a crock pot combine the bacon with one 28 ounce can undrained pork and beans, one 16 ounce can kidney beans, rinsed and drained, one 16 ounce can lima beans, drained, one 15 ounce can black eyed peas, rinsed and drained. Add the onion mixture and then the bacon — mix well. Cover and cook on high for 3 to 4 hours. Enjoy with rolls or corn bread squares.
BBQ BAKED BEANS
2 slices bacon (diced), 1 small sweet onion (diced), 1 bell pepper (diced), 2 garlic cloves (minced), 1 tbsp smoked paprika, 1/4 to 1/2 tsp chipotle chili powder, ¼ tsp salt, ¼ tsp freshly cracked black pepper, 2 tbsps apple cider vinegar, 2 tbsps BBQ sauce, 2 tbsps ketchup, 1 tbsp Dijon mustard, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 2 (22 oz) cans baked beans of your choice. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.
Heat a large (oven safe, if you don't want to transfer) skillet over medium-low heat and add the bacon. Cook until it's brown and crisp and most of the fat is rendered. Stir in the onion, pepper and garlic. Cook, stirring often, until everything softens, about 5 minutes. Stir in the paprika, chili powder, salt and pepper. Cook for 1 to 2 minutes. Stir in the vinegar, BBQ sauce, ketchup, mustard and brown sugar until combined. Stir in the baked beans directly from the can. Bring the mixture to a boil, then turn off the heat. I suggest tasting the beans here and adding more salt, pepper or heat if desired. If you'd like, you can lay a few strips of bacon on top of the beans here too.
Place the skillet or transfer to an oven-safe dish in the oven and bake for 30 to 35 minutes, or until bubbly and syrupy. Remove and let cool slightly before serving. You can make these ahead of time — cook them in the skillet then let cook to room temperature and cover, placing in the fridge. Bake the next day (or whenever you're ready). These also freeze well.
TEXAS BAKED BEANS
1 (16 oz) can pork and beans, 1 (16 oz) can red kidney beans, 1 (16 oz) can pinto beans, 8 slices bacon or 8 slices turkey bacon (cooked crisp, then crumbled), 1 lb lean ground beef, 1 onion (chopped), 1 tbsp prepared mustard, 1 1/2 cups ketchup, 3/4 cup brown sugar, 1/4 cup white sugar. Fry the bacon crisp and then crumble. Put aside. Brown the ground beef with the chopped onions. Drain. Combine all ingredients, except bacon, in a large casserole dish. Top with the crumbled bacon. Bake at 350 degrees for about 1 hour.
COWBOY STYLE BAKED BEANS
1 pound dried navy, pinto or pink beans; 2 large onions (diced), 12 ounces smoked pork or ham steak (chopped), 3 cups chicken stock, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/4 cup dark molasses, 1/4 cup ketchup, 3 tbsps dark brown sugar (plus more as needed), salt and pepper. Soak the beans overnight in water in a large bowl. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Sauté the onions and pork over medium heat in a cast iron Dutch oven until the onions are tender, about 10 minutes. Add the drained beans, pork, chicken stock, cayenne, molasses, ketchup, brown sugar, and salt and pepper to taste and bring to a boil. Cover the casserole and transfer to the oven. Bake for 3 1/2 to 4 hours, until the beans are tender. Serve topped with a sprinkle of brown sugar.
COUNTRY BEAN SUPPER
This is a very hearty combination of different types of beans combined with your choice of hamburger, such as turkey or bison or the healthy 90/10 beef. This recipe is easy to make, very filling and simply add a roll to complete the meal. Perfect for a busy day dinner, Saturday lunch or hungry teens.
1 16-oz package of 90/10 ground beef, 1 cup diced white onion, 1/4 cup of cooked bacon, 1 45-oz can of red or any kind of kidney beans, 1 can of butter beans, 1 can of cannellini beans, 1 tsp of salt, 1/2 tsp of black pepper, 1 tbsp of apple cider vinegar, two tablespoons of water, one cup of ketchup, ½ cup of brown sugar, 1 tbsp of liquid smoke. Brown one pound of beef with 1 cup diced onion until well cooked, drain. In a crockpot place the beef and onion mixture with 1/4 cup fried bacon, drained and broken into pieces, one 45 ounce can of pork and beans, one 15 ounce can of kidney beans, drained, one 15 ounce can of butter beans, drained, one 15 ounce can of cannellini beans undrained, one tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, one tbsp vinegar, two tbsps water, one cup ketchup, 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1 tbsp liquid smoke. Mix slightly, place lid on crock pot — turn on low heat and cook for 4 to 6 hours. Serve with rolls. Perfect for the busy days. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it touches on cultural aspects, the primary content is recipe-based food preparation, which doesn't align with any specific topic in the list. The 'Food' section of the newspaper further indicates this is a culinary feature rather than a cultural or local news item.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Read your Bible to reason with God
author: ED CONNASTER
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Read your Bible to reason with God

 May 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ED CONNASTER | Section: Columns 
 
 231
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most people do not like to read the Bible. Some people disagree with what it says, or do not like the way it makes them feel about themselves.However, most people do not realize that when you read the Bible, you are entering into the spiritual realm of reasoning with God.
God desires us to reason with Him, and even invites us to does this in Isaiah 1:18.
"Come now, and let us reason together, saith the Lord: though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool."
How is this even possible?
Reasoning with God always gives birth to questions within our hearts and minds. Those questions cause us to seek Him and find answers.
God is not afraid of your hardest questions. The ultimate thing He wants you to know is that He loves you so much that He sent His on begotten son to die for your sins, so that if you will turn from your sin, confess Jesus as your Lord, and believe in your heart that God raised Him from the dead, you will be forgiven and saved from His coming judgement on this sinful world.
So read your Bible, and start in the Gospel of John. God is waiting to reason with you, and you will not regret it.
Ed Connaster is pastor of Refuge Christian Fellowship Church.

title: Korean War veteran, 92, mindful of those made 'supreme sacrifice'
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Korean War veteran, 92, mindful of those made 'supreme sacrifice'

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Korean War veteran Zeford Gaddy is blind because of injuries he suffered to his eyes in battle some 70 years ago, but the 92-year-old Port Deposit resident downplays his blindness whenever someone broaches the subject.That's because Gaddy knows all too well that some of his fellow soldiers lost their lives in combat during his 21-month stint in Korea.
"They made the supreme sacrifice," Gaddy emphasized, before noting that he is mindful of and ever-grateful to all U.S. servicemen and servicewomen who were killed in all wars and conflicts.
Raised in Cecil County, Gaddy was drafted by the U.S. Army in the early 1950s, when he was about 21, and he was sent "straight to Korea" after finishing boot camp in Fort Indiantown Gap, Pa.
"Something had to be done and others did it before me. I was just picking up the baton," Gaddy said, explaining how he viewed his wartime military service as necessary and as a privilege. "It was an honor. I knew what my purpose was. I was there to serve and protect our country."
Gaddy spent much of his tour of duty in battle zones and, as a result, he experienced that deep bond — that brotherhood — that soldiers have with one another because they're fighting side by side. "You lived on a line and that puts you in a different frame of mind," he said.
Despite the closeness that grows among soldiers in combat, there was little time for mourning in the heat of battle when a serviceman was killed, according to Gaddy. "When one dropped out, you had to move up. Everything was too fast-paced. You had to keep the rest safe," Gaddy said.
Gaddy is blind today because metal fragments from a nearby explosion peppered his eyes in the midst of battle, sending him to a military hospital for about one week before he returned to duty.
But the damage to his eyes caused his vision to diminish gradually over the decades that followed Gaddy's honorable discharge from the Army in 1953. Gaddy's wife, Monolyne — they have been married 62 years — told the Cecil Whig that her husband has undergone 10 surgeries because he found himself plagued by cysts every time once-imbedded metal fragments surfaced on the front of his body.
On Sunday, Gaddy will be recognized for his wartime military service at Port Deposit VFW Post 8185 moments after the Memorial Day ceremony is completed, confirmed William Ward, who is the post commander. (Kevin Clark, a Gaddy family friend, was instrumental in bringing attention to Gaddy.)
"We are going to present him with a VFW coin at the end of our ceremony," Ward said.
Ward noted that Gaddy will be recognized during the portion of the program when the post honors "our living veterans," which occurs after servicemen and servicewomen who made the ultimate sacrifice have been honored. During that latter part of the ceremony, Ward will present the Order of St. Michael medallion — a high honor — to one of the veterans affiliated with the Post 8185.
As for recognizing Gaddy, Ward commented, "I will speak well of him, and I will speak well of his service." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Never forget: Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends
author: RICK STEVENS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Never forget: Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK STEVENS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, I attended a family wedding on Maryland's Eastern Shore, staying overnight in the small village of Cambridge.To pass the time between nuptial obligations, I decided to walk around the town. At the corner of Church and High streets, I encountered the Christ Episcopal Church and its accompanying cemetery, which I later learned has served as a burial ground dating to the 1690s. My innate curiosity led me through the iron gates to stroll among the gravestones. I discovered that four former Maryland governors are buried there, along with generations of local parish families.
Time and weather have rendered many markers nearly illegible, but one stone slab, adorned with an American flag, caught my eye.
Levin J. Newcomb Jr. was born April 27, 1918. He died June 19, 1944, in Normandy, France. Capt. Newcomb was just 26 years old. His marker records he was a member of Company A, 115 Infantry, 29th Division. It's reasonable to assume Capt. Newcomb was the company commander. The marker is engraved with the crossed rifles of an infantryman and the blue and gray yin and yang patch of the 29th Infantry Division. It includes the scripture, "Greater love hath no man but that a man lay down his life for his friends."
At the top are the words, "IN MEMORY OF," a phrase that intrigued me. Why were those words necessary?
It turns out Capt. Newcomb's final resting place is actually Plot G, Row 25, Grave 7 in the Normandy American Cemetery in Colleville-sur-Mer, France. He never came home to Dorchester County.
It was common in that era for servicemembers to be interred close to where they died. Many families, seeking closure or hoping to create a physical connection to their loved ones, placed tributes in their local cemeteries. Those markers allowed them to share their experience of loss with others in the community and perhaps cope with what must have been nearly intolerable grief.
This year marks the 80th anniversary of the Normandy invasion. It's the 80th anniversary of a campaign between June and September of 1944 that saw some 29,000 Americans killed in action.
Today, it's impossible to know the positive impact the fallen might have had on their families and communities across our nation had they survived the war. Robbed of life's bounties and promise, we'll never know how soldiers like Capt. Newcomb would have contributed to the greater good of society. I imagine him sitting in a pew in Christ Church with his wife, June, and young son, Richard, enjoying tasty Maryland crab at picnics, quietly being a pillar of the community … rarely talking about his experiences in combat.
But it was not to be. His brave commitment to a calling greater than himself is his legacy.
Capt. Levin J. Newcomb Jr., and others like him, are why we pause and reflect each Memorial Day. Understandably, I'd never heard of Capt. Newcomb before my unplanned wandering through that small, timeworn garden of remembrance. Yet, I'm honored to have learned a little more about him while researching this message. More importantly, I'm reminded of our explicit duty to "never forget" the contributions of our fallen … wherever they may rest in peace.
Retired Maj. Gen. Rick Stevens is senior vice president and director of business development at Dawson & Associates. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it mentions a local cemetery and community memory, the primary content is about historical remembrance rather than current local events, historical facts, or official notices.

title: Fun on a bun: hot dog recipes for summer weather
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Fun on a bun: hot dog recipes for summer weather

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The last few days of school are nearing, graduations and proms are in process, last minute exams are being held and the calendar is already filling for June.One thing is certain — two to three meals a day still need to be prepared, and today I am here to put a smile on your face and a hot dog in your tummy.
I was a sophomore in high school when my mother became ill and had to go to Baltimore for treatment Monday through Thursday and would return home on Friday afternoon. My sister was married and prepared food several nights each week.
My job was to cook for my dad and three younger brothers several nights each week. Well, thanks to the Esskay Company, I became a professional hot dog and burger queen.
One night it would be hot dogs on a bun, the next night it would be burgers on buns, and then the third night it would be their choice — burger or dogs.
I made it nice for them. I would have a platter all filled with chopped and sliced onions, sliced tomatoes, relishes, sliced pickles, mustard and ketchup. I was so proud of how nice the table looked and the cleanup was so quick and easy.
One of my brothers told mom years later that he did not eat hot dogs or burgers for many years, and my dad said his heartburn problems came from overeating burgers and hot dogs. My baby brother said he always wondered "where are the fries" but never asked.
I cannot move on with recipes until I tell you about my brief experience with the hot dog toaster.
I found a hot dog toaster while shopping one day. It looked exactly like a regular toaster, but the slots were wider and only held 4 hot dogs. I anxiously proceeded to try this great invention — no boiling water in the saucepan with a drop of vinegar (for relief of heartburn my dad would say), no having to drag out the grill or the iron fry pan.
I was smiling as I prepared my sides when the dogs started burning. I couldn't get the release button to work, and they kept burning. Through the smell and smoke I quickly unplugged this thing, and it currently is at rest in a Caroline County dumpster.
Now, here are the recipes.
CHICAGO STYLE HOT DOG
4 hot dog buns, 3 tbsps melted butter, 1 tbsp poppy seeds, 4 hot dogs, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 1/4 cup pickle relish, 1/4 white onion (finely chopped), 1 tomato (sliced into half moons), 4 pickle spears, 8 sport peppers, 1/2 tsp celery salt.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Brush outside of hot dog buns with butter and sprinkle poppy seeds on top. Place buns, seam side down, on a baking sheet. Bake until lightly toasted and poppy seeds stick to the bun, about 10 minutes. In a large pot of boiling water, add hot dogs and boil until warmed through. Place hot dogs in buns and then top with mustard, onion, relish, tomato slices, pickle spear, sport peppers and a pinch of celery salt.
SPIRAL DOGS
1 wooden skewer, 4 hot dogs, 4 buns.
Heat grill. Slide a long wooden skewer through the entirety of your hot dog. Place the hot dog on a cutting board and, using a paring knife, cut into the hot dog at a slight angle. Turn the hot dog and continue cutting until you reach the other end. Carefully remove the skewer from the hot dog. Repeat with remaining dogs. Grill for 8 minutes. Add any and all your favorite toppings.
HAWAIIAN HOT DOGS
8 King's Hawaiian original sweet hot dog buns, 8 hot dogs split lengthwise (be careful not to cut all the way through). FOR THE PINEAPPLE SALSA: 2 cups fresh pineapple (finely chopped), 1/2 small red onion (finely chopped), 1/2 cup freshly chopped cilantro, 3 tbsps fresh lime juice, kosher salt. FOR THE SPICY MAYO: 1/2 cup mayonnaise, 1/4 cup Sriracha, 1 tbsp fresh lime juice, kosher salt.
Make the pineapple salsa: In a small bowl, toss together pineapple, onion, cilantro and lime juice. Season with salt and set aside. Make the spicy mayo: In another small bowl, whisk together mayonnaise, Sriracha, and lime juice, if adding. Season with salt and set aside. Heat a grill or grill pan over medium heat. Split King's Hawaiian Original Hawaiian Sweet Hot Dog Buns and toast as desired. Set aside. Place hot dogs on a grill or grill pan and cook for about 3 minutes, or until grill marks appear. Place hot dogs in buns, then top with pineapple salsa, and drizzle with spicy mayo. Garnish with more cilantro before serving.
EVERYTHING BAGEL DOGS
2 tbsps poppy seeds, 2 tbsps dried minced onion, 2 tbsps sesame seeds, 2 tsps garlic powder, 1 tsp coarse salt. FOR THE BAGEL HOT DOGS: 1 package puff pastry (thawed), 1 package cream cheese (softened), 1 package hot dogs, 1 1/2 cups water, 2 tbsps baking soda.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Combine all seasonings into a small bowl, stirring until well blended. Set aside. Slice the puff pastry into 1" strips lengthwise. Spread cream cheese along each strip, then roll around a hot dog, covering it from end to end. Set aside. Microwave water until it starts to steam a little, about 1 minute. Pour into a large bowl, stirring in baking soda until dissolved. Dip each hot dog into the baking soda-water mixture, then place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Liberally sprinkle each hot dog with Everything Bagel seasoning. Bake until the pastry has puffed up and turned a light golden brown, 10 to 12 minutes.
OLD FASHIONED LUNCHEON COUNTER DOG
8 hot dogs (sliced down the middle), 8 buns, 1 onion (chopped or sliced in rings), cooking oil and butter.
Heat oil in a non-stick pan to medium heat. Prepare fresh buns by opening and buttering them. Add sliced or chopped onions to fry. When browned, remove onions to keep warm, or keep them in the pan pushed to the side. Slice hot dogs down the middle but not all the way through (keep it connected). You want to pry them open to have a double wide face down hot dog. Lay them flat, cut side down in the seasoned pan and cook until brown, Flip to the other side and brown. When browned to your liking, remove from the pan. Keep the pan on medium heat. Put buttered buns face down in the hot pan to toast them (I press them down a couple of times so butter and pan connect). When nice and brown, remove them. Assemble the hot dog and sauteed onions into the bun. Dress with mustard and ketchup and anything else your heart desires! Pour a nice, ice-cold Coke with a straw, add some crinkle fries, and enjoy a trip back in time!
CHILI DOGS
1 tbsp olive oil, 1 pound lean ground beef, 1 tsp onion powder, 1 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 tsp chili powder, 1 (15-ounce) can tomato sauce, 1/4 cup ketchup, 2 tbsps Dijon mustard, 8 all-beef hot dogs, 8 hot dog buns, grated sharp cheddar cheese, finely chopped red onion.
Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat until it shimmers. Add the beef, onion powder, garlic powder, kosher salt, and chili powder and cook until the beef is browned, mashing and breaking up any large pieces, about 8 minutes. Add the tomato sauce, ketchup, and mustard and reduce the heat to low. Simmer for 10 to 12 minutes to let the flavors meld. Meanwhile, grill the hot dogs. Heat an outdoor grill for direct, medium-high heat. Scrape the grill grates clean as needed. Place the hot dogs on the grill and grill until well-marked and heated through, about 2 minutes per side. Turn the heat off and gently toast the buns on the still-warm grill, about 2 minutes. To serve, place a hot dog in each bun and top with the chili, cheddar cheese, and red onions. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maybe there is hope for America to recover values
author: JOHN McCULLOUGH JR.
content:
Maybe there is hope for America to recover values

 June 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHN McCULLOUGH JR. | Section: Columns 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 About a dozen years ago, I wrote a Star Democrat letter to the editor lamenting that the political Left had taken over all of the societal corridors of power and influence.I also stated that I believed this would require either a collapse of our nation, requiring conservatives to rebuild it, or that it would require a 30-year plan to raise our children to take them back. Thankfully, there was not a collapse, though movies like the recent "Civil War" remind us that this is still a possibility and in the mind of some, a very distinct possibility.
The American people, except for those on the coasts and in big cities, are still predominantly conservative, but the "flyover" areas of the country just didn't have the societal influence to prevail in the culture wars that have erupted. And though I have to admit that I was not exactly right, because conservatives are not trying to take back those lost corridors of influence, but rather I am seeing them set up a sort of "political parallel universe" to basically try to make those former corridors of influence obsolete, or at least to take away their power to control all narratives.
This is actually a better scenario for the country, because it can happen faster and without having to find ways to fire or replace those in power (who have dug in like ticks, and black ball any who might threaten them, to hold onto their positions). Instead, it simply gives Americans alternative choices on where to find more worldview-friendly places to get news and information, education, entertainment, goods and services, social media, etc.
Let me give you some examples to buttress my point.
A dozen years ago there was only one conservative news cable channel to get information, Fox News, while there were seven to eight liberal ones, which included the likes of CNN, MSNBC, the alphabet stations and several others. Now conservatives have at least four to five cable news channels to choose from and myriad places to get conservative news on the internet.
Conservative leaning colleges, like Hillsdale, Patrick Henry, Regent and Liberty University, are bursting at the seams as parents want to keep their children away from the culture rot and "group think" that is spewed by most of higher education nowadays. School board elections are being hotly contested as conservatives have realized they have to stop the liberal machine at an early age to protect their kids. Parents want their students to be taught how to think, not what to think.
And Hollywood, through both viewers voting with their feet and even through the natural weaning away from movie theaters that happened during the pandemic, is also finding itself ignored in their woke bubble of self-importance. There is now even a conservative actors' guild being formed by those who were previously being muzzled or intimidated by power wielding Hollywood execs.
In sports, those who were being idolized for sitting down during a national anthem are now being booed. In goods and services, there are now those who proudly announce their "made in America" or patriotic stance on things to promote their products, and patriotic Americans are now "canceling" liberal businesses who try to shove their political views down our throats ... see Bud Light for a glaring example.
And liberal social media, probably the most ruthless bullies out there, are now finding themselves challenged by alternative conservative options. Facebook is challenged by Truth Social and others. Twitter, bought out by Elon Musk, is a bold attempt of his to bring balance to the information universe. YouTube being challenged by Rumble. Podcast after podcast, talk radio show after talk radio show of conservative commentators are regularly growing their audiences while attempts by liberal commentators to do the same largely fall flat.
After waiting a dozen years, it is encouraging to see Americans demanding and supporting this "parallel political universe" or what some have called an "alternative economy" that allows us to choose who we want to support with our time, attention and wallets.
In that old letter to the editor mentioned at the beginning, I stated that progressivism is just a new word for socialism and communism, and thankfully, the country is starting to push back in a dramatic and tangible way against that worldview. Maybe there is hope for us yet, to recover the values that made us the greatest nation in history with our foundations of faith, family and freedom.
John McCullough Jr. is a licensed residential homebuilder. A former touring golf pro, he has been golf coach for Delmarva Christian High School in Georgetown, Delaware, for the last seven years.

title: Paths forward: Can manufactured housing, adaptive reuse move the affordable housing needle?
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Paths forward: Can manufactured housing, adaptive reuse move the affordable housing needle?

 June 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: News 
 
 1205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The need to address affordable housing shortages and higher home prices and rents has prompted plenty of talk during and since the pandemic.Cody Filipczak — a home builder and developer in Eau Claire — is translating those words into deeds.
He redeveloped a shuttered assisted living facility into new affordable apartments and has development plans to bring more manufactured homes to a region where real estate costs have roughly doubled.
Still, those are just small bites at a very big and challenging nationwide apple.
Filipczak partnered with the nearby city of Altoona and community nonprofit JONAH (Joining Our Neighbors, Advancing Hope) to turn the former assisted living center into a 25-unit apartment complex called Solis Circle featuring smaller studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments.
Rents range from $425 to $810 per month with square footage running from 280 to 620 square feet, according to John DeRose, owner/broker for Rental Resources of Eau Claire Inc., which manages the property. Units include efficiency kitchens with larger communal kitchens and on-site laundry facilities.
"It's the coolest project I have ever done," said Filipczak, co-owner of C&M Home Builders & Real Estate, who noted Solis' tenant roster includes seniors, younger tenants and persons with disabilities.
Average rents in the Eau Claire area are more than $1,200 per month, according to real estate firm Zumper Inc. Filipczak said entry level housing prices in northwestern Wisconsin have doubled in recent years going from $150,000 to $300,000.
The project was able to come to fruition via a deal that involved the city taking ownership of the land and an old zoning provision that allowed for an assisted living center to be transformed into apartments.
"It still cost $100,000 to get it updated," said Filipczak, who also builds duplexes and other housing options across price ranges, including in Rice Lake to the south of Moon Lake Park.
Other adaptive reuse efforts to help address needed affordable and workforce housing are not as easy, said Filizpczak, who started his career as a carpenter.
Zoning rules, building codes and higher labor costs discourage the redevelopment of office buildings, church campuses and other properties into needed housing.
"They are just driving the pricing up," he said.
The Solis project opened in 2019. Mike Golat, Altoona's city administrator, said it was financed via a tax incremental district, a financing structure that allows local governments to invest in, collect taxes and reinvest in a designated area. Golat said the Wisconsin town has another $6 million to invest in affordable housing from that district.
He also noted the different approach taken at the Solis Circle redevelopment.
"We don't have income requirements. We didn't want to go to a voucher system," he said. "We wanted a mix of people in there to give it a bit more diversity and sense of community."
Filipczak also has plans to add 72 new manufactured homes to an existing 15-home community with the same type of housing stock. He said the new manufactured housing is slated to have prices between $160,000 and $200,000 with plans to allow homeowners to eventually purchase lots or form a homeowners association.
'I think it's the future'
The Wisconsin builder sees manufactured housing as the key to address the shortage of affordable apartments to rent and homes to buy across the country.
"I think it's the key to be honest. I think it's the future," he said. Golat said Altoona — which has a population of 9,100 people and has seen its population grow by 36% since 2010 — is looking at manufactured homes, tiny homes and zoning changes to lift barriers to new affordable construction. "We are looking at things like reducing minimum lot sizes, reducing setbacks, reducing infill requirements," he said.
That is welcomed by local housing advocates working to get more developers, landlords and property owners (including churches) on the affordable bandwagon.
"The zoning update is huge," said JONAH organizer Paul Savides.
Still, many affordable housing efforts — including apartments and manufactured homes — face stigmas about their impacts on the surrounding community and property values as well as 'not in my backyard' opposition from existing residents.
"We have that in spades here," Golat said.
Other affordable housing advocates see merits in manufactured homes because their pricing and square footage work better for families and multi-person and multi-generational households
The average price of a smaller manufactured home came in at $79,600 at the end of last year while larger ones more akin to a single-family home cost $149,600, according to numbers released earlier this month by the St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank.
Those are up 62% and 53% from Aug. 2019.
Still, that is lower than the current median single-family home price nationally of $433,558 according to real estate firm RedFin.
Manufactured housing accounts for 11% of new housing starts with the median income of manufactured homebuyers coming in at $35,000, according to the Manufactured Housing Institute, an industry group. That compares to a $107,000 median income for single-family homebuyers, according to the National Association of Realtors.
David Dworkin, president and CEO of the National Housing Conference, said manufactured homes have seen marked improvements in construction quality and offer homeownership potential to households priced out of single-family markets.
But Dworkin also said new climate change-inspired energy efficiency rules from the Biden administration will drive up costs on manufactured homes and in turn seniors and lower income households.
'Insane for our area'
Ann Malfavon, executive of the Klamath Housing Authority in southern Oregon, said while there is broad support for addressing the need for more affordable housing, "it still carries a stigma with it and the belief that this type of housing decreases surrounding property values."
Manufactured housing also faces stereotypes of rundown trailer parks and how they will stand up to extreme weather such as hurricanes and tornadoes.
Malfavon said higher costs for labor and materials before and since the pandemic and lack of inventory of apartments and homes for sales have increased prices.
"The median listing home price of Klamath Falls is $350,000 to $360,000, which is insane for our area, where the area median income is $75,200. This prices out a lot of individuals and families who would like to own a home," said Malfavon, whose group owns and manages 324 units in Klamath and Lake counties near the California border with new efforts slated to add another 99 units across four projects.
She said there are statewide efforts to streamline and quicken funding and financing and approvals for affordable projects.
The Oregon Department of Housing & Community Services also has a $10 million program to help co-locate child care facilities within new affordable housing developments and has given $20 million to four modular home builders to help spur affordable construction.
Modular homes are built in segments at centralized manufacturing facilities and then transported to property sites.
Delia Hernandez, a spokesperson for OHCS, said the modular homes can be used as temporary housing after wildfires and other disasters and the builders "will also prioritize low-income and middle-income housing construction."
There are concerns about developers and builders gaming the system of federal, state and local affordable housing grants, tax breaks and other incentives by designating small slices of new projects as affordable and workforce units while still charging rents that aren't helping address the larger problem.
"I see so much money going out from the federal government, from state and local governments for projects that are deemed affordable. They are nowhere near affordable," Filizpczak said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
