title: Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat

 July 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 753
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every Sunday when I was a child, we eagerly awaited the delivery of the Sunday newspaper. It always included a feature with riveting pictures from previous editions.They were not just a collage of all the pictures from previous editions.
They were selected by the newspaper's editors thinking not so much on how timely they were at the present, but how timeless they might be going forward.
If that program were still in place today, two pictures that most certainly would be selected would be from the 2024 presidential election campaign.
One is of former President and current presidential candidate Donald Trump after an attempted assassination at a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.
In that surreal picture, Trump is being taken with a bloody hand on a wounded ear, blood on his face and his other hand raised as a defiant fist from the event stage by Secret Service agents.
Another picture would be from the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.
In that picture, Trump is standing alone on a stage next to the helmet and bunker coat of Corey Comperatore, who was a volunteer firefighter and Trump supporter who attended the Pennsylvania rally.
Corey died shielding his family from the fusillade that almost killed Trump and seriously wounded two other rally attendees.
Prominently displayed next to Corey's bunker coat and helmet is an American flag.
Trump appears to be gazing with deep contemplation of and reverence for the memorial for Comperatore.
In deeply divided America, both pictures are generating widely different reactions.
Some Trump detractors claim the assassination was preplanned to generate support for the Trump campaign. They have implied Trump exiting the stage largely under his own power was done to show a stark contrast to a former opponent who often stumbled and needed assistance while walking.
Some Trump detractors claim the picture of Trump looking at the Comperatore's memorial was staged for nothing more than scoring political points. They question if Trump's hand on the shoulder of the turnout coat was orchestrated and insincere.
Sadly, a significant number of seriously deranged Trump adversaries have posted messages on social media with messages like "sorry the shooter missed" and "hope he [Trump] is killed the next time."
I found the vileness and hate in those messages so disturbing I couldn't read all of them.
Not all those adversaries are radical fringe malcontents.
They include a wide range of elected officials, celebrities and political commentators who have regularly characterized and continue to characterize Donald Trump as a Nazi, a neo-Nazi, a fascist, a dictator wanna be and an existential threat to America.
Some Trump supporters believe the attempted assassination was a deep state conspiracy.
They maintain the spectacular failure of security at the event was by design.
They also believe constant inflammatory comments from Trump's many adversaries created an environment where the question on an assassination attempt was not if, but when.
I am not going to engage a debate on the credibility on either side on these deeply held beliefs.
I am more concerned such debate affirms that an alarming and steady decline of civil dialogue in our society is the greatest existential threat to democracy in America.
In today's intensely polarized political environment, it is considered normal and acceptable to disagree by being viciously disagreeable, to listen only to those who share and affirm that their views are the right views. Worst of all, we expect and accept the practice of demonizing anyone, and everyone who doesn't agree with us on every issue all the time.
We desperately need a renewed national commitment to critical thinking, listening to others, avoiding group think, respect for differing opinions and acceptance of a system of government where the majority rules, even when that can and does result in public policy decisions that do not have universal agreement.
Much easier said than done.
The underlying reality of where we are as a society is best captured by the cogent observation of veteran political communications consultant, Frank Luntz: "It's not what you say or write, it's what people hear or read. You can have the best message in the world, but the person on the receiving end will always understand it through the prism of their own emotions, preconceptions, prejudices and preexisting beliefs."
In other words — my mind is made up. Don't try to persuade me otherwise with facts.
When dealing the deep divisions caused by the issue of slavery and the American Civil War Abraham Lincoln said, "A house divided cannot stand."
America has been and is a house divided.
If we do not change course soon, we will not stand.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Live at peace with everyone?
author: PETER SMITH
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Live at peace with everyone?

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PETER SMITH | Section: Columns 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the shadow of the attempted assassination of former President Trump last week, President Biden challenged both political parties to calm things down in the race, to be more civil with those who have differing political opinions and views.Many must have thought, "What an impossible request!" What do you think?
The Apostle Paul challenged Christians living in Rome in a similar way. He said, "If possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone." (Romans 12:18). Paul, did you really mean everyone? Does everyone include my enemies, crazy people at work, an ex-spouse or even a former convict? Are their parameters to follow? Guidelines?
It comes down to valuing others through the lens of love. If we claim to have faith in Jesus, then His love in us must respond through us in every situation.
I'm learning by watching others who do this well. They say, "I've learned to swallow my pride." Another told me he doesn't always try to get the last word in when he disagrees with someone else. Seems practical. And Paul did say "if it's possible…" which means sometimes we won't be able to live peacefully with others. But for sure, it comes down to me, to you, not the "other" person. Again his words: "as far as it depends on you…"
Will there be exceptions? Of course. When face to face with evil, we must deal with it and not cave in. But pastorally I've seen people use exceptions as their rule for living and dealing with others all the time. My prayer is that we learn to take the high road as much as possible when tough situations come our way.
Paul's challenge is to dig deep into our character, into our faith, when confronted with people who are not peace oriented at times. I pray God will help us discover ways to agree to disagree when we don't get along with others. Though it might be a difficult challenge, God says it's possible to do. May we believe it is too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a religious/philosophical column discussing peace, faith, and moral guidance based on biblical teachings. None of the listed topics directly address spiritual/ethical commentary, though 'Arts & Culture' and 'Local Life' could marginally relate to its reflective, community-oriented tone.

title: Canning day in the kitchen
author: Staff Writer
content:
Canning day in the kitchen

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 1630
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The fresh vegetables were picked, washed and ready to be processed for "canning day" on the farm.Canning day was decided by the ripeness of the vegetables. Let me tell you, canning involves a lot of work.
Outside in the storage building were baskets full of empty jars that were washed and stored during the year as the contents were eaten. In an empty "lard can" were the rings off the jars and boxes of new caps were waiting to be used in the process of the two-piece jar lids.
Two washing tubs were set up outside, one with hot soapy water and the other with clear water for rinsing. The bushel baskets holding the canning jars from the previous year's canning day were carefully carried to the house and placed on the long counter tops in the old-fashioned country kitchen.
On top of the kitchen stove would be two heavy-duty kitchen pots filled with vegetables — maybe green beans or lima beans or tomatoes or corn — and as soon as it was blanched, the veggies were placed in the canning jars.
The jar lids were put on lightly, and the jars placed in the canning pots. The canning pots started rolling on the fire, thus cooking the vegetables.
This scene lasted all day, or until the veggies were all used.
I must say what a beautiful sight — rows of glass jars with corn, green beans, beets, relishes, jellies, jams and so much more.
But thank you, technology, for the pressure cooker, food processor, microwave, portable oven and more.
CANNED PEACHES4 lbs. peaches (about 9 large peaches), 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 8 cups water.
bring a large pot of water to a boil. Fill a large bowl with ice water. Using a paring knife, cut a shallow "x" into the bottom of each peach. Add peaches to boiling water and let boil for 3 minutes. Remove peaches and place directly in a bowl of ice water. When peaches are cool enough to handle, peel peaches. Slice peaches and discard the pit. Divide peaches between 4 sterilized canning jars, being sure to leave about 1 inch of space from the top of the jar. In another medium pot over medium heat, add sugar and 8 cups water and bring to a simmer. Stir until sugar is dissolved. Pour simple syrup over peaches, leaving about 1/4 inch of space from the top of the jar. Gently tap jars on the counter to settle peaches and syrup. Add more syrup as necessary to each jar. Tightly seal jars with lids. Fill a large stock pot about halfway with water and bring to a boil over medium heat. Once water is close to a simmer, use tongs to carefully lower jars into hot water. Let water come to a gentle boil and boil for 25 minutes. Carefully remove jars from the stock pot and let sit at room temperature until completely cool. Press down on the lid of the jars to test if they are properly sealed. If the lid bounces back or pops the jar is not sealed. Once jars are properly sealed and cooled, store in a dry dark space until ready to eat.
PICKLED BEETS4 to 5 lbs small beets, 2 tsps pickling salt, 1 1/2 cups white sugar, 3 cups white vinegar, 2 tbsps mixed pickling spice tied in cheesecloth bag, 1 cup water.
Wash the beets and remove most of the tops, leaving about 1/2 inch of beet top remaining. In a large boiling pot of water, cook the beets until barely tender. Remove from the stove. Submerge the beets in a large bowl of ice water. Cut off the tops and the roots completely, then remove the skin. Peel and slice beets into preferred size. Combine the vinegar, sugar, water, salt and pickling spice in a nonreactive pot and bring mixture to a boil; reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the beets to the pickling liquid and return to a boil. Remove the spice bag. Carefully ladle the beets and pickling liquid into hot sterilized pint jars, leaving 1/2 inch headspace. Remove any air bubbles with a non-metal utensil. Add additional pickling liquid, if needed, to keep the proper headspace. Wipe the jar rims thoroughly with a clean damp cloth, failure to do this can result in the jars not sealing properly. Seal the jars and process for 35 minutes in a boiling water bath.
HOMEMADE PICKLE RELISH2½ lbs cucumbers (peeled, center row of seeds removed and finely diced), 1 large yellow onion (finely diced), 1 small red bell pepper (finely diced), 1 small green bell pepper (finely diced), 3 cloves garlic (finely minced), ¼ cup kosher or pickling salt, 3 cups white vinegar, 1/2 cup sugar, 2 tsps dill seeds, 1 tbsp yellow mustard seeds, 2 tsps celery seeds, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 2 bay leaves.
Place the diced cucumbers, onion, bell pepper and garlic in a large mixing bowl. Combine with the salt and pour water over the mixture until covered. Let sit for at least 6 hours or overnight. Drain the cucumber mixture in a colander, rinse thoroughly with water, and drain again. In a large stock pot, add the sugar, vinegar, and spices and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the drained cucumber mixture and return to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer, uncovered, for 10 minutes. Discard the bay leaves. Ladle the hot relish into hot sterile jars, leaving ¼ inch of headspace. Wipe the rims of the jars clean and seal tightly with the lids. Process the jars in a boiling water bath for 10 minutes. Sealed jars will store in a cool, dark place for a year. If the seal is broken, the relish will keep in the fridge for at least a month. Makes 4 pints. Best eaten at least a week later after the flavors have had time to meld and the vinegar mellows out a bit.
STRAWBERRY JAM5 cups crushed fresh strawberries, 4 16-oz. containers, 7 cups granulated sugar, 1 packet original Sure-Jell premium fruit pectin powder, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 1/2 tsp butter.
Wash jars, lids and bands in hot soapy water, dry completely, and set bands aside. Simmer lids in warm water in a saucepan until ready to place them on jars. Keep jars warm by simmering in hot water until ready to use. Do not boil. Fill a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner with hot water, and place on the stove over medium-high heat. You'll need enough water to later cover your jars with at least 1 inch of water. Crush strawberries in a large mixing bowl or shallow glass baking dish using hand masher until nice, smooth consistency. Transfer crushed strawberries to 8-quart stock pot. Add pectin, lemon juice and butter to the pot, and stir constantly with a wooden spoon over high heat while bringing to a rolling boil. Once boiling, add sugar, return to rolling boil, then boil for 1 minute while stirring constantly. After 1 minute, remove foam from top of jam by skimming it off with a metal spoon.one by one, remove a jar from hot water, transfer to a cookie sheet, place regular mouth canning funnel on jar, and ladle in strawberry jam mixture leaving 1/4 inch empty head space at top of the jar. Then wipe off the rim of the lid and threads of the jar with damp cloth.
Continue until all jars have been filled. Remove warm lids from the saucepan and place one lid on each jar. Then screw one band on each jar just until snug but not overly tight. Place filled jars on a rack in a 20-quart stock pot or water bath canner, then lower down into hot water. Make sure there is enough water in the pot that there is at least 1 inch of water above the jars. Place the lid on your pot and bring to a gentle boil. Once water is boiling, set your timer for processing and boil for 10 minutes, once jars have finished boiling, turn off heat, remove the lid from the pot and let jars sit for 5 minutes before removing. After 5 minutes, lift up the rack to an elevated resting position, then carefully remove jars one by one using a jar lifter, and transfer to a folded towel to cool. The lids on the jars will begin to 'pop' into the sealed position, signifying the jam has been preserved. If any lids do not pop within the first 12-24 hours, transfer those to the refrigerator and use those up first. It may take up to 24-48 hours to finish setting. Jars can be stored in your pantry, or a cool, dry cupboard for up to 1 year.
HOMEMADE SALSA10 cups peeled, chopped and drained tomatoes; 3 cups chopped onion, ¾ cups chopped green bell pepper, 5 jalapenos (finely chopped, membranes and seeds removed), 7 cloves garlic (finely minced), 2 ½ tsps ground cumin, 2 ½ tsps coarsely ground black pepper, 2 ½ tbsps canning or pickling salt, ⅓ cup chopped fresh cilantro, ⅓ cup sugar (optional, depending on sweetness of tomatoes), 1 ¼ cups apple cider vinegar, 16 ounces tomato sauce (necessary for safe canning/proper pH), 12 ounces tomato paste (optional if you want a thicker salsa).
Combine all the ingredients in a large pot and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring often, Fill sterilized pint-size canning jars within 1/2-inch of the top. Wipe the rim of the jar clean and seal with a lid and ring. Process in a water or steam bath canner for 15 minutes Remove the jars carefully from the water or steam bath and let cool to room temperature. Check to make sure the jars have sealed correctly. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Memories of crab catching adventures
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Memories of crab catching adventures

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My grandson Mason has been spending some time down on Tangier Island this summer. Mason has been telling me all about the crab cakes and steamed crabs he's been eating fresh out of the water and right into the steamer.Mason's brings back memories of the 1950s and 1960s adventures of crabbing. Mom would back the pickup out, and we would load the supplies, which included baskets with inner tubes attached to help the baskets float, chicken necks for bait, heavy string to tie the hook and sinker to, crab nets, towels, a picnic basket with sandwiches and a big jug of water.
We loaded up and rode in the back of the truck so we could hoot and holler at our friends as we rode through town. Our destination would be one of two country landings with docks for crabbing and areas for swimming.
The first was Mumford's Landing down off St, Martin's Neck Road (now a development off the Route 90 bridge outside of Ocean City), and the second was a dock called Little Georgetown, just down the road from our farm on the Delaware side.
One particular day, we were headed to Mumford's Landing. Upon arriving, Mom picked a spot to tie our strings on the dock poles. We took the lines and hung the nuts, bolts and sinkers on the bottom so the weight held the line down. Then we tied on the chicken neck for bait.
You had a choice — go swimming now or later — but you had to move down a good distance to stay away from the baited lines. Mom got two baskets ready with inner tubes to float the baskets, grabbed a crab net and walked along the shoreline crabbing. Someone stayed back with another net and basket to gradually pulled up the lines, placing the neck under the line to catch the falling crabs.
Upon arriving at home, the still kicking crabs were unloaded, the fire started and the Old Bay seasoning was pulled out. Once the crabs were bright orange/reddish in color the fire was pulled away and the crabs pulled and placed on the picnic tables to be picked.
Of course, we ate the delicious meat until we were full, and then we put it in containers to be carried to the kitchen to be made into dishes such as crab cakes, crab soup and much more.
You can purchase crabs locally at LNT Seafood in Preston, Blough's Seafood outside of Denton, Kool Ice and Seafood in Cambridge, Kayla's crabs in Federalsburg on Preston Rd, Trident Seafood on Rt 50 IN Hebron and Fat Boys Seafood on Old Ocean City Road in Salisbury. There are many other small local spots featuring fresh seafood catches, but trust "word of mouth" for the best recommendations.
CRAB DIP8 ounces crab meat, 8 ounces cream cheese (softened), 1/2 cup sour cream, 2 tbsp mayonnaise, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 1/4 tsp Worcestershire sauce, 1/2 tsp dry mustard, 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, 1 pinch garlic salt (optional), 2 tsp Old Bay seasoning or JO seasoning.
In a large bowl, mix cream cheese, sour cream, mayonnaise, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce and dry mustard until smooth. Stir in 2 tbsp of shredded cheddar cheese. Add crab meat into the mixture. Pour mixture into a 1-quart casserole dish. Top with remaining cheese, or more. But not too much because you don't want the cheese to overtake the taste of the crab. Add some of your favorite crab or seafood seasoning on top. Bake at 325 degrees for about 30 minutes or until the top is browned.
CRAB MAC N CHEESE1 16 oz box dry Cavatappi pasta or elbows, 1 lb jumbo lump crab meat, ½ cup unsalted butter, ½ cup all-purpose flour, 1 ½ tsp seafood seasoning such as Old Bay or JO, ½ tsp garlic salt, ½ tsp ground mustard, ¼ tsp black pepper, 2 oz chive & onion cream cheese (softened), 5 cups whole milk, 5 cups shredded cheddar and Monterey jack cheese (divided). For the topping: 2 tbsps unsalted butter (melted), ½ cup panko breadcrumbs, 1 tbsp grated parmesan, ¼ tsp seafood seasoning, 1 tbsp chopped fresh Italian parsley.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Spray a 13-by-9-inch baking dish with cooking spray. Set aside. Cook the pasta in salted water per the package directions until al dente. Drain well and set aside. Pick over the crab meat removing any shells and cartilage. Set aside. In a medium-size heavy bottomed saucepan, melt ½ cup butter over medium heat. To the melted butter add flour, 1 ½ teaspoon seafood seasoning, garlic salt, ground mustard and black pepper. Mix until the flour has been absorbed by the butter stirring constantly. Whisk in the milk. Whisk constantly to prevent clumping. Bring the milk to a boil then immediately lower the heat to low. Simmer for 3-5 minutes gently bubbling and stirring to prevent sticking. Turn off the heat. Add cream cheese to the sauce. Stir until melted then add 3 cups of Borden shredded Cheddar and Monterey Jack cheese. Remove from the heat, stirring until melted. Add the cooked pasta and crab meat to a large mixing bowl. Pour the cheese sauce over and mix until fully coated and the crab meat is evenly distributed. Pour ½ into the baking dish. Top with 1 cup shredded cheese. Repeat with macaroni then top with the final 1 cup of shredded cheese. Topping: Melt 2 tablespoon butter in a small microwave safe bowl.. Mix with the panko bread crumbs, Parmesan cheese, and ¼ teaspoon seafood seasoning, Sprinkle on top. Place into the oven and bake for 30-40 minutes or until the top is golden and the edges are bubbly. Garnish with chopped parsley just before serving.
CHICKEN, CRAB, SAUSAGE GUMBO1 cup bacon grease, 3 tbsps olive oil, 1 yellow onion (chopped), 1 red bell pepper (chopped), 2 cups andouille sausage (sliced), 1 cup all-purpose flour, 4-6 cloves garlic (minced), 3/4 gallon chicken stock, 1 15-oz can chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp apple cider vinegar, 2 cups stewed and shredded chicken, 3 tbsps fresh parsley, 1 tbsp dried basil, 1 tbsp dried oregano, 2 cups frozen okra, 2 cups crab meat, salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco to taste, shopped green onions and rice.
Add 3 tablespoons olive oil or bacon grease to a cast-iron skillet and cook the onion and bell pepper until soft and set aside. Cook the sausage in the same skillet until browned and set aside with the vegetables. Add1 cup of the bacon grease to the skillet over medium heat and stir in the flour. Lower the heat to low and cook for at least 1 hour, stirring every 5 minutes. The roux should be thick, but not chalky. When it is dark tan and smells like toasted nuts, it is done. In a large stock pot or Dutch oven, add the sautéed vegetables and sausage, and heat over medium high heat. Add the garlic and simmer for 2 minutes. Add stock, tomatoes, vinegar, chicken and all other dry ingredients. Simmer on low to medium heat for at least 1 hour. Add salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco to taste. Skim off about 3 cups of liquid from the pot (with as few solids as possible) and combine in a bowl with about 1 cup roux. Stir until it thickens and becomes paste-like. Add about half this mixture back to the pot on low heat. Stir well. Let simmer for a few minutes and add more roux mixture to thicken or water or stock to thin. The gumbo should be thick, but not as thick as gravy. Add half of the okra. Simmer on very low for at least 30 minutes. Be careful, as it can easily burn. Add the remaining cup of okra and the crab meat 5 minutes before serving. Taste again for salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco. Serve in bowls with rice and garnish with green onion.
CHESAPEAKE CIOPPINO2 tbsps unsalted butter, 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/2 cup celery, (medium diced), 1 cup onion (medium diced), 1/2 cup fennel (thin sliced), 2 tbsps garlic (thin sliced or minced), 1 tbsp Old Bay or JO seasoning, 1 bay leaf, 1/2 tsp oregano, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper, 1/4 tsp Worcestershire sauce, 2 cups chicken stock, 3 cups tomato puree, 1/2 lemon (sliced), 1 lb shrimp, 1 lb Maryland blue crab meat, 12 oysters (shucked), 1 lb rock fish (cut into large cubes), 24 mussels (cleaned or frozen).
Combine butter and olive oil in a medium stock pot. Heat on medium until butter has melted. Add celery, onion, garlic and fennel to the stock pot. Sauté until onion has become translucent, add crab seasoning, oregano, crushed red pepper, and Worcestershire sauce. Bring to a boil for 5 minutes, add chicken stock and tomato puree. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, cover and simmer for 30 minutes, Add the sliced lemon, shrimp, whole crab meat, oysters, rock fish and mussels, staggering to accommodate for cook times. Cover and simmer for 5 minutes or until mussels have opened. Serve hot.
MARYLAND CREME OF CRAB SOUP1/4 cup butter, 1 medium onion (coarsely chopped),1/3 cup flour, 4 cups milk or half-and-half, 1 tbsp Old Bay or JO seasoning, 1/2 tsp parsley flakes, 1 lb lump crab meat.
Melt butter in a three-quart saucepan on medium heat. Add onion; cook and stir 5 minutes or until softened. Add flour, Old Bay or JO, and parsley; whisk until well blended. While whisking constantly, gradually add milk. Bring just to boil. Stir in crabmeat. Reduce heat to low; simmer for 20 minutes stirring occasionally. Sprinkle with additional Old Bay or JO if desired.
To end this week, I'd like to send a special hello to Mr. Alan Planner and Mrs. Darlene Planner of Federalsburg. Thank you for being loyal readers and great friends. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal memories of crabbing and seafood recipes, which don't align directly with any specific topic. While 'Local Life' could relate to community activities, the content is more about nostalgia and recipes than local events. 'Agriculture' is a stretch as crabbing isn't farming. 'None of these' is the most accurate choice.

title: Lifetime of observations contribute to column
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Lifetime of observations contribute to column

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 890
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On a regular basis, some individuals have responded negatively to my guest commentaries on politics and public affairs. They have included assumptions about my background and motivations. As a result, they have a perception that I am using the commentaries to promote the Republican Party in general, and Donald Trump in particular.Such assumptions and perceptions are simply not true.
I am not an avid supporter of Donald Trump in his comeback bid for another term as president and have not been an avid supporter of him since he launched his first presidential campaign.
In one guest commentary last fall I even predicted he would not be nominated as the 2024 Republican presidential candidate.
I am not an avid supporter of the Republican Party and have never been a blindly loyal voter for Republican candidates.
Beginning with the first election when I was eligible to vote, and continuing to today, I have never voted a straight Republican ticket in any local, state or national election.
Candidate quality always has been and will always be my guiding principle on who to support and for whom to cast my vote.
At one time I was active in the Republican Party. I served as chair of the Republican Central Committee of Talbot County and as a member of the executive committee at the Maryland Republican Party.
I voluntarily stepped down as Talbot County Central Committee chair in February 2022. That resulted in my relinquishing my seat on the GOP's executive committee.
My past service with the local and state Republican Party is old history and irrelevant to today.
Since February 2022, I have not had any conversations or dealings with either organization.
With regards to the upcoming presidential election, I acknowledge that Donald Trump has flaws. So does Kamala Harris.
That said, I embrace the observation of Don Nielson the author of "Presidential Leadership: Learning from United States Presidential Libraries & Museums."
Nielson writes, "… leaders are not perfect. Try as they might, every leader still has flaws. They still make mistakes. They still fall short. They still have regrets. They still yearn to do better. Every leader is imperfect."
On at least two occasions I have written positive commentaries about a Democratic leader.
In one I praised Democratic President John F. Kennedy for his masterful leadership during the Cuban Missile crisis. His leadership has led many historians to conclude his actions avoided World War III.
In another guest commentary on President Kennedy, I suggested voters everywhere should embrace his timeless admonition to always ask this question — "What am I not being told?"
In all my commentaries, I strive to engage independent thinking and to follow lessons learned about bipartisanship from two awesome political mentors.
One was a Republican state senator in Pennsylvania for whom I served as his administrative assistant. Our office received more constituent requests for assistance than any other senator.
His ironclad rule was to help everyone regardless of their party affiliation, relative level of support or lack of support for him or their views on the issues. We never researched or even considered that information before we worked diligently on every constituent contact on every matter regardless of how small or how big.
A second mentor is the CEO of a Pennsylvania-based public affairs and public relations consulting firm where I serve as Maryland director.
For almost 45 years, this mentor, a staunch Republican, was a close friend of a long time equally staunch Democratic political operative in Pennsylvania.
His friend served as the executive director of the Pennsylvania Democratic Party, as a communications director for two Democratic governors, and as a communications director for two Democratic speakers of the House in the state House of Representatives.
For over 20 years, my mentor and his friend were verbal sparring partners on a weekly point-counterpoint television program. They also sparred in point-counterpoint columns for two publications and frequently shared the stage at conferences, seminars and classrooms. Many times, they rode together to and from those events.
In a city mayoral election, my mentor provided campaign counsel to a Democratic candidate because he felt strongly that she was the best person for the job.
Last, but not least, my mentor hosts a monthly policy briefing at our office in Pennsylvania.
On a regular basis, Democratic-elected officials, Democratic candidates and Democratic party operatives are featured as speakers and are welcomed as guests.
Going forward I will continue to offer my thoughts based upon a lifetime of participating in and observing a wide range of events in the political arena.
I will continue to respect the right of those who choose to disagree, sometimes vehemently, with the central messages in my commentaries.
I will continue to read every comment, pro and con, on my commentaries with a willingness to think, "You may be right."
In return, I ask all who disagree with me to do this:
Refrain from attacking my opinions using unsubstantiated assumptions about my background and motives.
Focus more on my content, staying on topic and giving due thought and consideration to that content, rather than trying to attack the messenger.
Remember two former and greatly missed U.S. Supreme Court Justices — conservative icon Antonin Scalia and liberal icon Ruth Bader Ginsberg. They were polar opposites on their opinions on almost every issue brought before the court. Still, they respected each other and never attacked each other. Justice Scalia said it best, "I attack ideas. I don't attack people."
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: God's provision is nourishment for the soul
author: BILLY JOHNSON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: God's provision is nourishment for the soul

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILLY JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 298
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Throughout the Bible, we see a beautiful and consistent theme: God, like a joyous chef in the kitchen, always provides a feast for His people.From the very beginning, in the Garden of Eden, God set the table for humanity, providing every kind of plant for food (Genesis 2:9). This theme continues with the Passover feast, where the Israelites ate the lamb as a sign of God's deliverance from Egypt (Exodus 12).
As the Israelites journeyed through the wilderness, God provided manna from heaven, sustaining them daily (Exodus 16). This miraculous bread was a daily reminder of His constant care. Similarly, the prophet Isaiah paints a picture of a grand feast of rich foods and well-aged wines, symbolizing the Lord's generous provision and the promise of a future filled with His blessings (Isaiah 25:6).
Looking ahead, the Bible speaks of a glorious wedding feast of the Lamb in Revelation 19:9, where believers will gather in celebration and communion with Christ. This image points us to the ultimate fulfillment of God's provision and fellowship with His people.
Jesus is the ultimate picture of this when He declares, "I am the bread of life that came down from heaven" (John 6:51).
Just as God provided manna in the desert, He now offers spiritual nourishment through Jesus. In Christ, we find not only our daily bread but the sustenance for our souls.
As we reflect on these biblical feasts, let's remember that God's provision is not just about physical sustenance but also about spiritual nourishment. He invites us to His table, where we can find rest, refreshment and joy in His presence. Let's embrace this divine provision with gratitude and share it with our community, knowing that the Lord who fed His people in the past continues to feed us today with His love and grace. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it mentions cultural elements like feasts, its primary focus is on theology and scripture, which do not align with any specific topic in the provided list. title: Cooking like The King
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Cooking like The King

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1178
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Time for my yearly tradition, even though still a sad one.On Aug. 16, 1977, the Rock N' Roll world lost a legend — Elvis Presley. I remember that day as well as I remember the first time I heard his voice at the age of 10.
My brother, age 12, and I were sick of Honkytonk music and Boogie Woogie songs. Our older siblings were into those crooners. Our first Elvis experience was in 1954, and the song was "That's Alright" followed by "Heartbreak Hotel."
He and I would take my sister's transistor radio outside and put on our little show until my sister came home and took her radio back. We had so much fun. We had a dance floor made with wooden chicken coops turned upside down.
When you go to Graceland and take the tour. The kitchen is one of the most popular stops after the Jungle Room. It hasn't been touched since the late '70s and has been recreated the way it was the day Elvis died based on photos taken from the death investigation, right down to the bowls of fruit and veggies that are replaced every few days to keep up the magic.
One of the most interesting stories was about the microwave. Elvis had one of the very first microwaves ever produced. He paid around $1,000 for the microwave, which can still be seen in the kitchen to this day.
Another story told is how he fell in love with Texas-style food when he was stationed there with the Army. Elvis was drafted in December 1957 and was assigned to the Second Armored Division at Fort Hood for his basic training.
Elvis, who was raised on lower class Mississippi and Memphis food quickly took a liking to the spicy, meaty dishes he was now eating daily. BBQ Pork pizza was one of those dishes, and I'll include that recipe here in this column.
As I said above, I have been lucky to go to Memphis and Graceland as well as Sun Records and to stand right in the spot where Elvis recorded "That's Alright Mama." I am thinking about going back in February for my birthday.
Memphis is such a soulful town that you can't help but bob your head and tap a foot at the sounds of the blues coming out of every door on Beale Street. And the food! On top of the amazing barbecue at Charles Vergos' Rendezvous, there is Gus's World Famous fried chicken, whose fried green tomatoes are out of this world.
I enjoy Elvis's music as I can associate it with many happy and tragic stages in my own life. Well folks this is my story from my heart. Enjoy today's recipes, which were Elvis's favorites.
FRIED PEANUT BUTTER AND BANANA SANDWICHESSmear peanut butter on one slice of bread, and on the other slice smear the bread with mashed banana. Put the slices together, smear each outside slice with bacon grease and fry in a hot skillet.
FRIED DILL PICKLES1 jar (32 oz) whole dill pickles, 1 cup buttermilk, 2 tbsps Louisiana-style hot sauce, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 2 tbsps garlic salt, 2 tbsps paprika, 1 tbsp cayenne pepper, 1 tsp pepper, oil for deep-fat frying, ranch salad dressing.
Drain pickles, discarding liquid. Cut pickles into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Drain on paper towels; blot with additional paper towels until dry. In a shallow bowl, mix buttermilk and hot sauce. In another shallow bowl, mix flour, cornmeal, garlic salt, paprika, cayenne pepper and pepper. Dip pickles in buttermilk mixture, then in flour mixture. In a Dutch oven, heat one inch of oil to 375 degrees. Working in batches, fry pickles for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with ranch dressing, if desired.
BBQ PORK PIZZA1 large ready-made pizza base or your favorite pizza dough, 2 cups of your favorite barbecue sauce, 2 tbsps vegetable oil, 1 1/4 pounds boneless pork tenderloin, 4 oz mild cheddar or American cheese (shredded), 10 oz mozzarella cheese (shredded), basil leaves.
Prepare pizza dough according to the instructions on the package and set aside, or use a ready-made pizza base. Pour the barbecue sauce into a small saucepan and heat gently over medium heat, stirring occasionally.
In a medium skillet or frying pan, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Add the pork tenderloin and cook for 3 to 4 minutes, or until golden, turning to brown evenly. Add about 1/2 cup of the barbecue sauce and cook the pork over medium-low heat, covered, for about 20 minutes. Baste occasionally. Remove from heat and reserve any pan juices.
Preheat the oven to 500 degrees. Place the prepared pizza base on a baking sheet according to the directions. Spread about 1 cup of the barbecue sauce over the base to within half an inch of the edge. Toss the cheeses together; reserve 1/2 cup. Sprinkle remaining cheese over the base and bake for about 10 minutes, until the cheese is bubbling and the crust is golden. While cheese is melting, carve the tenderloin into slices, then shred the slices into thin strips. Remove pizza from the oven and sprinkle pork strips over the cheese. Pour over the remaining sauce and any remaining pan juices. Sprinkle reserved 1/2 cup cheese over top and return pizza to the oven for 5 minutes, until hot and bubbling. Divide into wedges and garnish with basil leave
HAMBURGER STEAK2 1/2 pounds ground beef, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped green pepper, 1 tbsp garlic, 1 tbsp salt, 1 tbsp black pepper, 2 cups mushroom soup, 2 eggs (beaten).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl mix together ground beef, chopped onions, chopped green pepper, garlic, salt, black pepper, mushroom soup and eggs. Mix well Shape into mini steaks and fry in a skillet with 2 tablespoons Crisco. Cook for about 12 to 15 minutes, making sure steaks are cooked inside well. Drain on paper towels and proceed to make gravy with grease left in the pan.
ELVIS BANANA BREAD2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup sugar, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 4 medium ripe bananas (mashed), 2 large eggs (room temperature), 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter, 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, 1/4 cup canola oil, 2 tsps vanilla extract, 2/3 cup semisweet chocolate chips
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, whisk the first six ingredients. In another bowl, whisk bananas, eggs, peanut butter, applesauce, oil and vanilla until blended. Add to flour mixture; stir just until moistened. Fold in chocolate chips. Transfer to three loaf pans coated with cooking spray. Bake for 45-50 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool in pans 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool. If you make multiple loaves like Mary Jenkins Langston would make for his plane rides to Las Vegas, you can freeze them and reheat. Securely wrap the cooled loaves and freeze. To use, thaw at room temperature or, if desired, microwave each loaf on high for 60-75 seconds or until heated through. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While Elvis is an entertainment figure, the content centers on cooking rather than entertainment or cultural arts. 'None of these' is the most accurate category.

title: Labor Day — cooking for end of summer celebrations
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Labor Day — cooking for end of summer celebrations

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1353
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Labor Day is the last official summer holiday to be celebrated.The kids are ready for the return to school, the last-minute vacations are planned, and it is time to plan that Labor Day party.
Today we will explore some tasty dishes for that special day that does not require a lot of labor. Cooking outside is done year round now, and the grill awaits the food. Hot dogs and hamburgers are some of the favorite grill foods.
The 2024-25 school year does not start until after Labor Day this year for most schools, which is great for the kids who work in the summer. An extra paycheck helps pay for the school fees, shoes, clothes, classroom supplies and tuition.
Mason, my oldest grandson, has been going to college part time as well as working full time this summer. Colin, his little brother, also started working this summer in the food service industry. I tell both of them how lucky they are to be able to work in the air conditioning while others aren't so lucky.
That first day of school is always exciting and emotional for the first-time student and parents. In 1970 and 1971, when my two oldest boys started school, I played the strong parent role — walking them down the hallways of Buckingham Elementary, leaving them in the care of the teacher, walking bravely out to my car.
Turning around, I got out of the car and walked across the lawn to the back of the school and peered in the windows. How embarrassing when the teacher and students waved at me — including my own boys.
Thank you, American workers, for working to support your families, the young children, the elderly, the disabled, and those who supported you as long as they could. You are the backbone of America, and we support you. And just know it comes from the bottom of our hearts.
Here are some recipes for the grill to savor the ast days of summer.
DIJON GRILLED CHICKEN BREAST
1 tbsp Dijon mustard, 1 tbsp mayonaise, 1 tsp vinegar, 1 tsp black pepper, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 garlic clove (minced), cooking spray, chicken breasts (boneless, skinless).
In a small bowl, mix together Dijon mustard, mayonnaise, vinegar, black pepper, salt and garlic clove. Lightly coat the grill with cooking spray and preheat for 4 to 5 minutes. Place 4 chicken breast halves on the grill. Spoon the sauce over the chicken and grill for 5 to 7 minutes. Make sure you use all of the sauce. Double this recipe for a crowd.
GRILLED ITALIAN SAUSAGE AND PEPPERS
2 lbs Italian sausage, green peppers (seeded, thinly sliced), 1 onion (thinly sliced), 1 tsp black pepper, 1/2 tsp salt.
Cut Italian sausage into 4 portions. Lightly spray the grill with cooking spray and preheat for 3 minutes. Place the sausage on the grill. On top of the sausages place green peppers, onion, black pepper and salt. I sometimes sprinkle Old Bay seasoning. Double this recipe to fill the grill.
How about some great side dishes?
GERMAN POTATO SALAD
My friend Hannah always brings this great dish to cookouts, luncheons and dinners.
10 medium potatoes (peeled), 6 slices bacon, 3/4 cup sliced onions, 2 tbsps flour, 2 tbsps sugar, 2 tsp salt, black pepper, 1 tbsp celery seed, 3/4 cup water, 1/3 cup vinegar.
Cook potatoes until just done — do not overcook. When cool, cut into slices and set aside. Fry bacon, remove bacon from pan. Cook sliced onion in the bacon drippings. Add flour, sugar, salt, dash of black pepper, and celery seed. Cook until just bubbly. Add water and vinegar and stir until slightly thickened. Pour this mixture over the potatoes. Crumble the bacon over the top. Serve warm.
JELLO COOKIES
4 cups flour, 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 cup butter, 1 cup sugar, 1 3-oz package of dry Jello (flavor of your choice).
Sift flour with baking powder. Cream butter and gradually add sugar and package of dry Jello. Cream well. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. Drop batter by heaping tablespoons on a greased baking sheet. Bake for 12 to 13 minutes. Makes about five dozen.
STEAMED CORN
6 ears corn (husked), 2 tbsps granulated sugar, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 tsp salt.
Fill a pot full of water and bring it to boil. Stir in the sugar, lemon juice and salt. Place the corn into the boiling water. Let the water return to a boil. Once boiling again, cover with a lid and turn off the heat. Cook the corn for 8-10 minutes or until tender.
SWEET CORN RELISH
10 fresh ears of sweet yellow corn (husks and silk removed, slice kernels off the cob with a sharp knife), 2 large red bell peppers (cored, and finely chopped), 2 large green bell peppers (cored and finely chopped), 8 ribs celery (finely chopped), 1 large yellow or sweet onion (finely chopped), 4 cups apple cider vinegar, 2 cups sugar, 1 tbsp ground mustard, 3 tsps salt.
Combine all the ingredients in a pot and bring to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved. Reduce the heat to medium and simmer uncovered for about 20 minutes until the vegetables are tender. Ladle the relish into hot sterilized jars and seal with lids. Process the jars in a water bath for 10 minutes. Keep stored in a dark, cool place. Will keep at least one year. Once opened, store in the fridge for up to two months. Makes approximately eight pints. Wait a week or two before eating the relish to allow time for the vinegar to mellow out. Use it on hamburgers, hot dogs, sandwiches, fish, serve it with roasted chicken or mix with tomatoes/onions/cilantro for a Summer salad.
MEXICAN SALAD
1 onion, 4 tomatoes, 1 head lettuce, 4 oz grated cheddar cheese, 1 8-oz bottle French dressing, 2 cups Dorito chips, 1 lb ground beef, 1 15-oz can red kidney beans.
Chop onion with tomatoes and lettuce and put in a large bowl. Toss in cheddar cheese and French dressing. Crunch and add Dorito chips. Brown one pound of ground beef and add kidney beans when beef is browned. Simmer for 10 minutes. Mix into the salad and serve.
GRAHAM FROZEN STREET
Cool Whip (8 oz. container), box of graham crackers, container of color sprinkles or toppings such as nuts and cookie crumbles.
Lay out a cookie sheet to place your graham cracker sandwiches on. Pour sprinkles on a paper plate. You can separate if you have different varieties of patriotic sprinkles. Break sheet of graham cracker in half. Scoop Cool Whip with a tablespoon and place 2 tbsps on one half of the graham cracker. Close the sandwich gently and smooth sides with your finger or spoon. Dip each side of the sandwich in sprinkles. Place the finished sandwich on a cookie sheet. When the cookie sheet is full, cover with foil and place in the freezer for a few hours.
PINEAPPLE UPSIDE DOWN CAKE
Topping: 1/4 cup butter (melted), 1/2 cup brown sugar, 20-oz can pineapple slices (or 20 fresh pineapple rings), 1 jar of pitted maraschino cherries. Cake: 1/2 cup butter (softened), 3/4 cup sugar, 2 eggs, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (sifted), 1 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/2 cup milk.
Preheat the oven to 350-degrees. Grease a 8-by-8-inch baking dish. Topping: Add the brown sugar to the bottom of the pan. Melt butter, pour over the top of the brown sugar, mix together, and spread over the entire dish. Place the pineapples and cherries on top of the brown sugar, place cherries in the center of each pineapple slice.
Cake: Start by adding the butter to a large bowl and cream for one minute. Add the sugar and cream again for one more minute. Add the eggs, one at a time, and mix together. Add the vanilla and mix together. Combine flour, salt, and baking powder. Sift into the bowl and mix. Add the milk, mix together, and gently pour cake batter over pineapple. Bake for 40-45 minutes or until a cake tester comes out clean. Let the cake cool to room temperature and turn the cake upside down onto a cake plate. If you used canned pineapple, be sure to drain pineapple juice before removing the pineapple slices. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Labor Day recipes and cooking tips for summer celebrations, with minimal connection to any listed topics. While 'Local Life' could marginally apply due to the local newspaper context, the content is primarily about food preparation rather than community events or cultural activities. 'Entertainment' is a weaker fit as the article emphasizes recipes over leisure or media.

title: Chestertown’s casual gin connoisseurs
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Chestertown’s casual gin connoisseurs

 September 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 1229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — It all began with the little juniper berry, which actually isn't a berry at all, but what botanists describe as a seed cone with an unusually fleshy circumference and merged scales called a galbulus that gives it its berry-like appearance.It was this humble berry-like seed cone, however, that became the go-to ingredient for the all-important spirit and mixologist staple, gin.
The true origin of gin, has been historically debated, some tracing it back as far as the Middle Ages, where it was consumed for medicinal purposes only, and later in history it shows up again in the Netherlands in the 1700s as a more refined spirit called 'jenever' that was developed by a Dutch doctor, who also administered it for its healing properties.
This later iteration of gin was further developed in England after juniper berries were imported by Dutch merchants, who also talked up the wonders of the elixir derived from them. It is this history and, of course, the flavor profiles of the spirit that has made gin enthusiasts out of Lynn and Steve Mitchell of Chestertown.
The Mitchells are what you might consider casual aficionados of gin in the sense that they collect both common and rare varieties and are known to have about 20 different types on-hand at any given time. They enjoy entertaining friends and neighbors at smart gin-themed soirees and love discovering new gins on their various travels.
"With wine in the middle part of the 19th century becoming extremely expensive in England due to the duties placed on it, no one was buying wine, and they had to diversify," said Steve, a self-described fan of gins with a traditional juniper profile.
Among the bottles in their collection, Steve pulled out a large bottle of Gilbey's, which he described as a standard gin: one that offers good value for the money.
"If you're going to have a party and you're serving gin, this is the gin you want to serve," said Steve, who remarked that it is also a designated London Dry Gin, which historically means that it meets a standard for quality, although the term is often interpreted by some to be indicative of its flavor profile.
The distillers of Gilbey's gin, Steve said, were originally part of the larger contingent of wine producers that needed to pivot once those duties on wine and brandy were imposed. Gin consumption then became extremely popular in England creating what would become labeled as the "Gin Craze."
Steve, who attests to having more than a wee bit of British blood, (his mother was a World War II GI bride) said he learned later in life that he had ancestors who worked for Gilbey's early in the distiller's history. While he takes some of his ancestral tales with a grain of salt, he can verify that his great grandfather worked as a warehouseman for a liquor company in London.
As far as other solid, reasonably priced gins he pulled out a bottle of his secret weapon, something he said they often find at Costco.
Yes, Costco.
In fact, their Kirkland Signature label London Dry Gin made from natural botanicals is rumored to be produced by one of the most prestigious distillers in the world, although as part of the deal, Costco is forbidden to reveal which distiller it is.
While the online scuttlebutt often surmises it is a Tanqueray or Gordon construct, Steve has his own theory.
"I think it may be Bombay gin," he said, noting the shape of the bottle and its characteristic handle molded into the glass. These are gins that you can easily pick up locally, but there are others in the Mitchell's collection that are harder, if not impossible, to come by stateside.
There are two similar bottles that take a prominent place in the collection from the Slingsby Premium label, one a rhubarb-infused gin, the other gooseberry. These, he said, are best enjoyed sans-mixer in the cocktail style of a martini.
"Those I know I can't get until I go back to England."
Some of the smaller batch brands in the collection originate from as far away as Japan and New Zealand, and one organic seaweed gin from London-based distiller, Dà Mhìle, didn't even smell like seaweed at all, but does, indeed, leave the palate with a salty taste, according to Steve.
There's a gin from a boutique distillery once located in D.C. that has since closed that Steve is fond of called Green Hat. The name, he says, is a nod to the shady purveyor that supplied Congress members with alcohol during Prohibition. This particular purveyor was identified to those in-the-know by the green hat that he wore.
The "Navy Strength" designation, he said, denotes a 57% alcohol content, whereas traditional gin ranges between 40 to 45%.
According to Wikipedia, the British Navy required all booze and rum to be at 57% or higher; because if the casks on their ship ever broke and the gunpowder was flooded, the gunpowder would still need to be able to fire."
And then, there's a purple bottle of Hendrick's special edition gin in the grouping called Midsummer Solstice that was distilled for a limited time only.
"This gin was only produced in 2019 for one season, and I bought a bottle at Pip's (Liquors) and drank it, and figured they'd have it again the next year. They didn't [have it] and have not had it since then."
Fortunately, he received a call from the couple's daughter who lives in Cyprus, who told him she found a dusty bottle in a store there and asked if he wanted her to grab it for him. Needless to say, the answer was "yes", and that bottle has been consumed sparingly.
When it comes to gin, Lynn differs from her husband when it comes to flavor profiles.
"I'm not a Juniper fan," she said. "And coupled with my interest in gardening and cooking, I like more of the offbeat botanicals and the other flavors that are now being introduced."
Her favorite is a Japanese Craft Gin called Roku which she usually enjoys with an elderflower tonic.
An avid gardener, Lynn, is attracted to its vibrant floral notes balanced with the subtle spiciness of the Roku. She is also a fan, overall, of the approach some boutique distilleries had on the evolution of gin, particularly Hendricks.
"I think Hendrick's was really the trailblazer with their cucumber and rose combination; it showed that there was potential in the market for something other than just juniper."
Steve referred to Hendrick's approach to gin distilling as, "…. the watershed moment where actually the person who makes Hendricks gin is a female. And she, I guess said, 'Why are we making gin out of just juniper? Let's try something different.'"
This difference is being seen in the craft gin distilling business in a big way as it is now a more palatable option and is being favored by a newer generation of consumers, with a definite increase in popularity among women. According to a 2022 report by the American Distilling Institute, the gin category, and specifically the craft category, has seen exponential growth, specifically a 9% increase each year for nearly a decade.
Our conversation winded down with what else, but a good, old-fashioned gin and tonic while the late day summer sun faded with the couple talking about the possibility of one last gin-themed gathering in their screened-in back porch, and the next trip to England they may take as part of a tour around the holidays. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local couple's personal hobby of collecting and appreciating gin, including its history and cultural aspects. While it touches on local life, the content is not aligned with any specific topic in the list beyond general personal interest. The absence of direct relevance to categories like 'Entertainment' or 'Local Life' justifies 'None of these' as the best fit.

title: Charles native, killed in World War II, reinterred after eight decades
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Charles native, killed in World War II, reinterred after eight decades

 September 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A fallen soldier has been laid to rest in Maryland nearly 80 years after he was killed in action overseas during World War II.U.S. Army Pfc. Lemuel Dent Jr., a native of Charles County, was interred on Sept. 5 at Cheltenham Veterans Cemetery in Prince George's County. Johnson Funeral Services of White Plains performed graveside services preceding the interment.
At the service last week, Donald Dent, Lemuel Dent's nephew, received the flag covering his family member's coffin. Lemuel Dent was survived by four sisters and five brothers, but Donald Dent said that they have since died.
"It was a surprise to me," Donald Dent said about hearing that Lemuel's remains were identified.
Prior to this, all Donald Dent knew was that his uncle had died during World War II.
Lemuel Dent was killed Feb. 8, 1945, at age 30 near the Cinquale Canal, north of Viareggio, Italy, when the tank he was aboard was struck by enemy fire.
A resident of Ironsides, an area on Route 6 in Charles County, Dent was assigned to Company L, 3rd Battalion, 366th Infantry Regiment, 92nd Infantry Division, known as the "Buffalo Soldiers" in the European Theater.
The U.S. Army recognizes the 92nd Infantry Division as the only African American infantry division to see combat in Europe during World War II.
The tank Dent was in was struck by enemy mortar, machine gun and artillery fire. His body was not recovered at the time, and the Germans never reported him a prisoner of war, the Defense POW/MIA Account Agency said in a release.
On May 5, 1945, the American Graves Registration Command, Army Quartermaster Corps, was tasked with recovering missing American personnel in the European Theater. Investigators recovered a set of remains, designated as X-124 Castelfiorentino, from a gravesite approximately 2 miles west of Pietrasanta and 500 yards north of the Cinquale Canal.
The investigators initially identified the remains as possibly belonging to a soldier of the 92nd Infantry Division but did not have enough data to make a positive identification. The remains were interred at what is now Florence American Cemetery in Impruneta, Italy.
Dent was accounted for by the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency earlier this year after X-124's remains were exhumed in June 2022 from the Italian cemetery for laboratory analysis and identification.
At the funeral, local veterans and family members paid their respects to Dent. Members of the Buffalo Soldiers Motorcycle Club attended to salute Dent and pay homage to the rich history of the 92nd Infantry Division.
The name Buffalo Soldiers was initially selected for the club to pay homage to and ensure the legacy of African American military contributions in the post-Civil War era, according to the motorcycle club's website. The membership of the club is comprised of many active duty and retired service members, as well as law enforcement.
"I think it's a huge deal," Lonnie Bellamy, a member of Maryland's Buffalo Soldier chapter, said. "Taking the time to do all that work to lay him to rest, spending all that energy to put a name to the remains. … It absolutely resonated with us."
In Italy, Lemuel Dent's name is recorded on the Tablets of the Missing at Florence American Cemetery.
Now, a rosette rests alongside his name, indicating he has been accounted for and brought home.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: He still loves us
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: He still loves us

 September 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Genesis 6:5-6, we read that, "The Lord saw how great the wickedness of the human race had become on the earth, and that every inclination of the thoughts of the human heart was only evil all the time. The Lord regretted that he had made human beings on the earth, and his heart was deeply troubled (NIV)." Fortunately, we're here today because God found righteousness in a man named Noah.Even today, we are prone to sin, whatever our upbringing. We might be christened as babies and baptized into a church, we might go through childhood going to Sunday School and church every Sunday, but we are going to sin. But God still loves us.
We might grow to adulthood and become so dedicated to serving God that we go on missionary trips, memorize the Bibl, and go to Christian schools. We might become deacons or pastors, but even if we know and serve God and Jesus all our lives, we are still going to sin, and we are still going to be sinners. It's part of our nature.
"All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God." No matter how good we are, no matter how faithful, we will, on occasion, do wrong. The inclination to do wrong is in our hearts. God sees this. It's a part of our make-up, it's in the genes, it's in our DNA. But He still loves us.
We have always done wrong and we always will do wrong. God knows this better than we do, and it is because of our constant shortcomings that God sent His Son. Through Christ Jesus, we can wash our sins away. Yes, God still loves us. He always has, and He always will.

title: Tides of Grace welcomes new transit van
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Tides of Grace welcomes new transit van

 September 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 361
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Supporting the Eastern Shore through kindness and compassion, local non-profit Tides of Grace welcomed the addition of a transit van to more effectively service the community with a ribbon cutting ceremony at the Liberty Building Sept. 10.Thanks to a $12,500 grant received from the Queen Anne's County Commissioners covering the van, wrapping and insurance, the new vehicle for Tides of Grace will enhance the non-profit's ability to more efficiently serve the community through collections and deliveries, according to founder Leann Rhodes-Ickes.
Before the van, Tides of Grace volunteers utilized their own personal vehicles to distribute and collect goods for drives, she said.
"The support and love of the community is what keeps us going," Rhodes-Ickes said.
The mission of Tides of Grace is to support the community through kindness and compassion by providing a helping hand to those in need of resources and services.
What started as a holiday toy drive in 2022 has blossomed into needing its own designated set of wheels to serve the community, according to Rhodes-Ickes.
Tides of Grace provides free monthly services and drives for the community including collecting and distributing prom dresses, food bank goods, and hosting family photos, and family fun days.
More than just monthly events, Tides of Grace also staunchly keeps an ear out to who is in need and what is needed most in the community.
"Connecting the dots with the community has allowed us to make a full circle," Rhodes-Ickes said, as she credited Linette and Tim Miller with being instrumental in connecting Tides of Grace with the van within their price range.
"Keep doing what you're doing. It's about the community," Linette said.
Thanking Rhodes-Ickes and the Tides of Grace team for their initiative in servicing the community, County Commissioner Phil Dumenil noted it can be easy for the commissioners to fund worthwhile outside agencies, but "it takes a single person to get to that point," he said.
Serving about 300 people a month, the Stevensville based nonprofit would like to eventually expand to a larger space, Rhodes-Ickes said.
Tides of Grace is continually growing and is always looking for more involvement from the community and volunteers.
More information about Tides of Grace can be found at tidesofgraceinc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Advice for choosing candidates based on faith
author: JEFFREY S. TRIMBATH
content:
Advice for choosing candidates based on faith

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JEFFREY S. TRIMBATH | Section: Columns 
 
 754
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In just over a month, Marylanders will begin casting their votes in this year's general election. Every year, citizens of our state get to exercise their "consent," deciding who they want to represent them in government. In keeping with the scripture's command to love our neighbor (Mark 12:31), Marylanders of faith have a particular responsibility to participate.But how should Christians decide? What criteria should we use to choose one candidate over another?
I suggest the following five criteria may be helpful.
Person. Obviously, the most immediate vote one makes is for the candidate. What is the person like? What is their experience, both in politics and in life? What is their family life like? Do they have children? Have they been successful in a variety of different vocations and callings?
And what about their character? One important aspect of character emerges from the ancient meaning of the term as a "stamping tool." As an image embossed on a coin, does their public persona mirror their stated commitments? For example, if a candidate publicly claims a particular religious faith, his or her position on policy issues ought to be in conformity with, or at least not contradict, the fundamental teachings of that tradition.
Part of the character consideration is understanding that you are voting for political office, not ecclesiastical office. Of course, we want leaders in all sectors to be of good character. Favoring a presidential candidate, however, is fundamentally different than favoring your own pastor or priest.
Principles and Policies. Every person has core values, rooted in what they love and believe to be true. What are those core convictions, and where do they come from?
Every candidate possesses core values. For Christians, our core convictions about the most important issues in life are grounded in how God created us, and what He says in the scriptures.
What does the candidate believe about the human person, the nature of justice and how we're to live together? Which of these principles are more important than others?
A candidate's principles will inform their policies. For Christians, issues of life, family, education and religious liberty are top tier. There are important lower-priority issues too — property rights, rule of law, taxes, immigration, inflation, national security — which are informed by our commitment to justice.
Party. In our country there are two major political parties, both of which adopt platforms. Which platform most closely aligns with how God has created us and tells us to live? A candidate is one person, but that individual brings along with them the staff, resources and commitment of a political party. Which party has a history that aligns with biblical values?
People. Depending on the level of office, winning candidates bring with them staff and personnel to help them serve in office. The newly elected president will place 4,000 staffers in his new administration. Who are the people who will fill those positions? Are they known for their expertise and work ethic, or known for other things that distract from the task?
Prudence. After considering all of the above criteria, a Christian must ask: what is the most prudent choice? People of faith make political decisions in a fallen world, with a phalanx of competing dynamics and realities. Prudence is showing good and careful judgement as we make these choices. Part of making a prudent choice is understanding what is possible given this environment. Will the candidate you're choosing get elected? If that's not likely, are you supporting that candidate for another legitimate reason (to send a message, for example)?
A key aspect of making a prudent choice is weighing which candidate is the least bad. Scripture teaches, and experience confirms, that every human is fallen. Every election, therefore, is the choice of the lesser of two evils. Both candidates may favor abortion, for example. In that case, is there one that favors other policies that better align with other biblical principles?
There you have it — 5 "P's" to help you evaluate which candidate you will choose this November. I would add a final "p," and that's prayer. People of faith should fervently pray that God would give them wisdom and courage to vote for the right candidate, and pray that His will be done regardless of the outcome of the election.
God's people are called to "seek the welfare" of the city in which they find themselves, even if that land is hostile (Jeremiah 29). Taking the time to thoughtfully evaluate which candidates most effectively pursue that welfare is an important way we can love our neighbor and steward the gift of citizenship. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: One reason for unanswered prayers
author: KEN CLANDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: One reason for unanswered prayers

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN CLANDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church | Section: Columns 
 
 294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When it comes to God answering our prayer requests, there are many reasons that could be given as to why our prayers may go unanswered. One thing for us to consider is that poor relationships with others can hinder our prayers.When our kids were little, we would give them rewards for doing things around the house. We would tell them that if they picked up the toys in their room or took out the trash, we would go out for ice cream.
But at times, they would begin to argue and fight with each other while they were trying to earn their reward. During those times, I would simply say, "if you are going to fight, we are not going."
Jesus said, "…you can pray for anything, and if you believe that you've received it, it will be yours. But when you are praying, first forgive anyone you are holding a grudge against, so that your Father in heaven will forgive your sins, too." (Mark 11:24-25; NLT)
In other words, God says, "You can pray, and I will give you the desires of your hearts. But if you have some things going on in your relationship with someone else, you need to get that cleared up first."
The Apostle Peter tells husbands to honor their wives and to treat them with great respect, so that "…your prayers will not be hindered." (1 Peter 3:7; NLT)
Bitterness, disrespect and unforgiveness in our hearts will hinder our prayers before God. As a father, how our kids treat each other matters to me. To our Heavenly Father, how his kids treat each other matters to Him.
Your relationships with each other matter, and your prayers can be hindered if those relationships are not what they should be. Let's work on our relationships.
