title: Maryland stories: Couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Maryland stories: Couple celebrates 70th wedding anniversary

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1224
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nancy Peterson had employment lined up in her native Boston for the Summer of 1953, so she could make some money to help cover expenses before starting her senior year at Wheaton College near Chicago in the fall.Much to her disappointment, however, that job fell through.
So, Nancy accepted a summer job as a camp counselor at what is now known as Sandy Cove Ministries Christian Retreat Center, south of North East.
And that's how she met her future husband, Ralph Reisler... Well, that's sort of how they met.
On Tuesday, Ralph and Nancy celebrated their 70th wedding anniversary, a special day featuring delivered flowers sent by family members, friends and Ralph and dinner at a popular Cecil County restaurant.
"We see God's hand in how we met," Nancy said matter-of-factly while relaxing on a living room sofa inside the couple's home near Rising Sun.
Seated right next to his bride of seven decades, Ralph smiled and nodded in agreement.
It would be a much easier love story to tell if Nancy and Ralph had met at Sandy Cove while both worked there as camp counselors. That streamlined love story would include their summer friendship blossoming into love and leading them to the altar to exchange their wedding vows.
But Ralph didn't work at Sandy Cove.
When Nancy traveled some 350 miles south to work at that camp as a counselor in the Summer of '53, Ralph, a native Cecil Countian, was living on his family's dairy farm near Rising Sun. And he was working as a physicist at Aberdeen Proving Ground, where he and his colleagues conducted research on explosions.
OK, so if Ralph was working a good 25 miles away from Sandy Cove at that time, studying blasts on a military installation, how did he and Nancy cross paths?
This is where Ruth — Ralph's sister — enters their love story.
As it turns out, Ruth worked that summer as a Sandy Cove camp counselor, just like Nancy, and they had the same shift schedule. As Nancy and Ruth worked together at that Christian camp, they discovered commonalities and their friendship grew. (Ruth passed away in 2014.)
"Ruth also went to Wheaton College, but I had never met her before coming to Sandy Cove," Nancy noted.
Ruth invited Nancy to a family dinner on one of their shared off days. Because they were camp counselors, Nancy and Ruth lived at Sandy Cove that summer.
"She took me home with her — and there was Ralph," summarized Nancy, breaking into a smile.
Their conversation came relatively easy, considering that, according to Nancy, she wasn't very outgoing back then.
So how did Ralph feel after spending some time with Nancy during that family dinner?
"I was thinking, 'I better ask her out'," Ralph recalled.
And Ralph did just that, which led to another date and then another . . .
The Summer of '53 ended way too soon, however, and Nancy returned to Wheaton College, where she later would earn her elementary education degree.
She and Ralph kept in touch through letters.
Ralph also made a point to see Nancy in person as much as he was able to do so. During the next year, Ralph traveled periodically to Marshall Islands in the Pacific Ocean and to Nevada, as part of a work-related project. At both places, Ralph and his colleagues researched large explosive blasts.
His westward travels typically included a Chicago stopover, allowing him to spend time with Nancy.
"Back in those days, airlines would allow you to get off a plane at an airport that was on the way and get on another one heading to your (original) destination, without having to pay extra," Ralph explained, before noting, "Wheaton College is about 25 miles west of Chicago. So I planned my work trips so I could do a little courting."
Flash forward to Christmas 1953: The couple was seated together inside his parents' home when Ralph asked Nancy to marry him.
For the sake of spinning one of those dreamy love stories, it would have been fitting if Ralph and Nancy were lounging in front of crackling, dancing flames inside a brick fireplace when he popped the question. But they actually were keeping warm in front of a space heater.
And it would have been more storybook romantic if Ralph had dropped to one knee and slipped a diamond ring on Nancy's finger when he proposed. He did neither.
The kicker, though, was Nancy's answer — or lack thereof.
"I didn't give him an answer right away. I told him I needed to think about it. This was a big thing," Nancy said.
Ralph's feelings weren't hurt, though, because he understood Nancy's perspective.
He accounted for the fact that he was 25 and already had graduated from college, something Nancy was trying to achieve. Interesting fact: Ralph graduated from Wheaton College with a physics degree in 1949, one year before Nancy had arrived on that campus to start her academic career. Ralph also considered the fact that Nancy was 19 when they met.
So he gave Nancy time to think and to pray because both understood what a major commitment marriage is. Ralph still gently made Nancy aware of his feelings for her, though, in the months that followed. "I was persistent," Ralph said.
Flash forward to May of 1954: Ralph and Nancy are together on the front lawn of the Wheaton College campus, where Ralph pulls out an engagement ring and, once again, asks Nancy to marry him. Ralph didn't drop to one knee during the proposal — but that is OK.
"This was a little more romantic," Nancy said, laughing. "He said all the right things and kissed me."
Nancy said yes, of course.
Ralph and Nancy exchanged their wedding vows at her family's church near Boston on Sept. 17, 1954 — eight days before Ralph turned 26. Ralph turns 96 on Wednesday.
"The joke is, I asked God to be married by 25 and He did it with eight days to spare," Ralph said.
Ralph and Nancy have five sons — ranging in age from 54 to 68 — and 12 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren.
As for the reason they have been happily married for 70 years, Ralph and Nancy are quick to give God all of the glory.
Active members of Grace Bible Chapel near Rising Sun for nearly as long as they've been married, Ralph and Nancy believe that God wanted them to meet each other and that He made it happen in an interesting, roundabout way.
Remember the beginning of this perfect love story?
Nancy's first perceivable step toward Ralph was the disappointment that she experienced when her summer job in Boston fell through some 71 years ago, changing her plans and putting her on a new path — which led to her to Sandy Cove, which led her to Ruth, which, in turn, led her to Ralph.
Because Ralph and Nancy have personal relationships with God, they have been able to hold onto His guiding hand throughout their 70 years of marriage, at the highest peaks and through the deepest valleys.
"Following God's precepts and going to church," Ralph opined with little hesitation, when asked to give some keys to a long, successful marriage.
Ralph's comment prompted Nancy to quote Matthew 6:33, which essentially explains that blessings come to those who have their priorities in proper order in God's eyes. That Bible passage in the New Living Translation reads, "Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and live righteously, and He will give you everything you need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Religion Calendar
author: Angela Price
content:
Religion Calendar

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Angela Price | Section: Religion Calendar 
 
 2804

title: We need strong leadership
author: Staff Writer
content:
We need strong leadership

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 158
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Has it occurred to anyone besides me that our White House is empty of strong, sound leadership.It is now a fact to everyone that President Biden is senile. Kamala is prancing around the country trying to convince everyone that she would make a great president despite the fact that her values have not changed.
She has stated many times she is against funding the police, is against fracking, wants to continue with an open border and give the millions of illegals whatever they want at your expense, tax unearned income, control the food market and take away your legally purchased gun.
In addition she signed off on the horrific Afghanistan failure and doesn't really like Israel.
She is joyous, however. Let's hope Putin and the Chinese leaders do not read this paper to realize our country is the most vulnerable it has ever been not to mention increased crime and high terror alert. Support Trump. We need strong leadership.
SANDY WIELAND
Easton

title: Meet the new boss: Artificial intelligence (AI) brings a whole new meaning to political machines
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Meet the new boss: Artificial intelligence (AI) brings a whole new meaning to political machines

 September 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: News 
 
 1175
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vic Miller is in the matrix of artificial intelligence's intersection with politics and governance.Miller ran for mayor of Cheyenne, Wyoming, in August, finishing a distant fourth in the race.Miller's campaign centered on his plan to turn local governing decisions over to an AI-created system called VIC (Virtual Integrated Citizen).
Miller's AI-run for local office drew international attention. He said views of AI are still frequently defined by dystopian science fiction movies with Orwellian outcomes.
"There is a learning curve that hasn't been achieved yet," he said.
Miller said his AI goal is to prioritize public feedback and rational governance and rebuild public trust.
"I'm looking to get politicians out of democracy," Miller said.
Miller said he is looking at a future AI run for Cheyenne City Council, and he expects to see others look at bringing machine learning to governance.
"The toothpaste is out of the tube," he said.
But Miller is concerned about who will be able to access and use AI going forward.
He created VIC via ChatGPT's Open AI, but was booted from that platform over using the Microsoft-backed artificial intelligence technology for political purposes.
"What I didn't do is read their huge terms of service," Miller said.
He hopes the future of AI sits with open-source technology, rather than being controlled by large players. He said if the latter happens, it will be a "horror show" that will create a technological "caste system."
Miller has created the Rational Governance Alliance to foster open-source use of AI for data and public driven governance. Miller is looking to raise $10,000 to get the effort going.
That is a stark contrast to the big technology corporations and big money in the AI space.
The largest corporations in the AI space include six of the largest companies in the world (Apple, Microsoft, NVDIA, Amazon, Alphabet/Google and Meta/Facebook). They have a combined value of $15 trillion, according to CompaniesMarketCap.com.
'SCARY GREAT'
While Miller is focused on proving "the viability" of AI governance, for others, AI generates worries about misinformation and manipulation.
"It has become easier than ever to manipulate source material, create propaganda and influence narratives," said Isaac Mashman, founder of Mashman Consulting Group (a Little Rock, Arkansas-based consulting and branding firm), noting the amplified conservations around misinformation and "fake news" this campaign cycle.
Lou Steinberg, founder and managing partner of CTM Insights, a New York-based cyber research lab, said AI enable individuals to create convincing images and videos, and institutional and govern- mental actors to take their information and disinformation – dissemination to a mass production level.
"We've been using all open-source models, and they were great; Like, scary, great," Steinberg said.
He noted one of the AI voice fakes his group made of a foreign leader cost $20 to make and took a couple of man hours. "It no longer takes Pentagon-level resources," Steinberg said.
Miller said he spent limited money developing VIC via a $20 monthly ChatGPT subscription, but spent "hundreds of hours" feeding his creation documents and information.
Steinberg said there are also productive uses, pointing to India, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi used AI to translate his speeches and other campaign content into various languages and dialects.
"Better communication, better outreach, without subtitles. You can train these models to sound just like a voice. In fact, it only takes, you know, a couple hours of training time and a relatively small amount of video," Steinberg said, noting they don't look as awkward as past dubs.
He said there is a penchant to try to spot deep fakes and manipulated content.
"That's a fool's errand," said Steinberg, the former CTO at TD Ameritrade, stressing the focus should be on confirming what is real, rather thantrying to figure out what is fake.
Mashman said as AI technology improves and more creators adopt it, it will get harder and harder to discern "what is real and what is fake."
Cody Buntain, an assistant professor of information and cybersecurity at the University of Maryland, recommends increased due diligence for election-year content.
"When it comes to the 2024 election, don't take a single piece of information at face value. Always consider the source and how it fits in the broader picture," Buntain said.
While some AI applications will ban users who produce politically oriented content, there are scores of applications to choose from across the growing space.
"Generative AI is almost entirely unregulated, and there are countless platforms available for any person to use, so virtually anyone can create political misinformation with the help of AI," said Edward Tian, CEO of GPTZero, a New York-based AI detection company.
There are measures at the state level, especially in California, and proposals in Congress related to AI-generated content, especially so-called "deep-fake" pornography.
Some content created via AI enjoys First Amendment free speech protections in the U.S., especially parody or opinion. There are instances where prosecutors could pursue AI creators under election interference or fraud statutes.
Democratic presidential candidate Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz said in an August interview "misinformation and hate speech" do not enjoy First Amendment protections, sparking push back from speech advocates.
Scott Dylan, founder of NexaTech Ventures (a Silicon Valley-based, AI-focused venture capital firm), said laws and lawmakers are playing catch up to the AI wave.
"The political system, particularly candidates and officeholders, seems ill-equipped to fully grasp the depth of AI's influence," he said, noting that privacy and other laws will have to play catch up to all the changes.
Despite AI's reach and potential impacts on jobs, it has not been at the forefront in the U.S. elections, including the presidential campaign.
'DATA DRIVEN'
Dylan said AI is already a "transformative and disruptive' force behind the political curtains.
"Campaigns are increasingly leveraging AI tools to personalize voter outreach, optimize resource allocation, and enhance messaging," Dylan said.
He is seeing campaigns using AI to analyze social media trends, predict voter behaviors and maximize fundraising.
"Political groups are using machine learning to identify funding patterns, which helps them allocate resources more efficiently," Dylan said.
U.S. political campaigns are predicted to spend a record $10.7 billion on campaign ads this election (up 19% from 2020), according to research firm AdImpact LLC.
Neil Sahota, CEO of ACSILabs, a San Diego-based AI firm, who is also an artificial intelligence advisor to the United Nations, said political and campaign operatives view AI as "an indispensable tool" to gain a "competitive edge."
He points to both presidential camps and other political entities using AI for micro-targeting of voters and advertising buys — and machine-driven analyses of polling numbers.
The machines are also helping campaigns with speeches, social media and other content.
"Natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning algorithms assist campaigns in generating speeches, social media posts, and advertisements that align with their messaging strategy," said Sahota, who sees even more AI in politics going forward, including more use of augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR).
BIG BROTHER
But Sahota and Dylan also see voters concerned about privacy and groups surveilling their social media posts and online behaviors.
That gets back into the Big Brother dystopian worries referenced by Miller in Wyoming.
Dylan said voters might not like the sausage-making of AI-dominated politics.
"Many voters are wary of how their personal data is being harvested, analyzed and used by AI to predict their political leanings or behaviors," Dylan said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on AI's role in politics and governance, which doesn't directly align with any specific topic. While 'Public Safety' and 'Local Government' are tangentially related, the core theme of AI's societal impact and political implications falls outside the provided categories.

title: Breaking barriers: Access has improved, but challenges persist for voters with disabilities
author: MIke Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Breaking barriers: Access has improved, but challenges persist for voters with disabilities

 September 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIke Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 1280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 People with disabilities make up 13% of the U.S. population, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and U.S. Census Bureau.That's more than 42 million people.
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control has an even broader estimate, which includes more persons with cognitive and mobility issues.
According to the CDC, 28.7% of Americans have physical, cognitive or mobility disabilities.
Whether it's 13% or more than one-in-four Americans, persons with disability also make up a sizable — and frequently ignored — voting bloc as the November elections loom.
"All Americans have the right to vote for candidates and issues that are important to them, and people with disabilities have a lot at stake as what is decided in November can greatly impact their day-to-day lives," said Claire Manning, senior director of advocacy and mobilization at The Arc (an organization which helps and represents those with developmental disabilities).
BARRIERS TO VOTINGAccording to analyses by Rutgers University, persons with disabilities made up 17.7% of the electorate in 2020.
That was on par with Blacks (18.5%) and more than the Hispanics' (16.5%) share in the 2020 elections, according to Rutgers.
But 11 million disabled adults didn't vote in the 2020 election — making up 14.2% of nonvoters in the last presidential election.
Manning said disabled voters are a big enough block to sway the tight November elections — but they face continued barriers to voting.
"People with disabilities have always faced unacceptable barriers to casting their vote, and they continue to in 2024," Manning said. "This means they've been less likely than people without disabilities to turn out to vote in elections."
According to Rutgers' analyses, voter turnout among persons with disability in 2020 was 8.4% lower than among persons without disabilities. Turnout rates among persons with cognitive disabilities and mobility challenges were 25% lower than the non-disabled population.
In some parts of the country, voters with disabilities were more than 20% less likely to vote than voters without disabilities.
That includes Maryland where persons with disabilities are 20.9% less likely to vote than persons without disabilities. In Delaware, people with disabilities were 14.9% less likely to vote in 2020 and those without special needs.
Even with the Americans with Disabilities Act, which has been in place since 1992, some polling places have accessibility issues, said Anna Anderson, voting rights coordinator with Disability Rights Wisconsin.
Anderson points to polling places at schools, churches and other locations that might have challenges with steps, hallways, parking and voters being able to adequately use accessible voting machines.
Manning said pushback against mail-in voting and ballot drop boxes over concerns about fraud work against voters with disabilities.
She also said guardianship laws, lack of visual and audio voting aids and restrictions on who can help a disabled person cast ballots are also impediments.
Anderson said mail-in curbside voting and drop boxes are a big help for disabled voters. "There are never too many options that can exist to help people vote," she said.
Anderson would like to see disabled voters to be able to cast ballots from home. "One of the things that could be the most helpful is to allow people to vote electronically from their homes," she said.
Anderson said persons with disabilities can feel stigmatized voting when they draw extra attention or if poll workers are not properly trained or aware of protocols.
LEGAL ACTIONDRWI has also filed a complaint against Thornapple Township over the Wisconsin locality's move to remove an accessible electronic voting machine for this year's election.
On Sept. 20, the U.S. Department of Justice also filed a complaint against Thornapple in federal court over the action saying it violates the Help America Vote Act (HAVA), a 2002 federal law that requires polling places to be equipped with at least one voting machine that is accessible to voters with disabilities during federal elections.
Thornapple has a population of approximately 800 people and is located in the northern part of Wisconsin — 126 miles from Minneapolis.
Township officials have not yet responded to a request for comment.
DOJ also said it resolved a similar dispute with the town of Lawrence, the agency said.
That town — which along Thornapple is located in Rusk County and is about 150 miles east of Minneapolis— has agreed to install a disability accessible voting machine for the upcoming presidential election.
"Our democracy works when voters with disabilities have the right to vote on the same terms as any other voter," said Assistant Attorney General Kristen Clarke. "By failing to offer accessible voting systems, Thornapple and Lawrence shirked their responsibilities under the Help America Vote Act to provide equal access to the ballot for all voters."
Stacy Zimmer, who served on the Lawrence township board up until earlier this month, said the accessible voting machine was not used in a state election earlier this year and he contends Wisconsin law gives localities that option.
He was frustrated by outside groups' involvement in the issue in the small town of approximately 400 people
Charidy Ludescher said there will be one accessible voting machine at the township's one polling place in November.
'REASONABLE MODIFICATIONS'Sara Kempner, campaigns and strategic collaboration coordinator with the U.S. Vote Foundation, said the HAVA law has helped improve the voting landscape for disabled Americans.
"The 2002 Help America Vote Act (HAVA) has stipulated that the entire process of voting — from registering to casting ballots — must be made accessible,' she said.
"Voters can ask for reasonable modifications. This includes requesting curbside voting, skipping the line, or the opportunity to sit in a chair if standing is difficult. If one's assigned polling location can't meet these needs, voters can ask to be reassigned to a polling location that can," she said.
Kempner said the accessible voting system requirement "means voters with print disabilities may use screen readers. Voters with motor skill disabilities may use touchscreens or sip and puff devices."
HAVA also allows voters with disabilities to receive voting assistance, as long as it is not their boss or union leader.
Kempner said the law has helped shrink the turnout gap between disabled and non-disabled voters.
In Maryland and Delaware, voters with special needs can request mail-in or absentee ballots with online assistance tools, receive help in voting in-person and there are accessible voting machines at polling places including for persons with impaired or low vision.
In Montana, for example, every polling place has a specialized voting machine to help voters with disabilities vote privately. Curbside voting is also available, Voters with special needs can also get assistance filling out ballots from election judges or a designated friend or relative.
VITAL ISSUES
Still, Kempner sees challenges.
"Many polling locations are not yet fully compliant with HAVA standards. Sometimes the accessible voting systems sit unopened in boxes. Poll workers have not been adequately trained on rights and procedures," said Kempner, stressing the need for more awareness of disability voting rights.
Anderson said curbside voting for those with special needs is also helpful and that her group is working with nonprofits, community and churches to help disabled and mobility challenged voters get rides to the polls on Election Day.
She said that is easier in bigger cities such as Madison and Milwaukee.
"In rural areas, it's much more difficult to provide transportation," Anderso said.
Manning would like to see disabled voters and the issues that impact them more present during the 2024 campaign.
"The disability vote is powerful. Yet all too often, people with disabilities and the issues vital to them and their loved ones are absent from candidate debates, interviews, and media coverage," she said.
Manning said the general public is "overwhelmingly unaware of the experiences of people with disabilities in this country" and how elected officials approach various programs have big impacts.
"They decide how government programs like Medicaid, Social Security, and Special Education, which are vital to the independence and futures of people with disabilities, function and are funded," Manning said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on voting accessibility challenges for people with disabilities, legal actions under HAVA, and systemic barriers in elections. While it touches on public policy and national issues, none of the listed topics directly address disability rights, voting accessibility, or civil rights advocacy. 'Public Safety' is the closest but only partially relates to the core issue of electoral equity.

title: Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories
author: LINDA EVANS
content:
Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LINDA EVANS | Section: Columns 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Editor's note: This column originally appeared in the Star Democrat on Oct. 17, 2021. It is repeated here after Jimmy Carter celebrated his 100th birthday this week.It was the mid-seventies and I was a young Washington, D.C., Republican staffer with the rare opportunity to work as a personal assistant for the Honorable and Mrs. George Romney (Mitt Romney's parents).
Pretty exciting for a farm girl from the Eastern Shore of Maryland. When the Romneys invited me out to formal occasions, as a member of their staff, I was occasionally mistaken for Mitt's sister, Lynn.
It was cherry blossom time, and a longtime friend who drove me to the Tidal Basin that day happened to be an employee of the Secret Service. As we walked around the Tidal Basin, a long, black limousine pulled up and my friend yelled, "It's the president."
I nonchalantly responded, "The President of what? What company?"
He repeated, "It's President Carter! It's Carter!
As a government employee, he knew to position us near where the president's car door would open, with the idea of taking a photograph of the president, if possible. When President Carter emerged from the limousine, I was indeed one of the first in line, and even though I was a staunch Romney Republican, I did what any American would do, outstretched my hand and shook the hand of the president of the United States. Many would be lost for words at that point, but I somehow found the presence of mind to say sincerely, "Thank you for being our president."
President Carter, apparently touched by my sincerity, thanked me. My friend had his old Polaroid camera with him and asked the president if he would mind posing for a photo. The president quickly agreed, and then said to no one in particular: "Isn't she beautiful?"
What a compliment for me. I smiled for my friend's camera and that was the end of the exchange; my friend and I were off to tour the cherry blossoms with hundreds, possibly thousands of others that evening.
The Polaroids turned out so-so, but my friend, being politically minded, said he had seen White House photographers there. In fact, since I had my new black velour jacket over my arm, he said he felt the Secret Servicemen were carefully watching me for the president's safety.
"Why don't you call the White House and see if any of them got you on film?" he suggested. What an outlandish thought, but tempting. The next day, I looked up the White House switchboard number and hesitantly dialed 212-456-1414, and asked for the White House press secretary, as I had been instructed by my friend.
"Hello, this is Karl Schumaker," the voice on the phone answered with a German accent. Since I am also of German descent, we had something in common. I said, "Sir, you won't believe it, but the president of the United States told me I was beautiful yesterday at the Tidal Basin. "
Pause.
"What were you wearing?" he asked.
"I was wearing a pink jumpsuit and pink scarf."
"You are beautiful," Karl said. "I have three photographs of you. Would you like me to mail them to you or would you like to come to the White House and pick them up this week?"
I chose the date of Thursday that week because my sister would be in town, and we not only got autographed photos that day, but a tour of the Oval Office and presidential memorabilia. I showed the photos to our parents and then I filed them in my big, old file cabinet, with only one of the photos on my office wall, seen by almost no one. I'm still a Romney Republican and always will be, but also a Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter fan.
And a fan of someone else in the White House, the Press Secretary Karl Schumaker, who would teach the importance of customer service and taking extra time out to make memories that have lasted over 40 years. It was President Carter's birthday on Oct. 1 (he turned 100), and he received the Nobel Peace Prize also on Oct. 11 (in 2002), which reminded me of this occasion.
"To this day, Jimmy Carter looks back on a life of faith and service, and ahead to a more peaceful world," Mark K. Updegrove wrote in an article titled "Building a Better World," found in in Parade Magazine, Feb. 18, 2018. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Where we end up
author: PAUL TWINING Caroline County Coordinator, National Day of Prayer
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Where we end up

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL TWINING Caroline County Coordinator, National Day of Prayer | Section: Columns 
 
 293
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Please take a moment out of your busy schedule to ask yourself a very pertinent question: "Will the road of life on which I am traveling take me to where I want to go?"Of course, I am not thinking of a destination along the way, but of the final consequence of how I have chosen to live my life. Proverbs 14:12 says, "There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way of death."
The death spoken of in this verse is that of an eternal separation from God, so I dare not just shrug my shoulders and say, "Whatever."
What resolve is God looking for in a person's response to Him? The Scriptures make it clear that His approval of me is not based on the production of good things that I do in my lifespan. (Isaiah 64:6)
David in Psalm 51:17 informs us that "The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and a contrite heart, O God, You will not despise." God is looking for people who humbly admit their sin, and then turn in faith to Jesus for His forgiveness. (John 3:16)
Colossians 1:13 tells us that Jesus came to rescue us from Satan's domain and to transfer us into His kingdom. This provision puts us on the road that leads to a forever home in heaven with all who believe in what Jesus has done for us.
Our faith is not based on what we have done, but on what God has done on our behalf. John 3:1–21 is a great read for anyone who wants to be sure of being on the right road. May God give us honesty of heart and mind to evaluate where the road we are on ends up.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Teaching the faith
author: The Rev. David Casey-Motley Immanuel Lutheran Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Teaching the faith

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: The Rev. David Casey-Motley Immanuel Lutheran Church | Section: Columns 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Christianity is full of mystery, and yet, in another way, it's simple.The truth, in summary, could be placed on a page. Christ, born of Mary, is God's eternal Son. There is one God, three persons, Father, Son, Holy Spirit. Christ died as a payment for our sins, satisfying justice, a propitiation for our sins. Neither the works of the saints nor our own works in any way contribute to our salvation, which is wholly won by our Lord. As Christ's rose from the dead, so shall we, and when we rise we will see our returning Lord face to face. All of this is attested to in the scriptures, which are God's word.
And then, yes, baptism brings infants into the family of God, making them heirs of salvation. Why would we think that baby boys are somehow Israelites via circumcision, but our own baptized children are not Christian?
By instinct, then by our Lord's teaching about children. The Lord's Supper is the true body and blood, and brings to us the work of the cross, bringing us into communion with Christ. In baptism, we become members of Christ's body, and in the Supper, we take Christ's body into ourselves.
All of this is to say, doctrine is one, and it is whole, and there is no barrier in understanding. This is not a matter of depending upon a magisterium, for the scriptures are clear. I am happy to teach this stuff, but it is not so high or deep that you or anyone cannot get it. For it is God's Word that does the work. It is He who saves, forgives, and gives grace. It is His and His alone. May it ever be so. Amen. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland unions seek influence in election beyond membership numbers
author: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service
content:
Maryland unions seek influence in election beyond membership numbers

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KATHARINE WILSON Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1329
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — When Darlene Butler-Jones, a 66 year-old shop steward for Giant, walks into a store, people listen.Butler-Jones is part of a group of grocery store workers assigned by her union — United Food & Commercial Workers Union Local 400 — to explain the organization's political endorsements to her fellow employees.
As she walks through the store, talking to employees at cash registers and counters, Butler-Jones hears their concerns about fair scheduling, retirement, and dignity in the workplace.
"People want change," Butler-Jones said.
As Democrats and Republicans argue over which party truly represents working people and who will secure their vote, Maryland union leaders say it's not about party, it's about policy.
Capital News Service spoke to six Maryland-based union presidents and political leaders to better understand how union endorsements work and the impact of unions on politics in Maryland.
What the unions wantMaryland union leaders said they are focused on improving the lives of their members, which most said comes down to their ability to organize.
Donna S. Edwards is the president of the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO, a federation of more than 50 unions.
To get union backing, Edwards said, politicians need to support the Protecting the Right to Organize Act, commonly known as the PRO-Act, and the Public Service Freedom to Negotiate Act, a bill to guarantee the right to organize for public sector employees.
The PRO-Act, a bill promoted by the labor movement, aims to protect the right to join and form a union by prohibiting common employer intimidation tactics and requiring employees represented by collective bargaining units to pay their fair share of representation fees.
This Congress, 263 Democrats, three Republicans and two independents sponsored the PRO-Act. The bill has not been put up for a vote in either chamber. The Public Service Freedom to Negotiate Act has seen no action.
To get an endorsement from the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO, candidates must first fill out surveys detailing their stances on nearly every issue in some way related to labor. Then top candidates are interviewed by union members and leaders before a final selection is made.
The top three factors union officials making the AFL-CIO endorsements consider are the candidate's views on issues, viability and voting record, according to Kayla Mock, the political and legislative director for the local food and commercial workers union, which falls under the state's AFL-CIO.
Unions are focused on fundamental issues important to working people, like healthcare, child care, and the right to organize, Mock said. These issues, many union leaders say, typically favor Democratic candidates.
In the 2024 election, the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO only endorsed Democratic candidates for Congress.
"I tell my members this all the time, please bring me a pro-labor Republican. I would love to talk to them. I would love to endorse them," Mock said.
While many major unions in Maryland endorsed Democrats for local and federal office, as they have continuously done for decades, this isn't true among all unions and union endorsements aren't always followed by rank-and-file members.
Maryland-based Teamsters Joint Councils 55 and 62 endorsed the presidential campaign of Vice President Kamala Harris, breaking from the national union's decision to not endorse a candidate. However, in a Teamsters member poll from July 24 to Sept. 15, 49.4% of Maryland members wanted the national union to endorse Trump, compared to 46.5% for Harris.
In the 2020 election, around 60% of union households voted for President Joe Biden, Axios reported.
Jason Ascher, the Mid-Atlantic Pipe Trades Association's political director, said he has some union members who will vote for former President Donald Trump regardless of what Ascher and other union leaders recommend.
This trend, particularly among the building trades, Ascher said, followed the 1994 implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement — a pact among the United States, Mexico and Canada — that the Economic Policy Institute, a non-profit think tank affiliated with the labor movement, says led to the loss of thousands of union jobs.
The trade agreement, combined with social issues promoted by Democrats, pro-gun attitudes and the populism of Trump, created hard-line Republican voters within the union base, Ascher said. Now he and others are working at the local level to draw more of their union members back into voting for endorsed Democrats.
"It's a fight every day," Ascher said. "We have to convince our members, at least in the trades, that the Democrats are the ones helping us right now."
Ryan Whittington, the president of the Ocean City Career Firefighters Paramedics Association, leads one of a dozen first-responder unions endorsing the Senate candidacy of former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican.
When his union's board of directors decides to get involved in a state or local election, Whittington said, they open up a poll to every member of the union to select their preferred candidate. In the 2024 Maryland Senate race, Whittington said only two members of his union, which has more than 70 people, did not want the union to endorse Hogan.
"Within our local we have individuals who are Democrats, we have individuals who are Republicans," Whittington said. "For us, it's about looking at a candidate who is going to listen to the needs of our firefighters, our public safety officials, and make sure that they have our backs."
Who looks at union endorsementsWhile union members made up just 10.7% of the Maryland working population in 2023, union leaders say their impact stretches beyond their membership.
"We are members of the same communities that we're working in and living in. We're the next door neighbors," said Paul Lemle, the president of the Maryland State Education Association. "It's natural that people trust us."
Union popularity has seen record highs nationwide in recent years. In an August Gallup poll, 70% of Americans said they approved of labor unions.
Part of this increase can be attributed to younger Americans.
Around 88% of people under 30 supported unions in an August 2023 poll by the Democratic polling and research firm GBAO, conducted on behalf of the AFL-CIO.
Mock said she has seen first-hand a rise in young people embracing unions.
Her chapter of UFCW — which includes 35,000 workers across six states and the District of Columbia — held two successful union membership votes for cannabis dispensary workers within one week in Montgomery County, Maryland.
Mock, who was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention, said this attention from younger voters could be behind the Democratic strategy to boost the union vote.
"We're kind of the cool kids club," Mock said. "Democrats, very smartly, are going 'oh yeah, we actually do need labor.'"
In the 2022 statewide election, Maryland State Education Association members voted at a 24 percentage point rate higher than the rest of the state, according to the director of the union's political and legislative affairs, Samantha Zwerling. In every election, she said, politicians endorsed by the education association have more than an 80% chance of winning.
"Unions are inherently part of the democratic fabric of our society...That's what's meant by freedom of assembly and freedom of speech… they encourage participation and democracy," Lemle, the union president, said.
What unions want the public to know"Unions are not these big bosses. Look at me. I'm the union," Edwards, the Maryland State and D.C. AFL-CIO president, said.
The talkative, charismatic union leader was sitting in an emptying event space during the Democratic National Convention in August, showing her union friends in the Maryland delegation a photo of her holding a "Union Yes!" sign during the convention the night before.
Edwards, a social-worker by trade, grew up in a union home. She first joined a union while working for the Baltimore City Department of Social Services in the 1970s.
Her union leadership was able to get a pay raise for her unit of social workers — kicking off her passion for labor activism.
The union "is the only institution, in my view, that holds the line on a democracy in this country," Edwards said. "It allows for workers and their families to be involved in the political process, but it also gives you the financial security… to be able to be a contributing part of your community." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bug has invaded brains

content:
Bug has invaded brains

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 There seems to be a virus, or some sort of "bug" that has invaded the brains of nearly half the eligible voters in the United States of America. It attacks the truth receptors and reasoning sectors of these once perfectly healthy brains and renders them helpless.Anyone who still has an unaffected brain can make decisions which benefit this country and its citizens. We can still use our God-given filters to comprehend differences between truth and lies, good and evil, self-service and service to others and those individuals whose personal biases are consuming their reasoning and those who are clearly seeking the truth.
All clear-thinking voters need to stop hand-wringing, go to the appropriate site and vote for Kamala Harris for president and all who have promised to support her down-ballot. Time will be up in a few short days. Our beloved country's future needs your vote. Ride a bike, take a boat, car pool with neighbors and family members. Just be there.
VICKI SPARKS

title: Equal means equal
author: Staff Writer
content:
Equal means equal

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There has been a great deal of consternation lately concerning election judges in Talbot County. In fact, many people have complained to Sheriff Gamble since Maryland election law is being violated. As a good citizen and duly elected law enforcement officer, the sheriff wrote a letter to the election director questioning the intent of violating the law.For months, the election director has been dodging questions made by the public and apparently has been manipulating the law; however, this issue of flagrant abuse of the law has gone national. As anticipated, our Maryland state attorney general finally decided to weigh in. The Attorney General sent a letter to duly elected Sheriff reminding him that, as sheriff, he has nothing to do with enforcing election law.
Of course, we citizens of all political parties have a responsibility to ensure fair and safe elections, and the sheriff, unlike the attorney general, was properly amplifying the disbelief of concerned citizens.
Intentionally breaking the law? Are you really?
After the slap, the attorney general quoted the law, which states each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges from Democrat and Republican parties. He then says that, although that is true at each polling place, the total number of judges need not be equal between the two parties. What? Where are these unequal judges on duty if not at a polling place?
In past years, the people of Talbot County were told by the director of the Board of Elections that there weren't enough Republicans who signed up to be election judges. Nonsense.
If judge totals must be equal at every polling place, then the totals across the county will be equal. There are now 61 Democrats, 53 Republicans and 10 "other."
In our 10 precincts, only four abide by the law. It appears that information has been withheld from Talbot voters.
What part of equal does the election director Tammy Stafford and the Talbot election board not understand?
MARYANN JUDY
Easton

title: Talbot County food pantries gear up for the holidays
author: Tom McCall
content:
Talbot County food pantries gear up for the holidays

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — With the holidays approaching, Talbot County residents are preparing to hold food-centered gatherings, many with the help of local food pantries.Catherine Poe is the chair of the Talbot County Hunger Coalition, a network of members, providers and individuals working to end hunger and improve access to healthy, nutritious food. For the holidays, there is a big effort by the food pantries to provide festive meals.
"It is always so special. People line up long in advance because it is so unusual," Poe said.
Coordinating holiday plans for the food pantries begins months in advance, she said.
"The one (at the Senior Center) has already gotten their meals for Thanksgiving and Christmas. At Christmas it will come from The (Maryland) Food Bank," Poe said, describing the plan for one of the providers the organization works with.
Given the volume of food needed, the pantries get it at bulk prices and never buy from a supermarket. Sometimes donors help out.
"The other place is Mountaire Farms. It gives away thousands of free Thanksgiving meals. They are sending the Senior Center 100 boxes. All the pantries have to plan early where they are getting their meals from," Poe said.
They also get food from the Maryland Food Bank, a nonprofit hunger relief organization. Items from the food bank have to be purchased by the local providers, which Poe said gives citizens who want to help an opportunity to participate.
"We prefer cash (donations) because our money goes a long way," Poe said. "... The larger pantries spend about $7,000 a month, so they have to raise that every month."
St. Marks and St. Vincent dePaul food pantries use funds from their associated thrift shops to support feeding the community. Some other providers have grant writers to try to raise money.
Although the pantries take food from the public, it is more difficult to integrate it into their program than cash donations, Poe said.
Poe says the best bet is to cut a check to any of the nine food pantries in Talbot County — CarePacks, Talbot County Early Head Start, Brookletts Place, St. Michaels Community Center, St. Marks United Methodist, BAAM (Building African American Minds), Talbot County Local Care Team, WIC (Women Infants and Children) and The Talbot Family Network.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Let brotherly love continue
author: T.D. NICHOLS {&by2}Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Let brotherly love continue

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T.D. NICHOLS {&by2}Denton Church of Free Seventh-day Adventists | Section: Columns 
 
 245
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inspiration enjoins believers in Christ are admonished to "…see that ye love one another with a pure heart fervently" and to "let brotherly love continue."This theme of unifying respect and high regard is raised respectively in Hebrew 13:1 and in I Peter 1:22.
The world today is becoming increasingly divided, even in the face of numerous purported educational, scientific, cultural, political and other goodwill partnerships, whether humanitarian, religious or economic in nature.
Some of these alliances are cooperative efforts to share and promote equality, self-determination or justice. Divided by economics, nationality, race, social status, and in the U.S.A, specifically during this time of national elections, political affiliation.
It seems impossible to get through this cycle without increasing venom, hatred or suspicion. We do well to recall Proverbs 21:2, KJV saying: "Every way of a man is right in his own eyes, But the Lord weighs the heart".
Kindness, understanding and just plain decency seem to be lost at times. As never before, the admonition given to us in the Bible found in Romans 12:18 seems to be worth our consideration.
"If possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone."
We don't have to agree on every position, but that doesn't make us enemies. We don't have to have the same world view, but that doesn't have to also create division between us. Let's agree that we are a diverse community with different views but linked together with a common thread, and let brotherly love continue. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Exercise your constitutional right to vote Tuesday
author: ORESTES BAEZ APG Regional President
content:
Exercise your constitutional right to vote Tuesday

 November 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ORESTES BAEZ APG Regional President | Section: Editorials 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Tuesday, Nov. 5, we have an opportunity to exercise our constitutional right to vote. It is not a God-given right, it's a right detailed by our founding father's document to orchestrate a democratic world to exist and prosper in. And it's not about who you vote for, more importantly it's that you take the time to process choices and select a candidate you would be happy with in hopes others feel the same and provide enough support to move your candidate forward. Your candidate may or may not win.I shudder to think at what the founding fathers would say about the word smithing, arbitrary use of language, misinterpretation of the truth, and just some outright tomfoolery that some candidates show. I suspect that was not their original goal.
But why is this all so divisive? Why are our human choices creating chasms of space between people, friends and family?
My perspective comes from a small, rare point — I am a political refugee from Cuba. My father was in a prosperous country with lots of acceptance until the Russians made friends with the Communist Party in Cuba. My father was told he would be going to Czechoslovakia to teach the Russians how to fix cars. It was the second time they came for him.
"No thanks" was not an option. A friend from UNESCO smuggled my parents into the American Embassy and helped fake some documents so we could leave the country.
Come hang out in our communist world and see how popular it feels.
With $75, me, my sister, my dad's parents and my mom and dad flew to Miami to start over. Crowded living conditions, hard work ethic, no handouts were the beliefs we followed. Life of service — how can we help you? — was my mother's driving core belief. Ny uncles served in the Army to give back the country that accepted us.
We turned down relocation efforts around the U.S. because we would work to create our own prosperous world. We earned our keep each and every day. Our friends who were doctors and engineers pumped gas and sold newspapers to help generate money for the family until they could get an education and be certified to do what they did in Cuba.
The world was OK. We were tolerant of each other. Could we say that today? Should we say that today?
I visit the old neighborhood occasionally to remind me of my roots — the upstairs apartment over the garage that housed all of us, the old Sts. Peter and Paul church where I did my first Holy Communion, and the local markets where we shopped before the supermarkets existed.
People knew of you and helped you. We never fought over who to vote for. The most contentious conversations were the ones debating when the regime in Cuba would fall and how all would return to how it was. But we were still together.
What happened?
Today we can't put the genie back in the bottle. We are where we are and need to move forward. We need to find more middle ground and help all of us prosper. We need to vote and be tolerant.
Please join me in exercising your constitutional right on Nov. 5. And let's all be more tolerant. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The truth

content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The truth

 November 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: The Rev. Daniel T. Gedman St. Luke’s Global Methodist Church | Section: Columns

 Words 

 Read News Document

 While the world and its ways are always subject to change at the whims of those in control, God and the Bible are not subject to change.In a world of seemingly endless lies, we must remember that truth is not subject to new whims or reimagining. It is not up for negotiation. The truth does not change. It is objective, not subjective.
When reading the Bible, the truth is often disclosed by the definite article "the." It is stated definitively and singularly. One does not have to connect bits and pieces of a verse here and a verse there to find the truth, it is discernibly clear.
For example, Jesus said, "I am the way and the truth and the life, no one comes to the Father except by me." Notice that there are four statements of absolute truth in that sentence all highlighted by the definite article.
Jesus did not say, "I am a way." There are not many ways to God. Also, rather importantly, the definite article is set before "Father" as well. This highlights the fact that there is only one God the Father, not many gods.
Truth is not a series of ideas pulled, redacted, edited and restated from manifold sources. One will not discover the truth of God through the study of comparative religions or philosophies. It is found only in the Bible. There is but one way of salvation; Jesus the Christ. (Note my inclusion of the definite article for Jesus is the one and only Messiah).
Ultimately, the Bible is the perfect standard of truth. It defines truth as being absolutely reliable and enduring. The reason is quite simple: Authentic, biblical truth is inextricably linked to the dependable, unchanging character of God.
You can trust everything He says; He never lies; He always keeps His Word; He's faithful to all His promises. Thanks be to God we have the Bible.

title: It's time for a new season; they pass quickly
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
It's time for a new season; they pass quickly

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 341
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are entering into a different season in America. It's not a season everyone likes or voted for but the season is changing. For some it's better, for some it's worse. For some it's good news, for some it's bad news.Your perspective colors your season. For example, if you love autumn then you have enjoyed the current season in much of America. You haven't enjoyed it if you've been in the path of a hurricane, but you've enjoyed it if you live in most any other place in America. We've had a dry fall season, but it has been beautiful. Many dread the winter months, while some welcome cool weather over the long months of dry hot weather. If you live in Southern Arizona, you are ready for some cooler weather.
Political seasons are hard on our nation. We've been immersed in political advertisements for months. The presidential campaign has gone on forever. We are so ready to move forward. For many in America this doesn't feel good while others think it's great.
Seasons come and seasons go. No season lasts forever. There is always a new season around the corner. It's best for all of us if we can make the best of whatever the season of life is at the time. Winter or summer, make the most of the season. Youth or old age, they pass by so enjoy your season. Small children or adult children, love them and roll with the seasons. Young parents or old parents, roll with the seasons. Making great money or making less money, roll with the seasons.
Try to make the best of your current season in life. It's not always easy. We don't like the seasons of life when we are sick or even dying. Some seasons are difficult and even harsh and cruel, but they come to us all if we live long enough. So, enjoy the good seasons, tread water or make the best of what seems to be a bad season because in time in some way the season will change. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Infrastructure spending needs to use common sense
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Infrastructure spending needs to use common sense

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 730
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In late October, President Biden visited Baltimore to announce that the Maryland Port Administration will receive $147 million in federal funds for infrastructure improvements.During his visit, Biden did not acknowledge or address serious issues with another much larger federally funded infrastructure project in Baltimore.
That project is construction of a new $6 billion Frederick Douglass Tunnel in Baltimore for Amtrak, America's quasi-public rail passenger company.
The current tunnel is over 150 years old and is a major bottleneck on Amtrak's high-speed northeast corridor passenger rail service between Boston and Washington, D.C.
As a long-time, staunch supporter of Amtrak, I understand the need for this long overdue tunnel replacement project.
That said, I am stunned and disheartened by how much this project has been mismanaged.
In early October, Amtrak's Office of Inspector General released a scathing report on this project.
The mission of Amtrak's inspector general is simple and straightforward.
Conduct and supervise independent and objective audits, inspections, evaluations and investigations relating to agency programs and operations; promote economy, effectiveness and efficiency within the agency; prevent and detect fraud, waste and abuse in agency programs and operations.
Consistent with their mission, in the inspector general's report on the Baltimore tunnel project, they noted that Amtrak did not establish a program management structure early enough. As a result, they struggled to complete the necessary planning in scheduling, communications, document management and risk management for this project on a timely basis.
The inspector general criticized Amtrak's initial assignment for project management responsibility of a $6 billion dollar project to a single individual.
Eventually, the program team was expanded to seven members, but five told Office of Inspector General auditors that they were still overwhelmed by their workload.
Amtrak officials have since acknowledged staffing was insufficient and said the Capital Delivery team should have been staffed before it received responsibility for the program.
Amtrak later decided to hire a "delivery partner" to provide management and oversight, but that contractor wasn't engaged until the spring of this year. Amtrak officials agreed that the decision "should have been made earlier" to "maximize the benefits the delivery partner was intended to provide." As a result, the new contractor has to plan a management structure as it also prepares for construction.
The Office of Inspector General report made three recommendations:
Complete program management planning for the tunnel project.Establish processes to ensure the a project's management structure is established early enough to produce strong oversight for the life of the project.Establish processes to ensure program teams have sufficient staff before projects are assigned to the Capital Delivery department.
Amtrak management, in their response to the report, agreed with the recommendations and outlined how it is acting to meet those goals.
The inspector general's report concludes the project now "faces a significantly increased risk of cost overruns and additional delays as it proceeds into major construction." The report does not include projections for future cost overruns and additional delays.
On a $6 billion construction project, one thing is almost certain. Cost overruns and completion delays will likely be substantial. As a result, funds needed for other Amtrak service improvements to increase ridership and reduce their government subsidies will not be available.
I am sure this colossal mismanagement of federal funding by Amtrak is not unique.
Unfortunately, conventional thinking is public infrastructure projects completion delays and cost overruns are standard operating procedure. In other words, this is the way it has always been and the way it will always be.
That thinking needs to change especially when the federal budget deficit is at record levels, currently at $1.83 trillion and growing.
Former U.S. Sen. Everett Dirksen once observed, "A billion dollars here and a billion dollars there and pretty soon you are talking real money."
Many Americans are carefully monitoring their budgets and adjusting their spending habits on a regular, even daily, basis in order to pay their bills for basic living expenses.
Going forward, we need and deserve elected and appointed officials at every level of government to take appropriate steps to ensure funding for all government funded infrastructure improvement projects is spent efficiently and effectively.
They need to address the fact the current audit process is largely reactive, not proactive.
Concurrently, government project managers must be fully aware of and committed to best practice project management policies and procedures prior to and during large scale and complex infrastructure improvement projects.
It is common sense to help ensure things go right in the first place as opposed to learning what went wrong after the fact. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal infrastructure spending, project management failures, and audit issues related to a $6B Amtrak tunnel project. While it involves government funding and national implications, none of the listed topics directly address infrastructure management, federal project oversight, or bureaucratic inefficiencies. 'Public Safety' is tangentially related but not central, and 'Business/Economy' lacks specificity to the administrative critique in the text.

title: Giving thanks for my mother and her recipes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country cooking
content:
Giving thanks for my mother and her recipes

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country cooking | Section: News 
 
 1452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today I am pulling a favorite cooking column of mine from a few years ago. Not only do I love it, but I had a request from one of Mom's great granddaughters who had heard about it and wanted to see a repeat. This column fits right in with your holiday dessert planning, so enjoy.GIVING THANKSToday I am starting my column by giving thanks for the 52 years I was blessed with having one of the most influential women in my life — my mother. Mom was born on July 4, 1911, and died on Nov. 18, 1997 after a brief illness.
Mom graduated at the age of 16 after completing 11 years of school, as required in those times. By the age of 21, she had married my father; bought a farm; built a house, barn and chicken house; and was raising hogs and cows along with growing truck crops for market.
Did I forget to mention my parents throughout the years had nine sons and two daughters?
What a wonderful family life we had — the most complaining I ever heard her say was, "How many more can we feed at the table, 'cause company is coming or get them fresh eggs from the hen house for breakfast or I will eat after everyone else has eaten.'"
Laura Hudson Hitchens was not a woman to back down from whatever life handed her — she made the most out of a little and asked for nothing in return from anyone. I can never fill her shoes, but I have never given up trying.
Mom loved to cook anything, and she never really had a favorite food to cook, but her desserts were loved by everyone as she made the best pie crust ever. And those biscuits came in a close second! Let's make some Thanksgiving desserts today.
FOOL PROOF PIE CRUST4 cups flour, 1 1/3 cup shortening, 2 tsp salt, 1 tbsp sugar, 1 egg, 1 tbsp vinegar, 1/2 cup water.
Mix flour with shortening, salt and sugar. Set aside. Beat together egg, vinegar and water. Begin sprinkling the dry and wet ingredients together. Turn ingredients together with a fork. Chill 15 minutes or longer in the refrigerator before working into pie crust. Remove from the refrigerator and break into portions. Work the dough on a floured surface until smooth and proceed to roll out into the appropriate size crust you need.
EASY PIE DOUGH1 cup shortening, 1/2 cup boiling water, 3 cups flour, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp salt.
Cream together shortening with boiling water. Beat well. Add flour, baking powder and salt. Mix lightly and roll out on a floured surface.
PUMPKIN PIE2 cups pumpkin, 5 tbsp flour, 1/2 cup white sugar, 3/4 cup brown sugar, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spices, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 3 cups milk, egg whites.
Mix pumpkin, flour, sugars, salt and spices. Add milk. Beat egg whites and fold into the mixture last. Pour into an unbaked pie shell and bake in a preheated 450-degree oven for the first 15 minutes and then 350 degrees until toothpick inserted comes out clean — maybe 20 to 25 minutes.
SWEET POTATO PIE3 cups mashed sweet potatoes, 2 cups evaporated milk, 4 eggs, 2 1/4 cups sugar, 2 tsp lemon extract, 1 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/4 tsp baking powder, 1 tbsp milk, 1 cup coconut (optional)
Combine sweet potatoes, evaporated milk, eggs and sugar. Beat at a high speed and then add lemon extract and vanilla. Then mix baking powder with 1 tablespoon milk and add to potato mixture. Add coconut, if desired. Mix well and put in two 9-inch baking pans (pie pans) and bake in a preheated 375-degree oven for one hour.
APPLE PIE4 cups peeled and diced apples, 1/4 cup lemon juice, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 cup flour, 1/4 tsp salt and 1/4 cup half and half.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Prepare pastry for one two crust 9-inch pie. Place one crust on the pie plate. Mix apples, lemon juice, sugar, flour, salt and half and half. Mix well and pour into the unbaked pie crust. Cover with the remaining crust and cut slits in it, seal and flute the edges. Bake until the crust is brown, and juice begins to bubble — 50 to 60 minutes. You can place small strips of foil around the edges of the crust, before baking, to keep edges from burning. Remove foil for the last 15 minutes of baking. You can also add 1/2 cup chopped walnuts.
OLD FASHIONED MINCE PIE28-oz jar prepared mincemeat, 1/12 cups diced apples.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Place one unbaked pie crust on a 9-inch pie plate. Mix mincemeat with apples. Pour this mixture into the pie crust. Cover the top with another unbaked pie crust. Flute edge and seal. Cut slits into top crust and bake for 40 to 45 minutes.
NO ROLL PIE CRUST3 cups flour, 2 tsp sugar, 1 tsp salt, 1 cup vegetable oil, 1/3 cup milk.
Mix ingredients gently to combine. Divide in half and place each half of dough in a regular 9-inch pie pan. Pat out gently Push pastry up the sides and form a nice edge with your thumb and finger. Prick pastry on the bottom to prevent bubbling of the pastry during baking. Bake in a preheated 350-degree oven with your favorite filling or bake empty — let cool and add your favorite filling.
NEVER FAIL CRUST5 cups flour, 2 tsp salt, 1 tsp baking powder, 2 cups shortening, 1 egg, water, 1/4 cup vinegar.
Combine flour, salt, baking powder and shortening until coarse crumbs. In a measuring cup beat egg lightly with a fork and add enough water to equal 3/4 cup. Add vinegar and slightly beat with a fork again. Pour the egg mixture into the flour mixture and stir just to make a ball. Roll out shells for your pies. I found that with this recipe if you place the shell in the pie pan and freeze slightly then the shell does not shrink during baking.
IMPOSSIBLE COCONUT PIE4 eggs, 2 cups sugar, 1/2 cup flour, 2 cups milk, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 can flaked coconut.
In a blender, mix together ingredients. Pour into two 9-inch pans, lightly greased. Bake at 350 degrees for 30 minutes or until set.
PECAN BARSFor crust: 1 cups unsalted butter at room temperature, 1/2 cups packed brown sugar, 1/2 tsp salt, 2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour.
For filling: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, cut into pieces; 1 cup packed dark brown sugar, 1/3 cups honey, 2 tbsp bourbon, 2 tbsp heavy cream, 1/2 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp pure vanilla extract, 3 cups pecan halves chopped roughly.
Heat oven to 350 degrees. Lightly coat 9- by 13-in baking pan with cooking spray. Line with parchment, leaving an overhang on two long sides; spray parchment.
To make crust, using an electric mixer, beat butter, brown sugar and salt until light and fluffy. Reduce mixer speed and gradually mix in flour until small clumps form. Press into the bottom of the prepared pan. Using a fork, poke holes all over then bake until light golden brown, 20 to 25 min. Let cool while making filling.
For filling, in a small saucepan on low, combine butter, sugar, honey, bourbon, heavy cream and salt. Increase heat and bring to a boil; boil for 2 min. Remove from heat and stir in vanilla, then fold in pecans.
Pour mixture over baked crust, return to oven and bake until nuts are golden brown and edges are bubbling, 25 to 30 min. Let cool completely in the pan, then use overhangs to transfer to a cutting board and cut into pieces.
APPLE PEAR CRISP1/2 cup old-fashioned oats, 3 small Gala or Empire apples (peeled and chopped), 2 medium pears (peeled and chopped), 1 tbsp water, 2 tsp brown sugar, 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon, 1/2 tsp ground ginger, 1/2 cup dried cranberries, 1/3 cup chunky sweetened peanut butter, 3 tbsp whole wheat flour, 1/4 cup fat-free whipped cream.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Spread the oats in a single layer on a jelly-roll pan. Toast them 5 to 8 minutes or until golden brown, stirring once halfway through. In a 4-quart saucepan, combine the apples, pears, water, sugar, cinnamon, and ginger. Cook on medium heat, stirring occasionally, for 10 to 12 minutes or until sugar dissolves and fruit softens. Remove from the heat and stir in the cranberries. Divide the mixture among 6 shallow 12- to 16-ounce baking dishes.
In a medium bowl, combine the oats, peanut butter, and flour. Rub the mixture between your fingers to form small clumps then sprinkle it over the fruit mixture in the baking dishes. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes or until browned and bubbling. To serve, top each crisp with 1 tablespoon of whipped cream. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal reflections about a mother's recipes and cooking techniques, featuring multiple dessert recipes. None of the listed topics directly address cooking, food culture, or culinary traditions. While 'Arts & Culture' could marginally relate to cultural food practices, the content is not aligned with any specific topic in the provided list.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Give God our thanks
author: THE REV. D.L. HINES Eternal Life Ministries
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Give God our thanks

 November 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE REV. D.L. HINES Eternal Life Ministries | Section: Columns 
 
 436
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As I sit here recovering from a lung infection, I am reminded that I still have a reason to be thankful to God for all He has done for me and all that He is to me. I am led to reflect upon Psalm 138:1-8.This is a psalm of David, and it was sung by him as a declaration of high praise unto Almighty, God our heavenly Father, for His excellent greatness. It is a bold statement made by the psalmist because it expresses the human soul's deep need to worship the creator and articulates the heartfelt sentiment that God alone is worthy of all our praise.
David says, "I will praise the Lord with my whole heart, that means with a heart that is fully committed to pouring out the oil of gratitude as a sacrifice of thanksgiving upon the altar of God. I will praise my God with all that I have in me, and I will do it in the presence of everything and everybody that this world has exalted, to show forth my estimation that there is no God like Yahweh."
David further declares that he will always turn toward the God of his salvation to worship Him because of His lovingkindness and for His truth.
And we can bear witness to that, for we know that God so loved the world that He gave His only begotten son so that whoever believes in Him should not perish but have eternal life. In a world of lies and deceit, this is the one truth that can cut through every falsehood that Satan has deceived us with concerning ourselves and bring us into the marvelous light of the Gospel.
David said of God, "in the day that I cried out to you, you answered me and gave me strength deep down in my soul." How many of you know what it's like to cry out to God during your time of troubles and God answered your prayers and gave you strength to run on to see what the end was going to be? That should make you feel grateful that God, Almighty took the time to incline His ear to hear your cries and deliver you from your distress.
In the light of all the wonderful things that God has bestowed upon us and considering the magnitude of all that He alone is, David just could not help but to give our God all praise.
And when you and I look at our lives after all that the Lord has done for us, we too should not be able to withhold our praise from Him and shout Hallelujah.
