title: Country Cooking: Inventive recipes from the 1940s
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Inventive recipes from the 1940s

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Yes, it is that time of year again. And I do not mean Super Bowl, or Valentine's Day or tax time. It is a time that I let slip by quietly.I was born on Feb. 11, 194... My mother told me it was 3 degrees that February morning. I was born at home, so that meant the doctor traveled across town on snow- and ice-covered roads. My sister was 10 years old and at that time. I already had six older brothers, soon to be followed by three more brothers.
My sister's birthday was Feb. 15, and she did not want to share birthday parties. Some world and national news in the 1940s included the Italian partisans killed Mussolini, Hitler committing suicide after destroying major cities in Germany, World War II ending, Harry Truman taking the office of President after Roosevelt passed away.
Not only were things hard on our Bishopville farm, but the whole world was feeling the impact of World War 2. Creativity blossomed during the Great Depression and carried on into the 1940s.
The decade of the 1940s brought many things to our world: The microwave oven, ball point pens, Velcro, Tupperware and the frozen orange juice.
History has shown us again and again that financial hardship drives people to get a little more inventive in the kitchen.
Wartime rations necessitated substitutes and ingredient-stretching techniques. As a matter of fact, on the back of my birth certificate are stamps for sugar and flour. Thankfully, my parents never needed to use them.
After the war ended, food manufacturers explored methods that gave products a longer shelf life. During the latter half of the decade, more convenience products arrived on shelves as scientists delved into researching food preservation.
Like most 1940s recipes, meatloaf experienced a resurgence in popularity during the Great Depression. The use of bread or cracker crumbs helped stretch the ground beef as it was getting harder and harder to come by.
When the soldiers came back home from the Pacific they also brought home a love of SPAM. Philippines, Guam, Hawaii and Okinawa were places Spam was the most popular. Most of the time eggs were mixed with Spam because they were cheap and most everyone had chickens in the backyard.
"Victory Gardens" were another big thing in the 1940s. Many papers circulated various vegetable recipes. Soups and stews were cost-effective meals that could also stretch more precious ingredients such as meat and dairy.
No bake cookies that used things such as Corn flakes were served in just about all houses, even the White House.
One invention that has surely at one time or another been in just about everyone's hands — the corn dog — was created by German immigrants in Texas, who were sausage-makers finding resistance to the sausages they used to make. They have been credited with introducing the corn dog to the United States in the early 1920s, though the serving stick came later.
Carl and Neil Fletcher can claim that having introduced their "Corny Dogs" at the State Fair of Texas sometime in 1942. In 1946, on Muscle Beach in Santa Monica, California, Dave Barham opened the first Hot Dog on a Stick location.
So, as you see, the corn dog has a long disputed history, but boy are we glad to have it.
Here are some recipes from the 1940s this week to not only celebrate my birthday but to revisit a time where counting every penny and getting creative was a must.
HOMEMADE CORN DOGS1 cup yellow cornmeal, 1 cup all-purpose flour, ¼ cup white sugar, 4 tsps baking powder, ¼ tsp salt, ⅛ tsp black pepper, 1 cup milk, 1 egg, 1 quart vegetable oil for frying, 2 (16-oz) packages beef frankfurters, a pack of wooden skewers.
Combine cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, salt and pepper in a medium bowl; stir in milk and egg to make a batter. Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees, pat frankfurters dry and insert a skewer into each one, roll frankfurters in batter until well coated. Fry two or three corn dogs at a time in preheated oil until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels.
1940s BROWN SUGAR MEATLOAFCooking spray, ½ cup packed brown sugar, ½ cup ketchup, 1 ½ lbs lean ground beef, 2 large eggs, 1 small onion (chopped), ¾ cup milk, ¾ cup finely crushed saltine cracker crumbs, 1 ½ tsps salt, ¼ tsp ground black pepper, ¼ tsp ground ginger.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Lightly grease a 5-by-9-inch loaf pan. Press brown sugar into the bottom of the prepared loaf pan and spread ketchup over sugar. Mix all remaining ingredients thoroughly in a mixing bowl and shape into a loaf. Place on top of the ketchup and sugar crust. Bake in the preheated oven for 1 hour or until juices are clear.
SPAM AND EGGS2 large eggs (beaten), 1 container fully cooked luncheon meat, 2 oz Cheddar cheese (grated).
Cube the meat. Heat a nonstick skillet over medium heat. Pour eggs into the skillet, then scatter luncheon meat over top. Cook and stir until eggs are nearly set, 3 to 4 minutes. Sprinkle cheese over top and stir until cheese is melted, 1 to 2 minutes.
GARDEN FRESH TOMATO SOUP4 cups chopped fresh tomatoes, 2 cups chicken broth, 4 cloves garlic, 1 large slice of onion, 2 tbsps butter, 2 tbsps all-purpose flour, 2 tsps white sugar to taste, 1 tsp salt to taste.
Combine tomatoes, chicken broth, garlic cloves and a large slice of onion in a stockpot over medium heat. Bring to a boil, and gently simmer for about 20 minutes to blend flavors. Remove from heat and run the mixture through a food mill into a large bowl or pan, Melt butter over medium heat in the now empty stockpot. Stir in flour to make a roux by cooking, whisking constantly, until the mixture turns medium brown. Gradually whisk in a bit of the tomato mixture to prevent lumps from forming, then stir in the rest. Season with sugar and salt to taste.
NO BAKE COOKIES½ cup white sugar, ½ cup light corn syrup, 2 tbsps butter, ½ cup peanut butter, 3 cups of corn flakes cereal.
Bring sugar and corn syrup to a boil in a saucepan over medium heat. Stir in butter and peanut butter until thoroughly combined, then remove from the heat. Place cornflakes into a large bowl. Pour peanut butter mixture over top and mix until cornflakes are well coated. Drop 1-tablespoon scoops of the mixture onto a waxed-paper lined baking sheet. Flatten slightly if desired, then allow to cool for 30 minutes before serving.
STUFFED PEPPERS
1 cup cold water,½ cup uncooked long grain white rice,1 tablespoon vegetable oil,1 pound ground beef,6 medium green bell peppers,16 ounces tomato sauce, divided,1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce,¼ teaspoon garlic powder,¼ teaspoon onion powder, salt and ground black pepper to taste,1 teaspoon Italian seasoning. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Bring water and rice to a boil in a covered saucepan. Reduce heat to low and simmer until rice is tender, about 20 minutes. Meanwhile, heat oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add ground beef and cook until evenly browned and crumbly, 7 to 9 minutes. Hollow out bell peppers by removing and discarding the tops, seeds, and membranes. Slice the bottoms of the peppers if necessary to make sure they stand up straight. Arrange peppers in a baking dish with the hollowed sides facing upward. Prepare filling by mixing cooked beef, cooked rice, 1/2 of the tomato sauce, Worcestershire sauce, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper. Spoon an equal amount of filling into each hollowed pepper. Mix remaining tomato sauce and Italian seasoning in a bowl, and pour over the stuffed peppers. Bake in the preheated oven, basting with sauce every 15 minutes, until peppers are tender, about 1 hour. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: 'You have done it to me'
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: 'You have done it to me'

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I once heard a pastor say that sitting in a garage doesn't make you a car. In the same way, sitting in church doesn't make you a Christian.A Christian isn't someone who goes to church. This church is a place for us to gather; to praise and worship God; to learn about Jesus, His teachings and how we can apply these to our own lives. With that in mind, a Christian is someone who walks and talks the way of Jesus not just in church, but anywhere and everywhere.
In Matthew 25, verses 34-40, Jesus teaches us how we should treat the hungry, the thirsty, the destitute, the sick and the imprisoned, saying "What you do for the least of these, you do for Me."
He didn't specify that this should be done for fellow Hebrews, or just His followers. My friends, whatever we do for the poor, the downtrodden, the helpless, the homeless, the oppressed, the imprisoned, the stranger, we do for Jesus. He also made it clear that what we don't do for those in need, we don't do for Him.
I believe all of us will do whatever we can to help those in need. When they come to us, we are ready to assist in any way we can. Better yet, let's make the effort to seek them out. Jesus did that, too.
John Wesley made it easy to remember, saying, "Do all the good you can, by all the means you can, in all the ways you can, in all the places you can, at all the times you can, to all the people you can, for as long as you can."
After all, we're doing it to Jesus.

title: Less is more: 5 ingredient dinners are easier than you think
author: Jessica Haggard Food Drink Life
content:
Less is more: 5 ingredient dinners are easier than you think

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jessica Haggard Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1004
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From TikTok trends to Jamie Oliver's newest cookbook, minimalist cooking is extremely popular. The internet agrees: five-ingredient dinners are not only easier to cook but can be just as delicious and satisfying as more elaborate meals.Whether you're short on groceries or looking to simplify your way of cooking, mastering the art of minimalist meals is surprisingly easy. Here are tips to help you create effortless, minimal-ingredient dinners without the stress.
Build around pantry staplesStart with versatile pantry staples like pasta, rice or canned items like beans, corn or tomatoes as your base. Canned goods are not only affordable and convenient but also have a long shelf life, making them perfect for quick and easy meals.
These staples pair well with a variety of ingredients and create a solid foundation for your dish. For example, combine spaghetti, olive oil and garlic, then top with red pepper flakes and parmesan for a straightforward yet delicious pasta dish, or toss canned black beans with rice, salsa, diced avocado and shredded cheese for a quick burrito bowl.
Knoxville Backyard & Beyond 's Amanda Luhn's go-to quick meal is rice and beans. She says, "You can add almost any kind of vegetable about to go bad and make it into a stir fry with some soy sauce. Or make it a casserole-like dish with ground beef and cheese and bake it. Add chicken and some mushroom sauce and it's something else."
Utilize multi-use ingredientsOn TikTok, creators showcase a variety of quick and easy recipes that require only a few ingredients. For instance, the five-ingredient dinner with one hand trend emphasizes simplicity by using protein, vegetables and basic seasonings to craft a wholesome meal.
This approach is perfect for when you want to keep things simple and versatile in the kitchen. Opt for ingredients that can do double duty in your recipe. A rotisserie chicken can be shredded for tacos, tossed into a salad or mixed into a casserole. Humble potatoes can be turned into mashed potatoes, French fries and potato soups.
This TikTok video created by @_terriesmith shows an easy creamy ranch bowtie pasta made with chicken breasts, cream cheese, cream of chicken soup, ranch seasoning and bowtie pasta. A simple search of "five ingredient recipes chicken" on the platform will give you plenty of fun and easy ideas for using a multi-use ingredient like chicken.
Embrace prepped and packaged itemsDon't shy away from pre-cut vegetables, frozen fruits or jarred sauces to reduce prep time. For example, frozen stir-fry veggies paired with soy sauce, sesame oil, garlic and cooked shrimp can make a quick and flavorful meal. Convenience items can be a lifesaver when working with fewer ingredients.
Gena Lazcano from Ginger Casa shares, "I always keep noodles in all varieties, jarred pasta sauce, mozzarella cheese and ground beef on hand. I have three kids who love this meal each and every time, so I know I can't go wrong. It makes a quick and easy meal." These simple, go-to items make meal prep much faster while allowing you to create a delicious dish without much effort.
Use bold flavorsWith fewer ingredients, it's essential to maximize flavor. As celebrity chef Jamie Oliver shared on Good Morning America while talking about his newest cookbook, "5 Ingredients Mediterranean: Simple Incredible Food," "Keep the shopping list really low. Keep it easy. Focus on flavors and technique and really nice quick meals that you can have for breakfast, lunch or dinner."
The same philosophy applies when cooking with just a few ingredients — using fresh herbs, citrus, spices or vinegar can enhance your dishes without adding complexity. A squeeze of lemon or a sprinkle of smoked paprika can transform even the simplest meals into something memorable. Whether you're making a quick pasta or a salad, bold seasonings can improve your meal without complicating the process.
Master one-pan mealsOne-pan meals are perfect for keeping things simple and reducing cleanup, making them ideal for busy nights when you want a satisfying meal without the mess. The beauty of one-pan meals lies in their versatility — simply toss together ingredients that you have on hand then roast everything on a sheet pan. Pork chops with potatoes, carrots and onions roasted in olive oil make a filling five-ingredient dinner.
Not only does this method save time, but it also allows all the flavors to meld together as they cook. You can easily swap in different proteins and vegetables based on what you have on hand, which makes cooking easier and more flexible. The result is a hearty, satisfying dish with minimal effort and just one pan to clean. This cooking style is ideal for busy families, singles or anyone looking for a no-fuss way to prepare a wholesome family meal.
Get creative with leftoversTransforming leftovers into a fresh, new meal is a great way to reduce food waste and stretch your ingredients further. Take last night's roasted vegetables and combine them with eggs and cheese to create a quick frittata, or turn leftover rice into a delicious fried rice dish with soy sauce, scrambled eggs and frozen peas.
These simple swaps not only save time but also allow you to be creative in the kitchen, making the most out of what you already have. You can even use leftover two-ingredient salsa chicken to make a tasty stir-fry or repurpose it into wraps or sandwiches, offering endless possibilities for quick, flavorful dinners. By thinking creatively, you can easily breathe new life into leftovers and enjoy a fresh and exciting meal.
5 ingredients, zero stressCooking with just five ingredients is all about simplicity and smart choices. Cap off your dinners with desserts like three-ingredient fudge and you'll wonder how you ever cooked any other way. By building around staples, using bold flavors and embracing a little creativity, you can make delicious dinners without breaking a sweat — or your budget.
Jessica Haggard is dedicated to helping people cook easy everyday recipes focusing on bioavailable and nutrient-dense foods. She helps people overcome food allergies and discover healthy recipes that make a difference in their health with gluten-free, low-carb and keto cooking at Primal Edge Health.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: What happens when a person is born again?
author: DON REYNOLDS Calvary Baptist Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: What happens when a person is born again?

 February 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DON REYNOLDS Calvary Baptist Church | Section: Columns 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When anyone who turns from their sin and truly believes in the Lord Jesus Christ to be their Savior, that person's life truly changes. Today I would like to mention some of the things that happen.First, if a person is in Christ, he or she does not enjoy sin any more. If we love Him, we will remember that our sin is crucifying Him afresh, and then we just simply can't enjoy that sin. Yes when our Lord and Savior comes into our hearts we lose our pleasure in sin.
Secondly when a person is truly saved (born again — John 3:3) he loves the gospel of Jesus Christ. One lady stated, "I never do get tired of hearing you proclaim Jesus as Savior." It ought to be that way with every Christian.
Thirdly, if a person is in Christ, he loves to see others saved. A genuine Christian remembers that once he was lost, and he remembers the joy that came to him when he was saved. Now he wants others to have the same joy. The born-again person feels a burden for lost souls. He rejoices when others are saved.
Fourth, if a person is in Christ, he has a different attitude toward all others. A proof of a genuine follower of Christ is that a Christian must love all people. This is proof of his salvation. "By this shall men know that ye are my disciple, because ye have love one for another."
Another piece of evidence of a person who is truly born-again — he truly lives for two worlds. The person who is truly saved sees that the things of this world do not count. His life becomes one of giving living, always wanting to do for others in the name of Christ. Every bit of service rendered, every dollar contributed means that you are laying up treasure in heaven.
Jesus changed my life over 50 years ago. Yes, when He comes into one's life all things become new. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A stranger gets a proper burial
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
A stranger gets a proper burial

 March 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Considering no one present knew the departed, the modest turnout last week for a burial in a Lusby cemetery was remarkable.The Feb. 27 service at Middleham and St. Peter's Cemetery was drawn from the Book of Common Prayer, which was used often during the last quarter of the 19th century. That may have been the time when remains interred was part of a live person.
"I believe it was from somebody's private cemetery when the cliffs used to be way, way out," George Oliver told Southern Maryland News.
Oliver, who resides in Chesapeake Ranch Estates, frequently visits beach areas at the base of the cliffs, mostly in search of sharks' teeth and other fossils.
The Alabama native recalled the discovery of what turned out to be a coffin containing human remains at the edge of the Chesapeake Bay.
"I found it in November and discovered there was a skeleton in it," Oliver said. "I had been seeing it for months. It was sitting up out of the water. I just thought it was wood filled with sand."
Oliver said he contacted local law enforcement and was told of his find, "You can have it. There's nothing there."
Notifications were made to Calvert Marine Museum and the Calvert County Historical Society.
"Our parish was contacted several weeks ago by the county historic planner, Christopher Sperling," Hugh Davies, a parishioner at Middleham and St. Peter's, said. "He informed us that the county had received the remains of an unknown person and asked if they might be reinterred in the Middleham cemetery. The church had provided such a reinterment over 10 years ago."
Oliver also had been involved with that discovery.
"In 2008, we found a leg," Oliver said, adding that he had hoped the leg was missing from the remains he had found in late last year. However, remains of two legs were identified from that find.
Other information provided by the church stated the best estimate of the time of the coffin and remains is the late 19th century.
Church officials reported that a general conclusion reached is that the person "was likely a Christian" and that reinterment was needed. The Lusby church was deemed the most appropriate place for the interment, in part since Middleham Chapel is the oldest church building in Calvert County, dating back to 1684.
Pastor Erin Betz Shank, priest in charge at the parish, recited the service drawn from the Book of Common Prayer.
A white cloth bag containing the bones located within the coffin was re-placed in the coffin and attendees were invited to deposit handfuls of earth into the grave.
"We therefore commit their body to the ground, earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust," Shank recited during the service, which included the reciting of the Lord's Prayer. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it involves local elements, the focus on historical discovery and religious ceremony makes 'None of these' the most accurate classification.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season
author: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC | Section: News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Lenten season begins today, a day called Ash Wednesday.Ashes are a sign of mortality and repentance. The uses of ashes dates back to ancient Jewish tradition and often were associated with sacrifices, mourning and fasting. A person would properly express grief, humiliation and repentance sitting in ashes or placing them on the head.
At one time, during the early centuries of the church, public penitents at Rome were ceremonially admitted on this day to begin their penance.
This ceremony fell into disuse between the eighth and 10th centuries as general penance of the entire congregation began to take place. This penance was symbolized through the imposition of ashes.
Another use for ashes in the early church (second century) included a regular ceremony of public confession and penance. This use had acquired so much significance that Tertullian (a prolific early Christian author from Carthage in the Roman province of Africa) spoke of "the substitution of sackcloth and ashes for a man's usual habit."
Today, ashes symbolize the same meanings though the ceremonial customs have vanished. The one exception to this is Ash Wednesday.
The word "Lent" derives from the anglo-saxon term lencten, meaning "spring." During this time we earnestly recount all that God accomplished through the work of Jesus Christ.
We experience this period every year in the life of the church, but often, we forget, or sometimes we never knew what this time of year is about. Lent as a forty-day period of focus on penitence and preparation for the Resurrection Event of Easter. Today, we tend to observe Lent as a time of penance, by abstaining from festivals, by almsgiving, and by devoting more than the usual time to exercises of the faith. In recent years, more emphasis has been placed on these aspects than the physical fasting that marked this season in the early church.
I pray that this Lenten season would be a holy and sacred time of preparation for the celebration of the greatest day in human history; the resurrection of Jesus Christ. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses religious practices and theological reflections related to the Lenten season, which does not directly align with any of the provided topics. title: Hundreds pay their final respects to UD skaters killed in plane crash
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Hundreds pay their final respects to UD skaters killed in plane crash

 March 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 596
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hundreds gathered at the Fred Rust Ice Arena last month to pay their final respects to the five members of the University of Delaware ice skating community who died in a plane crash in January.Beloved coach Alexandr "Sasha" Kirsanov, promising young skaters Sean Kay and Angela Yang, and the kids' mothers, Julia Kay and Zheheng "Lily" Li, were among 67 people who were killed Jan. 29 when a commercial airliner collided with a military helicopter on the approach to Reagan National Airport in Washington, D.C. The Delaware victims were returning from a national skating competition in Wichita, Kansas.
At the arena Feb. 22, five caskets were placed on the ice where Kirsanov and his young students spent so much time honing their craft. Family members, friends and community members filed by them as a large screen displayed photos and videos of those lost.
Outside, the Delaware State Police Pipes and Drums Unit played a somber song as the five caskets were carried to waiting hearses. They received a police escort to Gracelawn Memorial Park near New Castle, where the families held a private burial.
The victims
Kirsanov came to the University of Delaware in the mid 1990s as a Russian junior champion. He was part of a group of Russian skaters who followed their coaches to train at UD's storied skating program, which has seen many of its skaters have success at the highest levels.
After retiring from competition, he stayed at UD and served as a coach with the High Performance Training Center and the university's collegiate skating team. He was known as a tough coach who cared deeply about the skaters he mentored.
"He brought so much love and energy to our team, filling every practice, every competition and every moment in between with passion and encouragement," Melissa Maldonado, president of UD's club figure skating team, said earlier this month. "He wasn't just invested in our skating. He was invested in us as people."
Eleven-year-old Sean Kay was outgoing and funny. His smile lit up the arena, he was always ready with a fun fact about roller coasters, and his love for the band Metallica was legendary.
Angela Yang, also 11, was quieter but sweet. She made other skaters laugh with her Snapchat messages and always dreamed big.
Both kids had trained at UD for a while but this was their first season as ice dancing partners. Both dreamed of making the Olympics, and they had won gold in a recent ice dancing competition.
The young skaters still had a lot of training to do but were on pace to be elite, according to coach Joel McKeever.
"They loved the sport," McKeever said earlier this month. "It was their lives. And you could tell it was going to be their lives for the rest of their lives."
Both Julia Kay and Lily Li worked hard to support their kids' dreams.
Kay spent her days taking Sean and his siblings to training and her nights working as a nurse to pay for costumes, travel and coaching. Yang raised Angela and two other children by herself while her husband worked overseas to support the family. She managed her own business and moved the family to Delaware to help Angela pursue her skating dreams.
"They were their biggest supporters, their strongest advocates and their greatest source of love," Maldonado said. "They dedicated so much of their time, energy and hearts to making sure their kids had every opportunity to succeed. Their love for their children was limitless. Their strength, kindness and emotion were evident in everything they did, and the bond they shared with their kids was something truly special."

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/March 14
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/March 14

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 334
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On March 14, 1879, Albert Einstein, who would revolutionize physics and the human understanding of the universe, was born in Ulm, Germany.Also on this date:
In 1794, Eli Whitney received a patent for his cotton gin, an invention that revolutionized the American cotton industry.
In 1964, a jury in Dallas found Jack Ruby guilty of murdering Lee Harvey Oswald, the accused assassin of President John F. Kennedy, and sentenced Ruby to death. (Both the conviction and death sentence were overturned, but Ruby died before he could be retried.)
In 1967, the body of President John F. Kennedy was moved from a temporary grave to a permanent memorial site at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia.
In 1973, future U.S. senator and presidential candidate John McCain was released from North Vietnamese captivity after being held as a prisoner of war for over five years.
In 1980, a LOT Polish Airlines jet crashed while attempting to land in Warsaw, killing all 87 people aboard, including 22 athletes and staff members of the U.S. boxing team.
In 2015, Robert Durst, a wealthy eccentric linked to two killings and his wife's disappearance, was arrested by the FBI in New Orleans on a murder warrant a day before HBO aired the final episode of a serial documentary about his life. (Durst would be convicted in the shooting death of his friend, Susan Berman; he died in January 2022 while serving a life sentence in California.)
In 2018, Stephen Hawking, the best-known theoretical physicist of his time, died at his home in Cambridge, England, at the age of 76 after living with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) for 55 years.
Today's Birthdays: Actor Michael Caine is 92. Country musician Michael Martin Murphey is 80. Actor-comedian Billy Crystal is 77. Country singer Kristian Bush is 55. Actor Betsy Brandt is 52. Actor Grace Park is 51. Actor Corey Stoll is 49. Actor Chris Klein is 46. Actor Jamie Bell is 39. NBA star Stephen Curry is 37. Actor Ansel Elgort is 31. Olympic gymnastics gold medalist Simone Biles is 28. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Relighting candles over the years
author: Staff Writer
content:
Relighting candles over the years

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, as I was sorting through papers I have kept over the years, I came across a letter to the editor of the Philadelphia Inquirer that I had written on March 30, 1982. Of course, I was much younger then.I had attended a peaceful protest march to Stop the Nuclear Arms Race. There were two images I particularly carried with me from that experience. I still do.
Quoting from that letter: "The first is the image of the middle of the road. With police and courteous drivers granting us the right of way, we walked literally down the middle of the roads leading from our meeting places to Independence Hall, over 15,000 people joined in a cause neither radical nor reactionary, but reasonable, logical, right and absolutely necessary."
"The second is the image of the lighted candle. In the cold night with a chill wind blowing, one has to be alert and active to keep one's candle burning. Mine went out several times, but when mine went out the candle of the person next to me seemed to stay lit. Someone's candle always re-lit mine, and I had chances to re-light others' too."
We are all older now, and the issues are surely different; however, some seem equally dangerous. The United States of America must not desert Ukraine and our allies in the free world. In my opinion that would be unprincipled, even immoral and extremely ill-advised for the sake of our own nation.
Again, quoting from the letter, "I hope and pray our political, intellectual, scientific, social and religious leaders will put their enormous energies into finding a way that will not embrace the extreme ... but will find a way for peace with justice." I believe that is what the great majority of citizens in our country want, and it is our duty to say so. As someone who sometimes finds it hard to keep one candle lit, I think I must try harder. If this letter has re-lit anyone else's candle, I am glad.
PATRICIA BRADLEY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: On Gardening: Three-part harmony container design for beginners
author: Norman Winter
content:
On Gardening: Three-part harmony container design for beginners

 March 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Norman Winter | Section: Entertainment 
 
 560
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As spring approaches at jet speed and you start thinking about planting mixed containers (but perhaps with a little fear of the partnerships) keep in mind three-part harmony. It certainly works in church music, and it is perfect for gardeners too!In the world of garden color, we call it triadic harmony. Simply put, triadic harmony is three colors spread equal distance apart on the color wheel. So in the mixed container or basket, this would be three colors of flowers to create pleasing harmony.
Rowe Farms is not only one of my favorite growers of seasonal flower color, but their Facebook page is a textbook on design ideas. Though they are in Jacksonville, a small city in east Texas, their product is found in Dallas, Fort Worth, Oklahoma City, Houston and Shreveport and locations in between.
Recently they featured some recipes that would soon be hitting garden centers. One was called Prime Time, and the other was Santa Belle. Of course, if you find ready-made baskets or planters, you've got your design creation. If you find the individual plants for sale you can copy the recipe. But Prime Time and Santa Belle, though created with different plants, have one thing the same, and that is color. They each have red, blue and yellow in a perfect triadic or three-part harmony.
The PrimeTime recipe features three Supertunia Mini Vista petunias, Yellow, Indigo and Scarlet that will dazzle all summer. Superbells Grape Punch, Pomegranate Punch and Yellow calibrachoas could have accomplished a similar look or recipe. This is what the Santa Belle recipe did but using Laguna Dark Blue lobelia, Superbells Yellow calibrachoa and Superbena Scarlet Eye verbena.
The red, blue and yellow scheme is one of the easiest for gardeners to put together. I used Superbena Violet Ice verbena, Supertunia Mini Vista Scarlet petunia and Superbells Yellow calibrachoa. Triadic harmony with red, blue and yellow delivers a lot of dazzle in quick and easy fashion.
Last spring I did another container with some of this year's new flowers, Virtuoso Classy Carmine dahlia, Stardiva Blue scaevola and Supertunia Saffron Finch petunia with cheerful yellow flowers. The colors were perfect!
If you have noticed, the rules in triadic harmony, particularly when using flowers, are not exacting or mandatory in color, but approximations. Some of our blues were violets and indigo, and even Superbells Grape Punch is purple with blackeye but looks blue throughout the day with changing light angles.
Always remember substitutes are allowed. One of my favorite containers from a couple of years ago featured Superbells Grape Punch calibrachoa, Supertunia Mini Vista Scarlet petunia and since I did not have a yellow flower available, I used Snow Princess sweet alyssum with white flowers as the perfect substitute. They say white is the absence of color, but I am not sure I buy that when it comes to flowers.
Red, blue and yellow is like harmony for beginners. Look at color wheels online and pick out your favorite color. Then you can see which colors are equal distances apart. I like orange so one of its colors is green, which of course will come from leaves.
You may have heard an old saying that close only works with horseshoes and hand grenades, but I assure you it works in picking harmonious flower colors too.
Start planning for spring and follow me on my Facebook page @NormanWinterTheGardenGuy for more photos and garden inspiration.

title: Telling the truth matters
author: Staff Writer
content:
Telling the truth matters

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words

 Telling the truth matters. When people share accurate information, our community stays safe.The Dorchester County Republican Central Committee recently said protesters were being brought here on buses. That is not accurate. While some protesters come from other counties, most are local. They live here in Dorchester, mostly from Cambridge, which is a Democratic stronghold, or nearby places like Worcester and Talbot counties. They are Andy Harris's constituents, just like you.
Even more troubling are claims about threats of violence. No proof has been shown to support these claims. Sharing information that isn't true creates fear. This can hurt our community.
Everyone in Dorchester County deserves to feel safe. Democrats and Republicans alike have the right to peacefully speak and protest without fear. Telling the truth matters. It protects us all.
SYDNEY BRADNER-JACOBS

title: COUNTRY COOKING: Hamburger favorite recipes
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
COUNTRY COOKING: Hamburger favorite recipes

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After a cold snowy winter, we are ready for that extra hour of daylight and warmer temperatures. Everyone is already talking about the yard work and clean-up that needs to be done. This brings back those memories of my childhood on the farm.We would go out on a spring Saturday morning to do yard and farm work for the day. My mother, my sister and I did the yard work around the house, and my dad and brothers did the barnyard and ditch banks close to the house and barn.
The fields were eventually spread with manure later during the week by the farmhands. Oh, what a lovely spring cleaning smell that was.
Since we lived out in the country, we were used to it, but boy, those town kids on that school bus that came to the country were not.
I decided to make the recipes this week using ground beef, and I remembered the farmer my father bought our beef from. We raised our own pork but bought our beef.
Raising beef began with a small herd of cows who gave birth once a year to calves. We had one milk cow, and that was enough to do with all the chickens, hogs, ducks and geese we had. The cattle needed lots of grazing fields, and we had a small pasture.
Ground beef was always popular with the cooks as you could make so many different dishes. When you are looking for the tastiest, cheapest, fastest meals, ground beef is number one.
It is very versatile, quick cooking and great for when you have a crowd to feed. Keep some burger on hand to make those classic dishes like meatloaf, burgers, barbecue meatballs, tater tot casserole, goulash, tacos and taco bake, stuffed peppers, chili, sloppy joe's, shepherd pie and much more. Let's get started.
STUFFED PEPPERS
6 medium green bell peppers (tops and seeds removed), 2 tbsps vegetable oil, 1 large onion (finely chopped), Kosher salt, 1 pound ground beef, 2 large cloves garlic (finely chopped), freshly ground black pepper, 1 28-oz can diced fire-roasted tomatoes, 2 cups cooked rice, 1 cup loosely packed fresh parsley leaves (roughly chopped), 1 1/2 cups shredded mozzarella, 1/2 cup plain dry breadcrumbs, 2 large eggs (lightly beaten), 4 tsps Worcestershire sauce.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Add about 2 inches of water to a large pot fitted with a steamer insert, and bring to a high simmer. Arrange the peppers in the steamer, cover the pot and cook, rotating the peppers as needed, until they are very tender and pliable, about 25 minutes. Remove the peppers with a slotted spoon and drain upside-down on paper towels. Put the oil, onions and a pinch of salt in a large skillet over medium heat, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the onions are soft and translucent, about 8 minutes. Raise the heat to medium-high. Add the beef, garlic, 2 tsps salt and a few grinds of pepper, and cook, stirring and breaking the beef up, until browned and mostly cooked through, about 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes, bring to a simmer, then remove from the heat. Let cool in the skillet for at least 10 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl, add the rice, parsley, 1 cup of the mozzarella, breadcrumbs, eggs and Worcestershire and mix to combine. Stand the peppers up in a 9-by-13-inch baking dish. If they fall over, cut away a little of the bottoms (without cutting through the pepper) to make a flat surface. Generously fill and pack the peppers with the meat-rice mixture. Top with the remaining 1/2 cup mozzarella. Add just enough water to the pan to cover the bottom to help steam the peppers. Loosely cover with foil, and bake until the peppers are tender and the filling is heated through, about 30 minutes. Remove the foil, and continue to bake for 10 minutes more. Traditionally people use green peppers, but you can use any of the colors available.
HAMBURGER STEAKS WITH GRAVY
Hamburger Steaks: 1/2 tsp ground mustard, 1/2 tsp smoked paprika, 1 large egg, 1 clove garlic (minced), salt and freshly ground black pepper, 1 pound ground beef (80/20 works the best), 2 tbsps breadcrumbs, 1 tbsp vegetable oil.
Onion and Mushroom Gravy: 10 ounces baby bella mushrooms (sliced), 2 sprigs thyme (leaves picked and stems discarded), 3 tbsps unsalted butter, 1 small onion (thinly sliced), 1 clove garlic (sliced), 3 tbsps all-purpose flour, 2 cups low-sodium beef broth (hot), 2 tsps Worcestershire sauce, 2 tbsps fresh parsley (roughly chopped).
For the hamburger steaks: Whisk together the mustard, smoked paprika, egg, garlic, 1 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp pepper in a medium mixing bowl. Mix in the ground beef and breadcrumbs by hand, then form into 4 oval patties, about 1/2 inch thick. Set a large nonstick pan over medium-high heat and add the oil. Add the patties and brown on both sides, about 3 minutes per side. Transfer the patties to a plate; set aside. For the onion and mushroom gravy: Turn the heat down to medium and add the mushrooms and thyme. Cook until the mushrooms release their liquid and are browned, about 8 minutes. (The mushrooms might seem dry at first, but will eventually release liquid and add moisture to the pan.) Transfer the mushrooms to a plate; set aside. Melt the butter in the pan, add the onions and garlic and cook until translucent and lightly golden, about 10 minutes. Sprinkle in the flour and cook, stirring, until the butter and liquid are absorbed, about 1 minute. Pour the broth and Worcestershire into the pan and stir until the flour is dissolved. Turn the heat to high and bring to a boil. Stir the mushrooms back into the pan and nestle in the beef patties. Cover with a lid and reduce the heat to medium low. Let simmer until the sauce has thickened and a thermometer inserted into the patties registers 165 degrees, about 10 minutes. Turn the patties over a few times to coat in the sauce. Season with salt and pepper and top with the parsley.
WESTLINE MEATLOAF
1 tsp dry mustard, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp pepper, 1 pound ground beef, 1/2 onion (finely chopped), 1 egg, 2 tsps Worcestershire sauce, 1 cup breadcrumbs, 1 cup ketchup.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a small bowl, mix together the horseradish, mustard, salt and pepper. Set aside. In a large bowl, mix ground beef, onion, egg and Worcestershire sauce. Add the contents of a small bowl and mix thoroughly. Add the breadcrumbs and combine well. Place mixture into a 1-pound loaf pan. Pour ketchup over top and place in the oven. Bake uncovered for 45 to 60 minutes.
HAMBURGER or CHEESEBURGER
1 large egg,½ tsp salt, ½ tsp ground black pepper, 1 pound ground beef, ½ cup fine dry breadcrumbs.
Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat and lightly oil the grate. Whisk egg, salt, and pepper together in a medium bowl. Add ground beef and breadcrumbs; mix with your hands or a fork until well blended. Form into four 3/4-inch-thick patties. Place patties on the preheated grill. Cover and cook for 6 to 8 minutes per side, or to desired doneness. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 160 degrees. If you are going to use cheese, this is the time you'd lay a slice on top so it starts to melt as the burger cooks. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: 'You, oh Lord, are God of all'
author: PHYLLIS DUCKERY
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: 'You, oh Lord, are God of all'

 March 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHYLLIS DUCKERY | Section: Columns 
 
 368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Spring is slowly and beautifully making its entrance day by day. It brings with it a new birth and freshness we all seem to need after this winter's cold and snow.The days get longer, the temperature rises, the tulips break through the earth, singing a song of praise, the soil is being prepared for the planting of fresh crops. New life is unfolding before us each day. There seems to be joy and a sigh of relief that says moving forward.
This is also the Lenten season, where we as Christians remember and observe the 40 days Jesus spent fasting in the desert before his ministry began. He was challenged and tempted by Satan but endured it all so he could be Our Lord, Our God of all.
This is a special and hollowed time leading to Resurrection Sunday. We prepare our hearts through prayer and fasting to celebrate the victory given to all mankind at the blood-stained cross of Calvary.
King David prayed in Psalm 51 that the Lord would purge and wash him, to blot out his sin and renew a right spirit within him. This should be the daily prayer and cry from all mankind, especially during the Lenten season.
Lord make me, make us pure, clean and Holy in your sight. We are all children of God created in his wonderful image, called to sing and show forth his praises and glory.
We occupy a world that is torn and broken by the hands and minds of man. Because of this our families, communities and even our churches are experiencing brokenness and collapse. Fear not, I can assure you today that we serve a God who is over it all and will get the Glory. Praise God.
As we seek his face, seek his wisdom, repent and turn from every weight and besetting sin, we will see his hand and power during this Lenten season. Just make it all about Jesus, the one who can fix it, the one who is faithful and true. This only comes through prayer and fasting.
All our need, the Lord will supply. Help us, Lord Jesus, during this Lenten season to acknowledge you and receive you afresh and anew. God's blessings upon you all.

title: We must keep interest on civil, respectful dialog
author: DAVID REEL
content:
We must keep interest on civil, respectful dialog

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 848
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Following World War II, Winston Churchill was facing two daunting political and governing challenges in pivoting from serving as a wartime to a post war leader of Britain.The first challenge was how Britain should deal with Germany, whose leaders were ruthless adversaries who inflicted massive amounts of death, pain and suffering on Britain during a six-year war; including bombing raids on London that killed and injured innocent civilians. The second challenge was how Britain should deal with the Soviet Union whose leaders were key allies during that same war, but post war; those same leaders were pursuing, maintaining and expanding the Soviet Union's spheres of influence and their communist ideology worldwide.
Churchill's guiding principle forward was pragmatic. In a world characterized by volatility, uncertainty, complexity and ambiguity, he would not expect permanent allies or permanent adversaries. He would pursue permanent interests.
Recently, two U.S. senators from Pennsylvania embraced Churchill's guiding principle in American politics in a relatively small, but very instructive way. What makes this instructive is these two senators have deeply held and stark differences in their political allegiances and political philosophies.
John Fetterman is a left-of-center Democratic senator who was endorsed by Bernie Sanders in his successful Senate primary election campaign and his successful general election campaign.
In the 2024 Presidential election, Fetterman strongly supported Joe Biden's reelection and strongly defended Biden when there were widespread calls for him to withdraw from the race.
When Biden did withdraw and was replaced by Kamala Harris as the Democratic standard bearer, Fetterman endorsed her and campaigned for her throughout Pennsylvania.
David McCormick is a right-of-center Republican senator who was endorsed by Donald Trump in his successful Senate primary campaign and his successful general election campaign.
In McCormick's challenge to Pennsylvania's then incumbent left-of-center Democratic Sen. Robert Casey, Fetterman endorsed Casey and campaigned for him.
Since those elections, their differences have not stopped the two senators from working together on select issues of shared interest, shared thinking and mutual respect.
One example is the role of mentorships in changing lives.
Both McCormick and Fetterman have a deep commitment to mentoring based on their respective firsthand experiences.
While in college, Fetterman's best friend died in a car accident. Immediately following that tragedy, Fetterman volunteered to be a mentor for Big Brothers and Big Sisters of America. He was assigned to an 8-year-old boy whose father had died from AIDS and whose mother was dying from cancer. Fetterman promised the boy's mother he would continue to be his mentor after her death.
In high school, McCormick was a mediocre benchwarmer on the football team. A new coach saw promise in him, mentored him and made McCormick one of the team's co-captains. That experience helped McCormick boost his low self-confidence and graduate from West Point.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, McCormick and his wife, Dina Powell McCormick, concluded that too many Americans, including their six daughters, suffered greatly from a lack of mentors.
As a result, they coauthored "Who Believed in You?" a book that includes interviews with successful leaders who had a mentor who saw something in them they may not have seen in themselves and helped them find and achieve their purpose in life.
Those interviewed include Gov. Wes Moore; Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella; Tory Burch, chief creative fashion designer and executive chairperson of Tory Burch LLC as well as founder of the Tory Burch foundation; Hollywood producer Brian Grazer, Arkansas Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders and former U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.
As a result of their mutual appreciation of the value of mentoring, McCormick, Fetterman, and their spouses (both of whom also have personal positive mentoring stories to share), agreed to three events where they would discuss their experiences and promote Who Believed in You?
McCormick, Fetterman and their spouses also met for a dinner, a most effective way for people to get to know, understand and respect each other. Following that dinner McCormick said, "I trust him. I think he's a very authentic guy. I think he's going to be a good partner."
Sadly, the first two of the mentoring events were postponed due to "unforeseen logistical issues" and the third event was canceled due to a "scheduling conflict." I believe the reasons were concerns over peaceful outcomes from protests before, during or after the events.
This is a prime example of how a tyranny of the loud is regularly disrupting much needed efforts to advance the cause of civil political discourse in our society.
This unexpected turn of events is also a call to action for elected officials and citizens in our community, our region, our state and our country to commit to doing two things.
We can, and we must replicate the actions of two these U.S. senators with efforts to get to know, understand, trust, respect and seek common ground with others who have opposite political affiliations and opposite views on many local, state and national public policy issues.
More importantly, we can, and we must commit to maintaining a permanent interest on civil and respectful dialogue, which will help us coexist in a society where even when we have inevitable disagreements on a wide range of public policy issues, we can disagree without being disagreeable.

title: For many Social Security is their sole income
author: LENA GILL
content:
For many Social Security is their sole income

 April 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 678
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Frances Perkins, the famous female labor secretary appointed by President Franklin Roosevelt, chaired the committee that drafted legislation for Social Security, enacted in 1935.It was a reliable insurance system for all working Americans. If you paid into it monthly, you knew that if you lost your job, became disabled or died, you or your survivors would receive a pension based on how much you paid in. Before that, the consequence was often destitution. As of February 2025, an estimated 73.2 million Americans received Social Security checks. In Talbot County, 30% of residents rely on Social Security benefits for income. For nearly half of them, it is their sole income.
Social Security is so popular it is considered a "third rail of politics" because politicians dare not vote to reduce benefits, as they and their party will face certain defeat in the next election. Most Republicans and President Trump pledged before the election not to reduce Social Security benefits.
Instead, Trump brought in his front man, Elon Musk and his DOGE musketeers to eviscerate Social Security, not by reducing benefits, but by slashing workers and field offices that make the program administrable. They suggest staff cutbacks of 7,000 persons, out of today's staff of 57,000 that is already considered insufficient. The ratio of one staffer to 1,369 beneficiaries is twice the ratio in 1995. The average processing time of disability claims has already doubled from four to eight months.
Musk's approach avoids Republicans in Congress voting on the evisceration. Perhaps Musk will then sell Social Security to the highest bidder who will privatize it, promising to make it function again. (At the end of 2024, the two Social Security trust funds held approximately $2.027 trillion in asset reserves. These reserves are owned by the beneficiaries of the Social Security program.)
What have the DOGE musketeers accomplished so far?
Several people who are quite alive were declared dead and their benefits terminated. For example, Ned Johnson, an 82-year-old retiree from Seattle not only discovered his Social Security checks stopped, but more than $5,000 of his prior benefits were clawed back as he allegedly died on November 23, 2024. He waited for eight hours at the Seattle Social Security office to prove that he was still alive. That same office is now earmarked for closure. Earlier, Trump fired the inspector general who would have investigated and avoided such mistakes. DOGE musketeers also claimed to have found $232 million in waste to cut from Social Security. Closer examination changed that to $560,000.
Elon installed one of his musketeers, Leland Dudek, as acting commissioner. In response to a lawsuit, a judge forbade the DOGE musketeers from accessing sensitive taxpayer data. Dudek then threatened to bar Social Security employees from accessing Social Security systems. The next day Dudek backed down and let the employees resume their normal work.
Which field offices will be closed is still not decided. There were protests around the country outside field offices last weekend, and the public was very vocal about keeping their local Social Security offices open. The phone lines available for the elderly and disabled to discuss their claims are already shut down. People are told to do much of their business online. However, it is believed that about 10% of people over 65 are not computer literate. A new claimant must appear in person at a remaining office alive.
For those who rely on the check from Social Security to pay for the essentials every month, failure to receive it is an emergency. I encourage everybody to call or email Sens. Chris van Hollen and Angela Alsobrooks, as well as Congressman Andy Harris to tell them to stop the plunder of the Social Security insurance program.
On June 1, 1950, Sen. Margaret Chase Smith of Maine stood up in the Senate chamber during a debate on Sen. Joseph McCarthy's claims of unidentified traitors in our government and said: "It is high time we all stopped being tools and victims of totalitarian techniques — techniques that, if continued here unchecked, will surely end what we have come to cherish as the American way of life."

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Effective prayers
author: GREGORY E. BLACKSTON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Effective prayers

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GREGORY E. BLACKSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 229
 Words 

 Read News Document

 James 5:16-18 NKJV reads, "Confess your trespasses to one another, and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much. Elijah was a man with a nature like ours, and he prayed earnestly that it would not rain; and it did not rain on the land for three years and six months. And he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth produced its fruit."This passage of scripture reveals to us that none of mankind is without fault.
Romans 3:23 NKJV reads, "For all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God. James 5:16 tells us that if we are able to (1.) acknowledge our wrong to one another, (2.) and pray for one another agreeing in the name of Jesus than we can be healed."
This passage of scripture reveals the power of confession to us.
I John 1:9 says, "If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness."
The scriptures state the effective, fervent prayer of a righteous man avails much. In verse 17, the word of God confirms that Elijah was a human just like you and I. He prayed for rain and for it to stop, and God honored his prayer.
Men and women of God, know that your prayers produce results.

title: Speak up or you may lose your guaranteed rights
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Speak up or you may lose your guaranteed rights

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 345
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first 10 amendments to the Constitution are known as the Bill of Rights. These rights apply to everyone in the United States including citizens, and with few exceptions, to non-citizens and legal residents. The First Amendment grants freedom of religion, press, assembly and petition. The fourth amendment protects against illegal searches, seizures and requires warrants.We now know that these rights are being violated by the Trump administration at an alarming frequency.
Perhaps you read about the student at Columbia University, a legal permanent resident who has been arrested and detained, apparently without due process, for leading protests about the situation in Gaza. He has been sent to a detention center in Louisiana.
Also recently arrested without due process of law is Kilmar Abrego Garcia, a Maryland resident. In a recent administrative error, Mr. Garcia was deported to a prison in El Salvador, despite a 2019 court order stating that deporting him to El Salvador could result in his harm or death from gangs there. Mr Garcia has no criminal record in the United States. The Supreme Court has decreed that the United States must correct its error and facilitate his return to the United States. The Trump administration denies having any responsibility to correct this error and states that the courts have no right to require the correction, and in short, it is none of their business.
These two cases are headlines but clear violations of the Bill of Rights. There are many more outrageous violations of our rights are occurring daily.
Our rights are under attack. The president is interpreting the Bill of Rights to align with his own objectives.
We should all fear for ourselves. It is not hard to imagine that U.S. citizens and legal residents may be ensnared in efforts to deport or detain anyone who does not agree with the president. Mr. Trump has already expressed a wish to overturn the 14th Amendment, which grants citizenship to anyone born in the United States.
We all need to resist attacks on the rights that our Constitution grants us. Speak up or you may lose them. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on constitutional rights, government overreach, and legal violations by the Trump administration, which does not align with any specific topic in the list. While 'National News' could marginally apply, the content is primarily an opinion piece about civil liberties and legal issues rather than factual news reporting.

title: Country Cooking: Fresh asparagus
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Fresh asparagus

 April 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fresh asparagus is a sure sign that spring has arrived.My mom did not plant asparagus, as not many in the family liked this vegetable. Years later, when I had a garden of my own, I learned how to grow asparagus that would continue coming back each year for at least 18 to 20 years.
Some rules I learned were to find a space in the garden that had direct sunshine for at least six hours each day. This spot also needs to be well-drained with rich, deep soil. I added compost to ensure the soil was rich and lots of it to have a nice tall row.
A very important factor: do not plant onions, potatoes, garlic, leeks, shallots or beans near the asparagus, as they seek the sun and overpower with growth to overcome the asparagus sprouts. Properly planted, this delicious vegetable produces many sprouts.
One of my first recipes was fried asparagus, given to me by a true southern lady, Ms. Lillie Mae. She has been gone for many years, but the recipe lives on with me.
FRIED ASPARAGUS
Prepare about a pound of fresh cut asparagus for cooking. In a skillet over medium heat melt 1/2 cup butter, add 2 tbsps olive oil, 1 tsp coarse salt and 3 minced garlic cloves. Stir and cook until the garlic is strongly fragrant. Place asparagus stalks in the pan and continue cooking and turning with a fork until tender. Drain on paper towels and serve warm.
ASPARAGUS CASSEROLE
This goes great with baked ham. In a buttered casserole dish, place a layer of asparagus, then a layer of crumbled cheese nips crackers. Wet with cream of mushroom soup mixed with water according to directions on the can. Finish the casserole with a few more crushed cheese nips. Bake in a 350-degree oven until asparagus is tender.
ROASTED ASPARAGUS
1 large bunch fresh asparagus, 1 to 2 tsps olive oil, salt, freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees and line a large, rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper for easy cleanup. Cut off the woody ends of the asparagus, usually about an inch or so is taken off. Place the asparagus on the sheet and drizzle with olive oil, just enough to lightly coat. Sprinkle salt and pepper over the asparagus and toss until the spears are lightly coated in oil. Arrange the spears in a single layer on the pan. Thin asparagus will take as little as nine to 12 minutes, whereas thicker asparagus will need 15 to 20 minutes. Roasted asparagus is best served when it's fresh out of the oven, but it will keep at room temperature for up to one hour or up to two days in the refrigerator.
ASPARAGUS FRITTATA WITH HAM, SPINACH AND CHEESE
6 eggs, kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, 4 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 4 stalks asparagus (sliced on a into 1-inch pieces), 1 green bell pepper (diced), 1/2 medium red onion (sliced), 3 medium cloves garlic (sliced), 1 cup packed spinach leaves (roughly chopped), 3 ounces sliced ham (cut into 1/2-inch pieces), 4 ounces medium-firm cheese such as cheddar or Jack (cut into 1/2-inch cubes).
Lightly beat eggs with a large pinch of salt and a few grinds of black pepper in a large bowl. Set aside. Heat 1 tbsp olive oil in a 10-inch nonstick, cast iron or carbon steel skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add asparagus and peppers, season with salt and pepper, and cook, tossing and stirring frequently, until asparagus is tender-crisp, about two minutes. Transfer to the bowl with the eggs. Heat 1 tbsp oil in the now-empty skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions and cook, stirring, until starting to brown around the edges, about two minutes. Add garlic and cook, stirring, until onions and garlic are lightly browned, about a minute longer. Add spinach and cook, stirring, until wilted, about a minute. Transfer to the bowl with the eggs. Add ham (if using) and cheese to the eggs and stir the mixture until everything is evenly combined. Wipe out the skillet. Add remaining 2 tbsps oil to skillet and set over medium-high heat until shimmering. Scrape egg mixture into skillet and cook, swirling and shaking pan rapidly, until bottom and sides begin to set, about three minutes. Using a heat proof spatula, press the edges in to begin to form the frittata's puck shape. Continue to cook, adjusting heat to prevent bottom of frittata from burning, until beginning to set around edges, about three minutes longer. Working over a sink or garbage can, place a large overturned flat plate or lid on top of skillet, set hand on top (using a dish towel if you are sensitive to heat), and, in one very quick motion, invert frittata onto it. Carefully slide the frittata back into the skillet and continue to cook until the second side is beginning to firm up, about two minutes. Use a rubber spatula to again press the sides all around to form a rounded puck shape. Continue to cook the frittata until lightly browned on the second side but still tender in the center when pressed with a finger, about two minutes longer. If desired, you can flip frittata two to three more times during these last minutes of cooking, which helps to cook the center more evenly and reinforce the shape. Carefully slide frittata out of the skillet onto a clean plate and serve.
CHEESY BAKED ASPARAGUS
1 bunch of asparagus, 3/4 cup mozzarella (shredded), 1/4 cup parmesan (finely grated), 2 cloves of garlic (minced/finely diced), 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/4 tsp salt, 1/8 tsp black pepper.
Trim the woody parts of your asparagus and toss will 1 tbsp olive oil, garlic cloves, salt and pepper. Lay out flat on a baking tray. Place in the oven at 390 degrees for eight to 10 minutes, or until it just starts to wrinkle and soften. Take out the oven, sprinkle over mozzarella then top with parmesan. Put back in the oven and broil until the cheese turn golden and bubbly, with the asparagus fork tender. Serve up right away.
LEMON ASPARAGUS SALAD
1 pound penne pasta, 1 pound thin asparagus (trimmed and cut into 2-inch pieces), 3 tbsps extra-virgin olive oil, 1 small onion (diced), 2 cloves garlic (thinly sliced), 1/2 cup heavy cream, 1 lemon (zested and juiced), 1 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 cup freshly grated parmesan plus more for serving, 1/2 tsp freshly ground black pepper plus more for serving, 1/4 cup fresh parsley (finely chopped), 1/2 tsp crushed red pepper flakes.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add penne and cook according to package directions until al dente. Reserve ½ cup pasta water, then drain. Set aside. Meanwhile, in a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat 1 tbsp of oil. Cook asparagus until crispy, then season with a pinch of salt. Transfer to a plate and set aside. Heat remaining 2 tbsps of oil over medium heat. Cook onions and garlic until softened, about five minutes. Add heavy cream, lemon juice and zest. Bring mixture to a boil, then simmer for five minutes. Add in salt, parmesan and black pepper. Reduce heat to low and mix until well combined. Turn off heat and mix in pasta, asparagus, and parsley until well coated. Add small amounts of pasta water until you reach desired consistency. Serve with more grated parmesan, cracked black pepper and red pepper flakes.

title: Country Cooking: The other side of the barnyard
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: The other side of the barnyard

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1187
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Driving down the country road to the farm, I realized that you always see one side of the barnyard as you turn into the driveway.This is the side where the water trough sits, and the feed containers are placed on metal tracks. The cows and hogs hang out here waiting to be fed. The corn cribs and the smokehouse are nearby.
On the other side of the barn is the area where the pony and goats hang out. At one time, we had a small lamb that we cared for while its owner was away. The goats would constantly get out and wander down to neighboring farms — eating everything in sight. They soon found new homes.
The Easter holiday is over, but I have some ham and lamb recipes I want to share with you. What was on your table for Easter dinner last week? For most, ham rates number one, with lamb, beef, seafood, turkey and chicken as other choices.
I know many families opt for lamb, but even though I know it is a very healthy choice, I just can't cook or eat lamb. Lamb meat comes from the young lambs and is a very rich source of iron, high quality of protein, zinc and vitamin B12.
I will include a lamb recipe today for those who like lamb. My mom always prepared the tastiest hams but only once or twice ever cooked lamb — probably because the children refused to eat it.
This past week I purchased a small ham — on sale — and decided to cook it instead of freezing it. It was delicious.
Ham and lamb can be eaten at any time of the year.
BONE IN BAKED HAM
This ham recipe comes from my kitchen. I have used it for many years. I purchase one whole bone-in ham, about 15 pounds and trim off any excess fat.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a mixing bowl combine one-pound brown sugar and 1/2 cup yellow mustard, mixing until you have a thick paste. Line a baking pan with foil, making sure the foil is long enough to fold over covering ham completely. Spray foil with cooking spray just in case the brown sugar mixture escapes from the foil. Place the ham on the foil and spread with sugar-mustard paste on top. Fold and seal foil. Keep ham sealed until cooking is complete — Bake for 4 hours. Check for doneness and let sit, covered, for another hour. Carve and serve.
NOTE: the ham bone will be great after Easter for seasoning in a pot of bean soup or ham and cabbage.
PINEAPPLE HAM
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Use a 8 to 10-pound ham and score the top in a diamond-shape, making the cuts half an inch deep. Place ham in a roasting pan. Mix together 3 cups brown sugar with 3 tablespoons yellow mustard, mixing until smooth and spooning onto top of ham. Mix together the juice from an 8-ounce can of pineapple rings and 1 cup honey. Drizzle this mixture over the ham and brown sugar paste. Place the pineapple rings on top of the ham and secure with wooden toothpicks. Cover and place in the preheated oven. After 15 minutes, remove the cover (foil or a lid) and baste with pan drippings, doing this several times until the scouring marks have opened, letting the juices seep into the meat. Continue baking until ham is well done according to size of ham (see package directions).
LEG OF LAMB
4 to 5-pound leg of lamb (bone-in, fat trimmed), salt and pepper, extra virgin olive oil, 5 garlic cloves (peeled and sliced), 2 cups water, 8 gold potatoes (peeled and cut into wedges), 1 yellow onion (peeled and cut into wedges), 1 teaspoon paprika,1 teaspoon all-natural garlic powder, fresh parsley for garnish (optional). For the rub: 15 garlic cloves (peeled), 2 tablespoons dried oregano, 2 tablespoons dried mint flakes, 1 tablespoon paprika, 1/2 tablespoons nutmeg, 1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil, juice of 2 lemons.
Take the leg of lamb out of the refrigerator and leave in room temperature for about 1 hour. In the meantime, prepare the remaining ingredients and make the lamb rub. Prepare the seasoning.
To make the rub or seasoning, in a food processor, combine the rub ingredients. Blend until smooth. Set aside (or in the fridge, if preparing in advance). Salt the meat. When ready, pat the lamb dry and make a few slits on both sides. Season with salt and pepper. Sear the Lamb. Turn the oven on broil. Place the leg of lamb on a wire rack and put it directly on the top rack so that it's only a few inches away from the broiler element. Broil for 5 to 7 minutes on each side or until the leg of lamb is nicely seared. Remove from the oven, then adjust the oven temperature to 325 degrees. Apply the seasoning or rub. When the lamb is cool enough to handle, insert the garlic slices in the slits you made earlier. Now cover the leg of lamb on all sides with the wet rub and place it in the middle of a roasting pan with an inside rack. Add two cups of water to the bottom of the roasting pan. Season the potato and onion wedges with paprika, garlic powder and a little salt, then add them to the pan on either side of the lamb. Cover and roast. Tent a large piece of foil over the roasting pan (make sure it does not touch the lamb) then place the pan on the middle rack of the 325-degree oven. Roasted for about 1 hour. Remove the foil and return the roasting pan to the oven for another 15 to 20 minutes or until the lamb temperature registers 125 degrees. Let rest. Remove the pan from the oven and let the leg of lamb rest for about 15 to 20 minutes before serving (the lamb will continue to cook, and its internal temperature will continue to rise to around 130 degrees).Place the roast lamb and potatoes in a large serving platter over a bed of rice, you like. Garnish with parsley. Or you may carve the lamb first, then arrange the sliced lamb with the potatoes over the rice.
BAKED PINEAPPLE
Multiple generations love this side dish. My son John will eat this even as a dessert or breakfast dish. It goes perfect with any of these recipes today.
One 20-ounce can of crushed pineapple including juice, ¾ cup granulated sugar, 2 large eggs, 2 tablespoons cornstarch, 2 teaspoons vanilla extract, 1 ½ tablespoons butter (divided into small pats), 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon.
Preheat your oven to 350 degrees. Lightly grease a 9-by-9-inch baking pan to prevent sticking. In a mixing bowl, add the crushed pineapple (with its juice), granulated sugar, eggs, cornstarch and vanilla extract. Stir until the mixture is smooth. Transfer the pineapple mixture into a greased baking pan. Evenly distribute the small pats of butter across the surface of the mixture, then sprinkle with ground cinnamon to enhance flavor. Bake for 45 minutes, or until the mixture begins to exhibit a golden hue perfectly caramelized. Let cool and serve.
