title: APG Media of Chesapeake wins 30 press association awards
author: Wendy Weitzel
content:
APG Media of Chesapeake wins 30 press association awards

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Wendy Weitzel | Section: Local News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — News organizations across the region were recognized with awards for work they produced over the past year. The editorial staff of APG Media of Chesapeake garnered 30 awards in 20 categories.The awards were announced during the Maryland-Delaware-DC Press Association's annual ceremony Friday, May 9, in Annapolis. The association represents over 100 member news media organizations in the region. The contest recognizes the best print and online work completed in 2024.
The contest, governed by the MDDC's editorial and advertising committees, is split into seven divisions, which group member publications into daily and non-daily print and online-only categories, then further group them by circulation. The entries were judged by news media professionals from Washington State's press association.
The Star Democrat took home a total of six awards in Division D.
Reporter Maggie Trovato and Managing Editor Wendy Weitzel took home first place in the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion category. Trovato also had second place wins in the Religion and Investigative Reporting categories. Reporter Tom McCall won the top prize for Breaking News Photo, as well as the second-place prize for a non-profile feature story. Sports Editor William Haufe took the top prize in the sports photo category.
In Division D, the Cecil Whig's Carl Hamilton won the Local Column, Feature category and reporter Jane Bellmyer took second place in the Business Reporting category.
The Whig's Patrick LaPorte came in second place in the Sports Story category. Southern Maryland News' Ted Black won the top prize in that category. Black also took home the second-place sports video prize.
The Southern Maryland News team took home seven other awards in Division D.
Reporter Mike Reid took home second place wins in the Feature Photo; Diversity, Equity and Inclusion; and Growth and Land Use Reporting categories. Reid took home first place in the General News Photo and Headline categories and went on to win best of show for General News Photo.
Reporter Matt Wynn won the Feature Video category.
Southern Maryland News also took home first place in the News-Driven Special Section category for its 150th anniversary edition.
The "Our Bridge Heritage" special section, produced by The Avenue News' Demetrius Dillard and The Dundalk Eagle's Olivia Barry, took home the second place prize in that category in Division F. Dillard also won the Business Reporting category.
Also in Division F, The Newark Post's editor, Josh Shannon, won first place in the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion category and the Investigative Reporting category. He got second place in the Continuing Coverage category. Jon Buzby took home first place in the Sports Feature Story category for The Newark Post.
Kent County News' Will Bontrager took home five awards in Division F. He won the top prize in the Feature Photo, Sports Feature Story, Local Government, and Arts and Entertainment categories. He got second place in the Feature, Non-Profile category.
"I am so proud of the work (Executive Editor) Jim Johnson and all the newsrooms have produced," said APG Chesapeake Regional President Orestes Baez. "They have done a masterful job creating content and producing engaging products. I am so happy they are receiving so much well deserved recognition. Just fantastic." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Just the facts, please

content:
Just the facts, please

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 I have always been puzzled by a newspaper offering an endorsement of a particular political candidate.Since the paper is a thing, shouldn't it read the management/owners of the Washpost, Stardem, etc. are endorsing Candidate X?
Furthermore is it ethical for the paper to tell us how to vote, however subliminally the message is delivered?

title: Country Cooking: Strawberry patches, fields, recipes and memories
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Strawberry patches, fields, recipes and memories

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When I was standing at my kitchen sink this afternoon washing, capping and slicing several small baskets of freshly picked strawberries, I had flashback memories of Mom doing this chore many years ago.The only difference was Mom had a large strawberry patch at one side of our garden, and my berries came from the local market.
Early in their farm life, my parents had a large strawberry field with workers who picked and drove the berries to a small packing house in town. Immediately, the berries got shipped to the large city markets. A lot of work was involved — from the day the plants were put in the ground, to the care and watering to the actual picking days.
In the meantime, let's go back to the kitchen, where our berries were being prepared for canning, freezing and the recipes the family loved. That large bowl of fresh "sugared down" strawberries that appeared at the dinner table was soon eaten.
Once again, the canning jars were carefully washed and waiting for that strawberry jelly and jam. The freezer was rearranged to make room for the frozen berries to eventually be used for pies, cakes and much more.
Two of my favorite strawberry memories are the old-fashioned homemade strawberry ice cream and strawberry shortcake.
Enjoy today's recipes.
STRAWBERRY JAM
5 cups crushed fresh strawberries (you'll need approximately 8 cups fresh strawberries or approximately 4 16-oz. containers), 7 cups granulated sugar, 1 packet original Sure-Jell premium fruit pectin powder, 2 tbsp lemon juice, 1/2 tsp butter.
Wash jars, lids and bands in hot soapy water, dry completely, and set bands aside. Simmer lids in warm water in a saucepan until ready to place them on jars. Keep jars warm by simmering in hot water until ready to use. Do not boil. Fill a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner with hot water, and place on the stove over medium-high heat (you'll need enough water to later cover your jars with at least 1 inch of water). Crush strawberries in a large mixing bowl or shallow glass baking dish using hand masher until nice, smooth consistency (small chunks are okay). Transfer crushed strawberries to 8 quart stock pot. Add pectin, lemon juice and butter to the pot, and stir constantly with a wooden spoon over high heat, while bringing to a rolling boil. Once boiling, add sugar, return to rolling boil, then boil for 1 minute while stirring constantly. After 1 minute, remove foam from top of jam by skimming it off with a metal spoon.one by one, remove a jar from hot water, transfer to a cookie sheet (this will catch any spills), place regular mouth canning funnel on jar, and ladle in strawberry jam mixture leaving 1/4 inch empty head space at top of the jar. Then wipe off the rim of the lid and threads of the jar with damp cloth.
Continue until all jars have been filled. Remove warm lids from the saucepan, a magnetic lid lifter works like a charm, and place one lid on each jar. Then screw one band on each jar just until snug but not overly tight. Place filled jars on a rack in a 20 quart stock pot or water bath canner, then lower down into hot water. Make sure there is enough water in the pot that there is at least 1 inch of water above the jars. If necessary, add more hot water. Place the lid on your pot, and bring to a gentle boil. Once water is boiling, set your timer for processing and boil for 10 minutes, once jars have finished boiling, turn off heat, remove the lid from the pot and let jars sit for 5 minutes before removing. After 5 minutes, lift up the rack to an elevated resting position, then carefully remove jars one by one using a jar lifter, and transfer to a folded towel to cool. The lids on the jars will begin to 'pop' into the sealed position, signifying the jam has been preserved. If any lids do not pop within the first 12 — 24 hours, transfer those to the refrigerator and use those up first. It may take up to 24-48 hours to finish setting.
Jars can be stored in your pantry, or a cool, dry cupboard for up to 1 year. Label the top of each lid with the type of jam and the date it was made. Remove bands when storing and be sure to never stack jars on top of each other. Always inspect lids to ensure the seals are good before using. When ready to use, transfer a jar to your refrigerator, and use within 1 month.
STRAWBERRY PIE
1 1/2 cups water, 1 cup granulated sugar, 3 tbsps cornstarch, 1 3-oz package strawberry Jell-O, 1 1/2 pints fresh capped strawberries, 8-inch pre-baked pie shell.
Mix together water, granulated sugar and cornstarch. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly until thick. Remove from heat and Jell-O; mix in well and let stand for 10 to 15 minutes; then fold strawberries. Pour into pie shell. Refrigerate until firm. Serve with a cool whip on the top. You may also use a graham cracker crust.
STRAWBERRY RHUBARB PIE
1 cup + 2 tbsps granulated sugar, 6 tbsps cornstarch, 1/2 tsp salt, 1 pound fresh rhubarb, 1 pound strawberries (stemmed and quartered), 1 tbsp orange juice, 2 tsps orange zest, 2 tsps vanilla bean paste or vanilla extract, 1 large egg, 2 tbsps turbinado sugar.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Place a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet on the center rack of the oven to preheat. Roll out one piece of dough on a floured surface into a 12-inch round, starting at the center and working your way out (sprinkle flour over the top of the dough if it's a bit too moist). Carefully lift the dough and place in a 9-inch pie pan (not deep dish); gently press against the sides of the pan. Trim excess overhanging dough at the edge of the pie plate. Stir together the sugar, cornstarch, and salt in a large bowl until evenly combined. Add the rhubarb, strawberries, orange juice, orange zest, and vanilla. Toss until evenly coated. Pour the fruit mixture into the pie crust. Roll out the other piece of dough into a 12-inch round on a floured surface. Cut into eight 1 1/2-inch-wide strips. Arrange 4 strips of dough in parallel rows on top of the filling. Working with one strip at a time, arrange the remaining 4 strips perpendicular to the first ones, weaving the strips over and under to form a lattice. Trim the ends of the strips and press them against the bottom crust. Press with a fork all around the edge of the pie crust to crimp. In a small bowl, whisk the egg and 1 tbsp of water with a fork. Brush the dough lightly with the egg wash and sprinkle with the turbinado sugar. Bake the pie until the filling is bubbly and thickened in the middle of the pie, 1 hour 20 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes. (Cover the pie with foil if the crust is getting too dark after 45 minutes.) Allow the pie to cool to room temperature before slicing, about 4 hours.
STRAWBERRY BREAD
2 quarts fresh strawberries, 4 beaten eggs, 3 cups all purpose flour, 2 cups sugar, 3 tsps cinnamon, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 1/4 cup cooking oil, 1 cup chopped nuts.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Grease and flour two 9 inch loaf pans and set aside. Wash and cap and slice berries. Drain well and place in a medium bowl. Stir in eggs, flour, sugar, cinnamon, salt, baking soda, oil and nuts. Mix well, pour into prepared pans and bake one hour or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
STRAWBERRY LEMONADE
1 pound strawberries plus more to garnish, 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 2 cups fresh lemon juice (strained and divided), ice, lemon slices to garnish.
Hull and quarter the strawberries. Place the strawberries in a large bowl, stir in the sugar and ¼ cup lemon juice. Allow to sit, covered for 30 minutes. In a countertop blender, blend the strawberry mixture until pureed. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve to get the seeds out. In a large bowl, combine the strawberry puree with the remaining 1 ¾ cups of lemon juice and 4 cups of water. Add up to 1 additional cup of water to taste if the mixture is too sweet or strong. To serve, stir the lemonade and pour it over ice. Garnish with sliced lemon and strawberries.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Lost and found
author: KEN CLENDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Lost and found

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN CLENDANIEL Bethlehem Wesleyan Church | Section: Columns 
 
 295
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Luke 15, Jesus tells three stories about lost items: a shepherd who loses a sheep, a woman who loses one of her silver coins and a father who loses his son to promiscuous living far from the family estate.Jesus told these stories because the highly religious people of his day, the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law, felt that there were certain people who didn't deserve God's grace and mercy.
They felt that sinners and people who were far from God didn't matter to God. Jesus tried to show them that all people matter, even those who are lost and far from God.
In fact, God takes the initiative and does an all-out search, rescue and restoration mission for those who are lost. "For the Son of Man came to seek and save those who are lost." (Lk 19:10; NLT)
It would not be strange for a sheep to be lost while out on the hillside. And it really would not be strange for a good shepherd to seek out the lost sheep. Jesus basically said, "Wouldn't you all do the same thing?"
What would be strange would be for the shepherd or the woman who lost a valuable coin or a father to do nothing to seek and save that which was lost.
And not only to seek and rescue but to restore that which was lost. The sheep's injuries were tended to and cared for. The coin was placed back into safe-keeping. The son was restored back to his position as son in the family.
God is on a mission to bring restoration back to people's lives. He wants to restore joy and peace and relationships. He wants to restore dignity. He wants to restore our significance and purpose. May all who are lost be found. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Bringing back the 'Votes for Women' sashes
author: GLENNA HECKATHORN
content:
Bringing back the 'Votes for Women' sashes

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENNA HECKATHORN | Section: Columns 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Women are going to have a tough time registering to vote if a new executive order and the House-passed SAVE Act are enacted.President Trump's March 25 executive order requires those registering to vote to provide a passport or similar documentation proving citizenship. According to The Center for American Progress, the SAVE Act "would require all Americans to prove their citizenship by presenting documentation in person when registering to vote or updating their voter registration information."
The center says "More than 140 million Americans do not possess a passport, and as many as 69 million women, who have taken their spouse's name, do not have a birth certificate matching their legal name. … These women lack citizenship documents showing their original names, because they changed their names after marriage and their birth certificates do not match their current IDs."
The U.S. League of Women Voters responded to the executive order by filing suit in April. In League of Women Voters v. Trump, a federal court judge has issued a temporary stay "blocking the U.S. Election Assistance Commission from … adding a requirement to show a passport or similar document proving citizenship when registering to vote. … The injunction preserves the status quo where … voters already affirm under penalty of perjury that they are U.S. citizens."
One hundred years ago when women rallied for equal voting rights, sashes were often worn by suffragettes during parades, rallies and other events as a way to bring attention to their cause. A simple phrase "Votes for Women" drew attention to their message and helped to unify them with each other and their supporters.
The colors of the sashes were symbolic — with purple for loyalty, white for purity and gold for light and hope. Through their hard work and persistence, the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, giving women the right to vote in elections, passed on Aug. 19, 1920.
Notably, the League of Women Voters was established in that same year on Feb. 14, 1920. To celebrate the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the League and passage of the 19th Amendment , the Mid-Shore chapter distributed replica sashes to store fronts in Cambridge and Easton. The sashes were made by Cambridge resident Anne McAnulty and lettered by Margaret and George Anzalone.
Now, after a century, the right of women and other citizens to vote is once again in jeopardy. In response, the League of Women Voters-Mid Shore will resurrect the sashes worn by the suffragettes calling for "Votes for Women."
"Now we will proudly wear our sashes in solidarity with those suffragettes and the many others who fought for voting rights, past President Kathi Bangert said. "As we work in the community to register voters, promote civic education, empower voters and defend democracy, the LWV-Mid Shore members will proudly wear our sashes in support of voting rights." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Voice of sanity, representation
author: Staff Writer
content:
Voice of sanity, representation

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am a lifelong Republican voter, now residing in Garrett County, and son of the late Clinton S. Bradley III who served Talbot County as a county councilman for 29 years. My wife and I are still residents in Maryland. We, like many, look to the lone Republican Congressman, Andy Harris for a voice of sanity and representation.Congressional District 6 (Western Maryland) lost its Republican representation because of gerrymandering to deliberately include non-Western Maryland liberal voters. Maryland is a one-party state. And given the current state administration's views, spending and planned tax increases, there is plenty of reason for Republicans to give up on Maryland. Some even move out of the state.
But perhaps nothing is as disheartening as our lone Maryland congressman Harris voting "present" on HR1 ("the one big, beautiful bill") and using his platform as the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus to not support President Trump, who is the leader of the Republican party. According to his press release, Harris says he voted "present" after meeting with Trump.
So, now I am asking myself, who does Harris represent? How is he advancing the interests of Maryland conservatives, Delmarva folks, or the national or state Republican party, or even the House Freedom Caucus where most of its members voted to support HR1 after meeting with Trump?
My father used to say, "I have to earn your vote."
I do not see how Congressman Harris is doing this for Congressional District 1 or Talbot Countians. Gerrymandering is one way to lose your voice and representation; another is when an elected representative at any level votes "present."
CLINTON S. BRADLEY IV
McHenry, Maryland

title: Country Cooking: Steaks for Father's Day
author: Staff Writer
content:
Country Cooking: Steaks for Father's Day

 June 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 958
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Father's Day was introduced in the United States in the early 20th century to complement Mother's Day.Father's Day was founded in Spokane, Washington at the YMCA by Sonora Dodd, who was born in Arkansas. Her father was a Civil War veteran and a single parent who raised six children. After hearing a sermon about Anna Jarvis' Mother's Day in 1909, Dodd told her pastor that fathers should be celebrated as well. Beginning in 1915, Father's Day has been celebrated on the third Sunday in June.
Hats off to all fathers on this special day. My own father was a proud father of nine sons and two daughters. There were many of our friends included in our family functions that had no father figures in their lives, and "Pop" treated us all the same.
His famous saying was "You put your feet under our table, then your hands were put on farm work like my own kids'." Needless to say, it did not deter anyone from coming to the table.
Today, I am turning the column to my son John. Proud father to three boys — Mason, Colin and Braxton. Enjoy your day with some wonderful grilled steaks.
Grilling Steak
I prefer not to freeze my steak. It is not always convenient, but I try to get my steak the day of or day before I plan to grill it. I think steak that is not frozen and then thawed out tastes better. Could just be me.
However you do it, whether from the freezer or out of the refrigerator, take that steak out and let it sit. Steak right out of the fridge will cook unevenly. Set yours out at room temperature for 30 minutes before grilling.
Here are a few ways to grill various cuts of steak as well as the various temperatures for getting the grill you want.
Rare: 120 to 130 degrees.Medium Rare: 130 to 135 degrees.Medium: 135 to 145 degrees.Medium Well: 145 to 155 degrees.Well Done: 155+ degrees.
SIRLOIN
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 4 to 5 minutes per side for medium-rare.
SKIRT STEAK
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 3 to 5 minutes per side for medium-rare.
RIBEYE
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 4 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare.
FILET MIGNON
Preheat the grill over high heat. Season steak generously with salt and pepper. Grill steak over direct heat 5 to 6 minutes per side for medium-rare.
T-BONE STEAK
There is something magic about a nice, fat T-bone. That piece of bone gives this steak so much flavor that you'll want to pick it up and eat steak right off the bone when your plate is clean. I like my T-bones to be at least 1 inch to 1 ¼ thick. This is so you can get a good crust but still have nice tender meat. Thaw your T bone out and let it sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes. If your grill doesn't have a thermometer, you can try to use a meat thermometer to check the surface heat, but it is not always accurate.
Here is what you'll need: 2 T-bone steaks at least 1 1/2 inches thick, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon ground black pepper, 1 stick unsalted butter, 1 tablespoon fresh rosemary (chopped), 2 cloves garlic (finely minced), ¼ teaspoon ground black pepper.
Turn on your grill and let it warm up to medium-high heat. Clean the grill grates and oil them. Pat the steaks dry with paper towels, then generously season with salt and pepper from all sides including the edges. Make the garlic butter, in a small saucepan, melt the butter with rosemary, garlic, and pepper. When the butter starts bubbling, cook for 1 minute then remove from heat so you don't burn the garlic. Allow the herb and garlic to steep in the butter as you grill the steaks. Add the steaks to the grill and reduce the heat to medium and cook for 4-5 minutes per side. Check the temperature. For a medium rare steak, grill the steaks for about 4 minutes on each side until the internal temperature reaches 130 degrees.When the steaks are done, remove from the grill onto a plate and pour the butter all over the steaks and cover with foil. Allow to rest for 5 minutes before slicing and serving.
NEW YORK STRIP
New York strip is my second favorite cut of steak that is much prepared the same way with a few adjustments. After letting steaks sit out for maybe 20 minutes, pat them dry. You want to try to get the same thickness of at least 1 inch thick. Pat dry to absorb any extra fluid or moisture.
Here is what you'll need: 2 New York strip steaks at least 1 inch thick, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon ground black pepper, 1 stick unsalted butter.
I preheat the grill to high heat. Heat the butter in a microwave safe bowl and then when ready I coat each steak on all sides as well as edges. I sprinkle the Kinder's Prime Steak seasoning on both sides of the steak. When you are ready to grill the steak turn the heat down to medium then place the steaks on the grill. Let sit for about 4 minutes a side then flip. At this point I coat with butter and sprinkle more seasoning on each side after I flip. About 5 minutes a side and I check the temperature using a meat thermometer. I like my steak medium rare so I pull them off when they hit 130 to 135 degrees. I slice immediately and eat while hot off the grill. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: What does your cross look like?
author: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: What does your cross look like?

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN GEORGE Ridgely Church of the Brethren | Section: Columns 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Luke 9:23, Jesus says, "If anyone would come after me, he must deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me." This is repeated in the gospels of Matthew and Mark, lending importance to these words.But what does our cross look like? Are we waiting for a big, wooden one like Jesus carried?
As Christians, one of our goals is service to the church and to the community. It's easy to pick up something we're capable of. Maybe we have the skills, time and desire. We know we'll take joy in doing them. Yet, despite the time, money or sweat we put into it, this is not our cross.
If it's easy, and if we take joy in it, this is not our cross. Do you think Jesus took pleasure in carrying the cross He did? Was it easy?
The cross we are being asked to pick up and carry in His name will have the same weight as the one He carried. It will be just as cumbersome. So pick up your cross.
Our cross will not be shaped like the cross that Jesus carried. It might be big or it might be small, but it will be heavy.
This is how we follow Jesus. We must step out of our comfort zones and go above and beyond what we think we're capable of. Doing the will of God becomes our cross to bear. So pick up your cross.
Jesus didn't want to carry His cross, but He did. When the time comes for you to pick up your cross, you're not going to want to carry it either, but pick it up and carry it for Him, just as He carried His for us. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Shelter Alliance names Kimrose Goodall executive director
author: Staff Writer
content:
Shelter Alliance names Kimrose Goodall executive director

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The Shelter Alliance appointmented Kimrose Goodall as executive director, effective July 1. Goodall brings to the role a distinctive blend of medical, psychological and theological expertise, shaped by years of hands-on work as a physician and counselor.Her deep commitment to holistic care uniquely equips her to lead the Shelter Alliance in its mission to serve Kent County's unhoused population.
Raised in Kingston, Jamaica, Goodall briefly resided in Baltimore, where she attended Baltimore Polytechnic Institute. She later returned to Jamaica to complete the International Baccalaureate program at Hillel Academy in Kingston. She earned a Bachelor of Pure Sciences and a Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery (MBBS) from the University of the West Indies.
After graduating from medical school in 2018, Goodall served more than six years as a physician at both the University Hospital of the West Indies and the Constant Spring Medical Center in Kingston.
During her medical practice, she developed a deep passion for addressing the psychological and emotional needs of vulnerable populations. This led her to pursue a Master of Arts in counseling psychology at the Caribbean Graduate School of Theology, where she graduated with honors in 2024. As part of her graduate training, she completed a clinical practicum at the A.F. Whitsitt Center in Maryland, working directly with individuals facing substance use challenges and housing instability.
Goodall's academic and clinical background includes trauma-informed care, crisis intervention and multicultural competency, equipping her to serve individuals from diverse cultural, socioeconomic and psychological backgrounds with both insight and empathy.
Her approach is shaped not only by professional experience but also by personal experience, including a period of housing insecurity. That lived experience fuels her passion for providing holistic, dignified and compassionate care, and deepens her understanding of the complex barriers faced by those without stable housing.
Founded in September 2024, the Shelter Alliance aspires to establish and operate a year-round, 24/7 shelter in Kent County. Since its inception, the organization has provided emergency accommodations in local motels, offering temporary shelter to those in need. To date, it has provided 97 bed nights to 38 individuals and has helped three clients secure permanent housing through partnerships with Deep Roots in Earleville, the Maryland Rural Development Corporation in Chestertown, and Corsica River Mental Health Services in Centreville.
With a full-time shelter, the Shelter Alliance aims to expand its impact and help more residents transition from crisis to stability.
The Shelter Alliance welcomes public support. Checks may be made payable to the Mid-Shore Community Foundation with "The Shelter Alliance" in the memo line and mailed to P.O. Box 2, Chestertown, MD 21620.
The Shelter Alliance Inc. is a component fund of the Mid-Shore Community Foundation, a 501©(3) nonprofit organization. Donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton High School graduate dies in car crash
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton High School graduate dies in car crash

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton community is mourning the death of recent high school graduate Darren Foxwell.Foxwell, 18, died following injuries sustained as a passenger in a single-vehicle car crash just outside Trappe on Tuesday morning. He was transported to Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment of life-threatening injuries. He died on Wednesday afternoon, his family said on Facebook Thursday.
In a Facebook post on Wednesday, Darren's father, Len Foxwell, wrote that the family is "eternally grateful for everyone who has sent their love and support, for those who have stepped up with profound gestures of support, and for Darren's friends who drove here from Easton yesterday to say goodbye to their childhood buddy."
"Each of you have been a lifeline and have honored Darren in your own special way," Len Foxwell wrote.
His father added that the team at Shock Trauma in Baltimore "fought like a tiger to keep Darren comfortable, preserve his dignity and provide solace for a family that has been destroyed."
A member of Easton High School's wrestling and lacrosse teams, Foxwell graduated last month. He planned to attend Bethany College in West Virginia this fall and play lacrosse for the Bison.
Foxwell played the last two years for Easton as a backup defenseman. Easton High boys head lacrosse coach Dennis Keenan said he was popular among his teammates and had a "bright future."
"I think he was funnier than he actually thought he was," Keenan said. "The things he would say would just crack me up. He was getting better each day. You could see flashes of brilliance."
Foxwell wrestled for three years at Easton, including under head coach Jason Biringer during his senior year. Biringer said Foxwell had an "infectious" personality.
Early this past season, Foxwell stepped away from the wrestling team. But after speaking with his coach, he returned and started at the 167-pound weight class for the Warriors.
After returning to the team, Biringer made Foxwell a team captain because of Foxwell's work ethic and focus.
"The other wrestlers looked up to him," Biringer said. "He has such a good, gentle demeanor that he was just very well liked."
"He just had one of those infectious smiles that you're like, 'It's always good to see Darren,'" Biringer added.
Family said on Thursday that arrangements for funeral services and a celebration of life are being made and will be announced soon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Public broadcast has been a part of our lives
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
Public broadcast has been a part of our lives

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 431
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Voice of America or VOA was initiated in 1942 to speak out against Nazi misinformation and propaganda. The Voice provided people under Nazi domination a way to hear the truth about World War II. The Voice provided the first real notification of D-Day, the invasion of Nazi controlled Europe and, thereby, triggered partisan uprisings all over Europe.After World War II and during the Cold War the Voice of America expanded its efforts to fight communism and played a role in the decline of communism in several countries. Today the Voice of America provides digital and radio content in 48 languages for affiliate stations around the world. The target and primary audience for the broadcasts is non-Americans living outside the United States borders, especially those without a free press or independent journalism.
It is the voice of freedom for them.
National Public Radio or NPR is an American public broadcasting organization that serves as a national syndicator to a network of more than a thousand public radio stations in the United States. NPR caters to local stories and news, local foods, local history, local culture and local dance. Classical and jazz music is played on NPR stations around the country. Programs like "Kids, screen time and mental health" might be a topic.
The Public Broadcasting Service or PBS is a publicly funded nonprofit organization and the most prominent provider of educational programs to public television stations in the United States. Some of the programs we have all enjoyed include NOVA, Frontline, Masterpiece Theater, Sesame Street, Mr. Rogers Neighborhood, Barney and Friends, American Experience and the most popular, Downton Abby.
These well-known and in most cases revered broadcast organizations are and have been a part of our lives for many decades. They have given all of us good things to entertain us, good things to think about and unbiased information. In the case of Voice of America, it has been our only way to reach places like Russia with the truth about world events like the war in Ukraine.
Mr. Putin is no doubt breaking out the vodka to celebrate this gift from Trump.
All these well-known and revered broadcast organizations are under fire from Mr. Trump to be cut off from any support that has come from the federal government. Wny is this being done? VOA, NPR and PBS all support us, the make our lives a little better, they give us a voice to reach other people.
I urge all of you to support VOA, NPR and PBS by letting our elected representatives know that you do not agree with ending this contribution to our lives. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Country Cooking: Summer snacking
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Summer snacking

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News 
 
 1108
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School is out, and summer fun is just beginning. Get those sweets and treats ready because the "I'm hungry" crowd has arrived.Ever wonder how kids can sit in school six hours a day with only lunch but when school is closed the "I'm hungry" cry is every two to three hours? It is easier to have snacks prepared and ready to hand out.
Buy a large economy size box of zipper snack bags and fill assorted crackers and chips. Fill another batch with assorted raisins, nuts, dried banana chips and gummy bears. Have small, flavored water bottles ready to simply hand out. I remember those summer shopping carts when I bought the little Kool-Aid flavored drink mixes in as many flavors as possible.
It seems I bought mostly grape and orange flavors. Homemade lemonade and sweet tea were saved for dinner time. At one point in the early '70s, with enough package points, you could order the plastic Kool-Aid pitcher with matching drinking cups for free. The Kool-Aid emblem was on the side of the cups.
Sometimes I would mix a package of Kool-Aid and pour in the ice cube trays, freeze and add to the glass of Kool-Aid for fun. This could also be tasty with a mixture of different flavors with the drink and ice cubes.
Making lunch sandwiches could be fun by using large cookie cutters to cut the bread. Place the cut-out sandwich on a plate and lay chips and pickles on the side. Use toothpicks to push into small chunks of cheese for added fun and nutrition.
FROZEN BANANA BITES
1 cup peanut butter, 4 bananas (sliced into 1-inch rounds), 8 (1 oz) squares semisweet chocolate, 1 tbsp shortening, ⅓ cup toffee baking bits.
Cover a baking sheet with waxed paper. Spoon a thin layer of peanut butter on top of each banana slice. Insert a toothpick through the peanut butter layer into the banana. Place banana bites onto the prepared baking sheet; freeze for 30 minutes to overnight. Melt chocolate and shortening in the top of a double boiler over simmering water, stirring frequently and scraping down the sides with a rubber spatula to avoid scorching. Cover another baking sheet with waxed paper. Remove 2 to 4 banana bites from the freezer at a time; coat each bite with chocolate mixture. Place coated banana bites on the second baking sheet; sprinkle each with toffee bits. Repeat until all the bites are coated. Return banana bites to the freezer until set, at least 1 hour. Allow bites to sit at room temperature for about 15 minutes before serving.
ICE CREAM SANDWICH POPS
6 ice cream sandwiches, 2 bottles chocolate shell topping (such as Magic Shell), 12 popsicle sticks, assorted toppings (such as sprinkles, crushed cookies, nuts, crushed candy bars. We love Oreo cookies.)
Cut ice cream sandwiches in half crosswise. Insert a popsicle stick through up through the center of each cut end. Remove the caps and seals from the shell topping. Place in the microwave and cook for 8 seconds. Pour each bottle shell topping into a glass measuring cup. Dip each pop into shell topping until completely covered, allowing excess to drip off. Dip the top ends in desired toppings and place on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Freeze pops at least 1 hour before serving.
CLASSIC PUDDING POPS
One of my son John's favorite snacks as a kid was pudding pops. You don't really see them in the stores too often anymore. Here is a homemade recipe for that nostalgic sweet treat.
2 cups milk, ½ cup evaporated milk, 1 (3.5 oz) package instant chocolate pudding mix, ¼ cup white sugar.
Beat milk, evaporated milk, instant pudding and sugar in a bowl until thoroughly combined. Pour into ice pop molds and freeze until firm, about 3 hours. Also for this recipe if you are diabetic or making you can prepare it this way. Use zero sugar pistachio pudding, substitute liquid Splenda for the sugar (1/2 tsp) and they are wonderful.
S'MORES POPSICLES
2 cups cold milk, 1 package instant chocolate pudding mix, 2 whole graham crackers (crushed), 1 ½ cups vanilla ice cream (softened).
Beat milk and pudding mix together in a bowl using an electric mixer until thickened, about 2 minutes. Measure 1 1/2 cup pudding and set remaining pudding aside for another use. Sprinkle graham cracker crumbs into the bottom of each ice pop mold; add about 1/4 cup ice cream. Sprinkle another layer of graham cracker crumbs and top with about 1/4 cup pudding. Add a final layer of graham cracker crumbs. Freeze until completely frozen, about 3 hours.
TROPICAL FRUIT ICICLES
½ cups low-fat vanilla yogurt, 1 cup sliced mango, 1 (8 oz) can pineapple chunks (undrained), 1 small banana, 1 orange (juiced).
Blend yogurt, mango, pineapple chunks with juice, banana, and orange juice in a blender until smooth. Pour into ice pop molds; freeze until set, 4 to 6 hours.
PEANUT BUTTER BANANA
ICE CREAM
4 ripe bananas cut into 1-inch slices, ¼ cup peanut butter.
Arrange banana slices on a baking sheet and freeze, 8 hours to overnight. Process frozen bananas in a food processor until evenly chopped; add peanut butter and process until thick and creamy.
STRAWBERRY LEMONADE
1 lb. strawberries plus more to garnish, 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 2 cups fresh lemon juice (strained and divided), ice, lemon slices to garnish.
Hull and quarter the strawberries. Place the strawberries in a large bowl, stir in the sugar and ¼ cup lemon juice. Allow to sit, covered for 30 minutes. In a countertop blender, blend the strawberry mixture until pureed. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve to get the seeds out. In a large bowl, combine the strawberry puree with the remaining 1 ¾ cups of lemon juice and 4 cups of water. Add up to 1 additional cup of water to taste if the mixture is too sweet or strong. To serve, stir the lemonade and pour it over ice. Garnish with sliced lemon and strawberries.
HOMEMADE FRUIT POPSICLES
Strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, pineapple and mango are just a few of the fruits you can use here. For this one we will use 2 cups fresh blueberries, raspberries, strawberries and sliced bananas (mixed); 2 cups plain or vanilla yogurt, ¼ cup white sugar, 8 small paper cups, 8 popsicle sticks.
Place the mixed blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, sliced bananas, yogurt, and sugar into a blender. Cover, and blend until the fruit is chunky or smooth, as desired. Fill paper cups 3/4 full with fruit mixture. Cover the top of each cup with a strip of aluminum foil. Poke a popsicle stick through the center of the foil on each cup. Place the cups in the freezer for at least 5 hours. To serve, remove foil and peel off the paper cup. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Crackin my shell: Emotional detachment and war
author: SARENA NEYMAN
content:
Crackin my shell: Emotional detachment and war

 June 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SARENA NEYMAN | Section: Columns 
 
 827
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Every spring, someone in my town posts hand-drawn "turtle crossing" signs near the roads where turtles lay their eggs. I'd never actually seen one crossing and used to wonder why anyone bothered with these signs.But recently, I spotted a small painted turtle inching across the road, likely returning to the pond after burying her eggs. I considered moving her but worried I'd throw off her inner compass.
The next day, on a morning bike ride, I saw a massive snapper the size of a watermelon, slowly making her way across the asphalt. I got off my bike and paused the podcast I'd been listening to: Peter Beinart's interview of Israeli journalist Gideon Levy.
Levy said many Jews, both in Israel and the U.S., shut their hearts to Palestinian suffering. They skip the disturbing images of destruction and starvation, avoid the headlines, ignore the unbearable. His words brought to mind "The Zone of Interest," the Oscar-winning film about an Auschwitz commandant's family unmoved by the screams beyond their walls. What's chilling is how ordinary people adapted, how they built lives alongside atrocity by refusing to see the victims as fully human.
As I stood by the turtle, a car pulled up. The driver rolled down the window. "Should we move it?" she asked. We both admired the majestic prehistoric-looking creature, its jagged shell and ancient eyes, like a living dinosaur that had somehow lumbered out of the deep past. These animals have not changed in 90 million years.
"I don't think it's safe to move a snapper unless you've done it before," I said.
She nodded, rolled up her window and carefully drove around it.
I was pulling out my phone to take a photo when I saw another car approaching. I assumed they saw the huge turtle. I didn't wave or signal. Surely they'd slow down.
But then, in an awful instant, I realized they weren't slowing down at all. The impact was immediate. The snapper was thrown into the air. When she hit the ground, I heard a sound I will never forget: her shell exploding beneath the tire — a violent, cracking thunder that tore through my ears. The car never even slowed down.
It felt like something in me had cracked too.
I'm not someone who cries easily. I have a hard shell — quicker to think than to feel. Maybe it started in childhood. I was the one who had to wake my grandmother from her nightmares. No one else heard her cries at night, but my room was next to hers. I hated the job. A Nazi soldier had ripped her 4-year-old daughter from her arms. She never saw the little girl again.
Shaken by the turtle's death, I got back on my bike and resumed the podcast. Levy was describing a Palestinian friend in Gaza with only two days of insulin left. This is everyday life in Gaza, Levy says. We all know what happens when severe diabetics can't get their insulin, he adds.
The death of the turtle reminds me of how vulnerable the earth's creatures are and the cruelty of humans. I hear the high-pitched screech before a bomb explodes, the scream of a father pulling his daughter's body from the rubble, the cries of hungry children with ribs like bird cages.
It's strange what breaks through. It's rarely facts or numbers. Dozens of Israeli children were killed by Hamas on Oct. 7. Thousands upon thousands of Palestinian children have been killed since that date. Among much of the Jewish community I grew up in, one number evokes national mourning. The other is met with silence.
In a recent interview, Ezra Klein spoke with writer Kathryn Schulz about the challenge of staying emotionally awake.
"I spend days covering efforts to rip health care from people and torch the global economy," Klein said, "and then I'm supposed to go to a birthday party."
We can't live every second in full awareness, Schulz tells him. We'd collapse. But, she says, if we're lucky enough to feel suffering only indirectly, we must choose, again and again, not to look away. Even if we don't know how to intervene.
Throughout the day, I keep remembering the snapper's death. The arc her body made in the air. The shattering crunch. These turtles can live for up to 100 years. Who knew how many years were cut from her life? She had survived predators, pollution, drought. And then in an instant, she was smashed to pieces.
I am haunted by my inaction.
Why didn't I wave at the car? Why didn't I hold up my hand? I keep thinking about how preventable it all felt. How easily we destroy what we don't slow down to see. How easy it is to detach from it all.
Over time, the memory of this day will fade. But I want to remember that sound. That cracking. Because in its violence it connected me to the fragility of life, the tragedy of indifference, the ease with which one becomes numb — and how dangerous that can be. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal reflection about emotional detachment, human indifference, and moral responsibility, using a turtle crossing incident as a metaphor. While it mentions local elements (turtle crossing signs, local author), the core themes transcend typical 'Local Life' coverage. title: 'They were everything': Father remembers sons who drowned in Greensboro
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
'They were everything': Father remembers sons who drowned in Greensboro

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Mason and Bentley Puckett tragically died on June 29 in an accidental drowning, according to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.Michael Puckett, Mason and Bentley's father, described his children as "everything."
"You couldn't not love them," Puckett said. "They were everything. They love four wheelers, they love balls, they love their daddy, they were outside boys. They had to be outside all the time."
Bentley was 3 years old, Puckett said. He was just beginning riding his four wheeler by himself. Bentley also enjoyed riding a four wheeler with his older brother, Mikey, who Bentley called "his Mikey."
"I mean he was life," Puckett said about Bentley. "From the time he got up to the time he went to sleep, he was outside playing. He stole everybody's heart. If you met him, you had no choice but to love the boy."
Mason was 1 year old. Puckett described Mason as just like his brother Bentley, but Mason loved his balls.
"He stole everybody's hearts, he loved his balls, and he loved riding four wheelers," Puckett said.
Puckett said the relationship between Mason and Bentley was unmatched.
"They were close," Puckett said. "Of course, they fought like brother sometimes. Bentley was not a morning person and Mason was. When they woke up, Mason wanted to give his brother kisses and hugs, and Bentley didn't want nothing to do with him. They always just wanted to go outside, I don't care if it was rain, cold or nothing, they wanted to go outside."
Mason and Bentley have seven siblings who they loved dearly. Puckett said they were both close with all of them. They also loved their cousins dearly, Puckett said.
A visitation will be held on Tuesday, July 8, from 10 a.m. to noon at St. Luke's Methodist Church, on 100 S. 5th Ave., Denton. A memorial service will follow at noon. The interment will be private. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: You are not too busy to make time for God
author: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton
content:
You are not too busy to make time for God

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: REV. DANIEL T. GEDMAN St. Luke’s GMC, Denton | Section: Columns 
 
 340
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What does God want from me?Without question, our belief in Jesus as the Christ is the prerequisite to everything else. Nevertheless, what does Christ want after our salvation?
Certainly, He does not need anything from the physical world. After all, God is the provider of all things. But there is one thing we can offer: Time.
Time is definable and measurable. It controls our lives, it marches on no matter what we do, and our days are limited. We sell it, give it away and waste it. The best we can do is to utilize our time efficiently and effectively. In our culture, time is precious commodity. God wants our time. Interestingly, time is the one thing may people claim not to have.
"They are too busy," they'll say. Well, as someone noted, the acronym BUSY means "buried under Satan's yoke." Yep, too many times our being "busy" causes us to not spend time with God.
Jesus taught that we should "seek first his kingdom." This requires time. Just as we prioritize bills and purchases, our time is prioritized, and God is not always at the top of the list. While this seems to be a part of our human condition, there is one solution I can offer, whereby you can begin to commit more of your time to God: weekly worship.
Paul admonished us to "not give up meeting together, as some are in the habit of doing." Consider for a moment that we have 168 hours per week. An average worship service is one hour. By dividing 1 into 168, we see that Sunday worship consumes six-10ths of 1 percent (.6%) of our time.
Even netting our time by a 40-hour work week, 56 hours for sleep and one hour preparation and travel time to church, only amounts to 1.4% of our time.
Is God worth 1.4% of our time? Commit yourself to attending corporate worship once a week. God will bless your commitment, and you'll find that you want to spend more time with God in prayer and reading His Word, the Bible. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: God’s watchful eye misses nothing
author: Staff Writer
content:
God’s watchful eye misses nothing

 July 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Two pudgy toddler hands rose above the murky river, small and still. My heart leapt into my throat, and I shouted my husband's name. He had already turned and was sprinting through the shallows toward our youngest daughter.Our family of five had gone to a little stretch of sandy beach in Cambridge, Maryland. We watched our girls playing at the water's edge, our toddler splashing nearby. But in what seemed like an instant, she had wandered out too far and was now completely submerged, with only her tiny hands reaching up for help.
That near-tragedy rattled us deeply. We considered ourselves good parents, careful and attentive, but in one unguarded moment, everything could have changed forever.
This memory has been on my mind again after hearing of two recent tragedies: the loss of two toddler brothers who drowned in Greensboro, Maryland, and the young girls swept away by flash flooding at Camp Mystic in Texas.
The grief of those families is unimaginable, and my heart aches for them.
I find myself asking the same questions they surely ask: Where was God? Did He see? Did He hear their cries?
I don't know why some are rescued and others are not. But I do know this: God did not turn His face away.
Even when Jesus hung on the cross, suffering unimaginably, God saw. Many assume He turned His back when Jesus cried out, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?" (Matthew 27:46). I once believed that too. But as Bible teacher Rich Schmidt explains, Jesus was quoting Psalm 22 — a psalm that begins in agony but ends in hope: "For he has not despised or scorned the suffering of the afflicted one; he has not hidden his face from him but has listened to his cry for help" (Psalm 22:24).
Jesus was not alone on the cross. And those children were not alone in the water.
God's watchful eye misses nothing:
"The eyes of the Lord are in every place, keeping watch on the evil and the good." (Proverbs 15:3)
"The Lord is close to the brokenhearted and saves those who are crushed in spirit." (Psalm 34:18)
My prayer is that the grieving families somehow feel His gaze upon them now — not with answers, but with presence.
Because He sees.
Even here. Even now.
TRACY HARPER
Preston 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Shame of being poor becomes empathy, motivation
author: ARLYCE MENZIES
content:
Shame of being poor becomes empathy, motivation

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ARLYCE MENZIES | Section: News 
 
 898
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I grew up poor, that is, American poor.I fantasized about food at night–mashed potatoes, buttery dinner rolls, raspberry cheesecake. I would wake up and imagine a breakfast — strawberry waffles with whipped cream, cold orange juice — then, talk myself toward accepting what I knew was there — toast with peanut butter and usually, milk. My dad did not tolerate ungratefulness.
I couldn't pay school fees like the dreaded $10 workbook fee and was harangued by the dogged collectors as I repeated that I forgot it. I couldn't rent an instrument, so I didn't play one but singing lit my heart on fire. I couldn't join sports, couldn't buy uniforms or pay for trips. My gym teacher in seventh grade said I was great at running and hurdles, and she encouraged me to join the track team. I joined, but immediately sprained my big toe and quit. I think my teacher, the coach, knew I could have overcome this minor injury, but couldn't overcome going without the right shoes, walking two miles home from practices, having no money or rides or, in fact, confidence to run.
I got the free lunch at school. We had to walk up to the stage in the cafeteria to find our ticket — a white card with our name on it — before getting in line. Not only were we conspicuous, frantically searching for the ticket in front of everyone, but we were also the last to get the food our bagged-lunch friends couldn't recognize.
"What is that? Are you going to eat that?!"
When we had to bring a lunch for field days, my dad would pack something in a bread bag like an only-peanut-butter sandwich and a whole carrot with the white root hairs obscenely pressed against the clear plastic. Variations on this lunch included a boiled egg crayoned with "B" on the shell or a plain baked potato.
Packaged snacks weren't covered by food stamps or WIC — milk stuffs for Women Infants and Children. We had whole milk and bricks of government cheese food. We had unmarked cans and other food bank finds including, once, a sugary cereal we were excited about until we tasted that it had been contaminated by the powdered laundry soap it had sat with in the donation box.
We were turned away in shops because what we wanted couldn't be bought with this other-colored money or because they said they didn't have change for food stamps. Thankfully, my mom mostly knew where she could stock up and on what.
We rarely went to the doctor. We all have scars that show no one stitched them or set the bones straight — OK, only one broken finger set with a stick and tape. When my sister was really sick, the irritated doctor didn't want to take Medicaid. He only gave her Claritin. It turned out to be mono, and she was in bed for a week, then she got pneumonia. She recovered. Our remedies were to pray, drink water, put a cloth on your head or where you hurt, hot or cold, depending.
My mother-in-law says I'm an exception.
She says people on welfare are lazy, only busy pumping out babies and watching TV. She thinks it's easy to have no job, let the checks roll in, buy steaks and chocolate with your government winnings. She hasn't sat in the welfare office for three hours only to be yelled at, looked down upon and rejected for the second time because you couldn't get the papers right.
She hasn't had a disability or loved a person who is blind from a genetic disease like my dad was. She hasn't had a nervous breakdown, spent months in mental wards after suicide attempts like my mom has. She doesn't know anyone who grew up on or is on welfare, except for me.
In some ways, I am an exception. I grew up with both my married parents. My great-grandfathers were a doctor and a lawyer. The lawyer left us each $4,000 for college. There wasn't any question — we had to go to college. My dad went blind slowly. He memorized children's books so he could "read" to us without seeing the pages.
Although she didn't finish college, my mom loves poetry and had a full mahogany bookcase. She planted daffodils in the yard; we lived in our own house. My parents got a settlement after being in a dormitory fire. My mom's dad got a lawyer who won them enough to buy a house on an acre of grassy land with crab apple trees that bloomed pink in spring.
I am not an exception in that I am white. More than 62 percent of welfare recipients are white and about 46 percent are single mothers. Despite the term "white trash" my mother-in-law imagines this waste of money is for People of Color.
I am not an exception in that my parents are disabled. The majority of welfare recipients are children, the elderly, and people with disabilities.
I am not an exception in that I am hardworking and work to improve my life and the lives of others.
I am not an exception in that very young, I knew some strangers, teachers and people around me thought I was a useless weight, a tax burden, a bad decision, a mistake. I am not an exception in carrying this shame, trying to shape it, alchemize it into empathy, motivation, a commitment to justice. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it touches on race and welfare, the core themes don't align with any listed category. title: Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society

 July 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 782
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The recent flash flood tragedy in central Texas resulted in seeing the best and the worst of American society.The best has been an outpouring of sympathy, caring and support for the flood victims, their families and the survivors. There have been countless reports of selfless rescue and recovery efforts by first responders and volunteers, some from well beyond the immediate flooded area.
The worst has been numerous messages on social media and other media platforms — e.g., a newspaper editorial cartoon — that were vile, hateful and some of which were vulgar.
Many of them chose to blame Trump supporters or policy decisions of the Trump administration for this tragedy.
Far too many did not include expressions of sadness or sympathy for the deaths of innocent children and adults or compassion for the lifelong impact on all the flooding survivors.
The level of vitriol in these messages is so offensive, I will not repeat any of them in this column.
The only thing they have in common is they are devoid of any sense of decency and civility.
Somewhat surprising has been dismay and even outrage expressed from unexpected sources over these vile messages.
Nina Turner is a former national co-chair for the Bernie Sanders 2020 presidential campaign.
She recently said, "It takes a serious lack of humanity to see children to be in a politicized discussion and respond something like lines of "that's what they [voters in Texas] voted for."
Turner's closing one word comment says it all — "Shameful."
John Favreau and Tommy Vietor are co-hosts on the left of center, Pod Save America.
Both worked for Barack Obama prior to and during his presidential administration.
Both have condemned social media posts that blame local Texans and the Trump administration for all who died as a result of the recent floods.
Favreau said: "I think the really gross stuff was, I saw some people be, like, 'Well, Texas, you voted for Trump, and this is what you get.'"
Favreau has challenged suggestions that staffing levels at the National Weather Service in Texas had anything to do with the tragedy. Favreau has said, "It seems like the National Weather Service, like I said, did send out a timely warning, it just didn't get to people. And that's, you know, not the Trump administration saying that; independent meteorologists and experts have all said this."
Vietor has said that while questions about the effect of weather services cuts could be "an important question going forward, I could have done without the, like, instant, you know, leap to blame name-your-political-opponent for this tragedy on Twitter."
The "blame your political opponent" campaign on this tragedy is already well underway.
Shortly after news broke on the flooding, Sen. Chuck Schumer demanded the Commerce Department's inspector general investigate vacancies at National Weather Service offices and whether the purported vacancies resulted in a higher death toll in in Texas.
Schumer has suggested that proposed but yet-to-be-implemented Trump budget cuts resulted in unfilled weather service positions in Texas were to blame. Sen. Chris Dodd has said likewise.
Schumer proclaimed: "The American people deserve answers."
Yes, we do, but not from you two or anyone who wants to advance a political agenda from this tragedy.
We deserve answers only if the following investigative guidelines are agreed to, in advance of, and are strictly adhered to during every phase of any investigation. At a minimum, the investigation must focus less on assigning blame for what happened or did not happen with regard to timely and effective flash flood alerts.
The laser like focus must be on what can be done going forward to help ensure it never happens again.
Differing opinions must be welcome and considered provided they follow the timeless observation of former U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who once said, "Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but not their own facts."
One new previously unreported fact comes from a recent Washington Post article headline — "Camp Mystic's leader got a 'life threatening' flood alert. They evacuated an hour later."
We also need to accept that we never have and never will live in a risk-free world.
We can only anticipate risks and take prudent steps to try to avoid them or deal with them if and when necessary. Accidents can never be totally avoided despite plans and best intentions.
Going forward, we desperately need a renewed universal commitment that when tragedies strike, to make sure social media posts and other public reactions reflect common decency and respect for each and every person impacted in any way by that tragedy.
This is especially vital in dealing with those who hold different political party affiliations or different views on a wide range of public policy issues.
We must do so if we have any hope of reversing the steadily declining levels of decency and civility in our society. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on societal reactions to a natural disaster, including political blame, social media vitriol, and calls for civility. None of the listed topics directly address the intersection of disaster response, political discourse, and societal decency. While 'National News' is closest, the content emphasizes cultural/political commentary over factual news reporting.

title: Community, lawmakers rally behind Easton pastor detained by ICE
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Community, lawmakers rally behind Easton pastor detained by ICE

 July 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Politicians and community members are rallying behind Daniel Fuentes Espinal after his arrest by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement on Monday, July 21.Honduran born Espinal has lived in the United States since 2001 and has served as the minister of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015. According to his daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, Espinal, who also does construction work, was arrested by ICE agents early Monday morning after stopping by Lowe's to pick up material for a job site.
ICE confirmed Espinal's arrest in a statement to the Star Democrat Thursday.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement read. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
Diaz said Espinal had no other criminal history. She said the family is working with an immigration attorney, but access to and information about Espinal is limited other than occasional 20-minute phone calls, which cost $50.
According to Diaz, her father has not had access to his medications and is sleeping on a concrete floor in the ICE detention center. She said he has been helping other detainees by preaching, praying and giving them faith.
Members of the Mid-Shore community have organized efforts in support of Espinal in the wake of the arrest.
Tred Avon Strategies principal Len Foxwell created a GoFundMe with a goal of $15,000 to support Espinal's growing legal fees and help cover costs for Espinal's wife and three children during his absence.
Foxwell's son, who recently died in a car accident, was best friends with Espinal's son.
The GoFundMe, created Thursday morning, was more than halfway toward its goal as of 4 p.m. Thursday.
The Talbot Democratic Forum and the Talbot Democratic Central Committee plan to hold a rally on Friday from 5:30 to 7 p.m. on Route 50 and Dover Road in Easton to demand Espinal's immediate release from ICE custody.
"Pastor Daniel Fuentes Espinal was ripped from his family and congregation by ICE with no warning. He has no criminal record. He's a father, a faith leader, and a vital part of our Eastern Shore community," Cambridge Indivisible wrote in a Facebook post promoting the rally.
Democratic politicians from throughout the state are also calling for Espinal's release.
"The Trump Administration clearly isn't targeting the most dangerous criminals living in the U.S. illegally — they are snatching up anyone they can find as they pursue their mass deportation agenda and terrorizing our communities in the process. My team is engaged with Pastor Espinal's family and I will be monitoring this closely," U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen said in a statement to the Star Democrat.
Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st), whose district includes Easton, said in a statement to the Star Democrat that he was aware of Espinal's situation but did not have the specifics of the case.
"Congressman Harris believes due process within the immigration system is important and that facts should be clear before making any further public comment," the statement said. "More broadly, Rep. Harris has always believed that any immigration enforcement action taken should be based on accurate information and lawful immigration adjudication processes."

title: Country Cooking: Cooking for The King
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Cooking for The King

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1061
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today's column is being written from the heart. The month of August is always a busy month, but not too busy for me to reflect on the past.Those of you who know me also know this is the month I usually travel to Memphis and meet with worldwide friends to gather at Graceland and pay respects to Elvis.
Aug. 16, 1977 was the day we teenagers of the late 1950s and '60s lost one of our favorite idols. Hard to believe it's been 48 years since I heard the news that morning. As goes with all our idols, Elvis is just as popular today with fans of all ages.
My answer to those who ask why I liked him so much is easy to explain: My older siblings loved the late 1940s through the mid-1950s music, and when I became a preteen, my generation needed a change of dance styles and rock 'n' roll music. And we got it — to the horror of our elders. That is true for all generations.
When I meet fans from Germany, some are my age, but some are 30 and 40 years old and remembering their grandparents and parents talking about Elvis serving in the Army in Germany.
Let's explore some of the King's favorite foods. Elvis loved his mother's meatloaf, and I occasionally make this recipe.
MEATLOAF
2 lbs ground beef, one chopped onion, one chopped green pepper, two minced cloves garlic, 4 oz crushed saltines, 8-oz can crushed tomatoes, 8-oz can tomato sauce, 1/2 cup ketchup.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Mix together ground beef with onion, green pepper, garlic, crushed saltines and crushed tomatoes. Mix well and form into a loaf and place in a baking pan. Bake covered, for 45 minutes. In the meantime, mix tomato sauce and ketchup and set aside. After 45 minutes of baking, remove the meatloaf and pour the ketchup on top and return to the oven. Bake for another 15 minutes and serve with mashed potatoes.
ROAST BEEF
2 tbsps black pepper, 1 1/2 tbsps salt, 2 tbsps garlic, 6 lb beef, 1 1/2 cups water.
Mix pepper, salt and garlic to form a paste and rub on this mixture on the beef. Place this roast in a baking pan, add water and place in a 350-degree oven. Bake for about 4 hours or until tender. You can steam some fresh vegetables to serve with the roast.
SPANISH OMELETTE
4 eggs, 1/2 cup chopped green bell pepper, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup shredded cheese, salt and pepper.
Beat eggs well and mix in bell pepper and onion. Fold in 1/2 cup shredded cheese of your choice with salt and pepper to taste. Cook in a greased skillet for about 4 minutes.
HAMBURGER STEAK ELVIS
2 1/2 pounds ground beef, 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped green pepper, 1 tbsp garlic, 1 tbsp salt, 1 tbsp black pepper, 2 cups mushroom soup, 2 eggs (beaten).
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl mix together ground beef, chopped onions, chopped green pepper, garlic, salt, black pepper, mushroom soup and eggs. Mix well Shape into mini steaks and fry in a skillet with 2 tablespoons Crisco. Cook for about 12 to 15 minutes, making sure steaks are cooked inside well. Drain on paper towels and proceed to make gravy with grease left in the pan.
ELVIS BANANA BREAD
2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup sugar, 1 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice, 4 medium ripe bananas (mashed), 2 large eggs (room temperature), 1/2 cup creamy peanut butter, 1/4 cup unsweetened applesauce, 1/4 cup canola oil, 2 tsps vanilla extract, 2/3 cup semisweet chocolate chips
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, whisk the first six ingredients. In another bowl, whisk bananas, eggs, peanut butter, applesauce, oil and vanilla until blended. Add to flour mixture; stir just until moistened. Fold in chocolate chips. Transfer to three loaf pans coated with cooking spray. Bake for 45-50 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool in pans 10 minutes before removing to a wire rack to cool. If you make multiple loaves like Mary Jenkins Langston would make for his plane rides to Las Vegas, you can freeze them and reheat. Securely wrap the cooled loaves and freeze. To use, thaw at room temperature or, if desired, microwave each loaf on high for 60-75 seconds or until heated through.
FRIED PEANUT BUTTER AND BANANA SANDWICHES
Smear peanut butter on one slice of bread, and on the other slice smear the bread with mashed banana. Put the slices together, smear each outside slice with bacon grease and fry in a hot skillet.
FRIED DILL PICKLES
1 jar (32 oz) whole dill pickles, 1 cup buttermilk, 2 tbsps Louisiana-style hot sauce, 1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 2 tbsps garlic salt, 2 tbsps paprika, 1 tbsp cayenne pepper, 1 tsp pepper, oil for deep-fat frying, ranch salad dressing.
Drain pickles, discarding liquid. Cut pickles into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Drain on paper towels; blot with additional paper towels until dry. In a shallow bowl, mix buttermilk and hot sauce. In another shallow bowl, mix flour, cornmeal, garlic salt, paprika, cayenne pepper and pepper. Dip pickles in buttermilk mixture, then in flour mixture. In a Dutch oven, heat one inch of oil to 375 degrees. Working in batches, fry pickles for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until golden brown. Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with ranch dressing, if desired.
Before I close the column today, I need to honor my late brother, Staff Sgt. (E6) Ollie L. Hitchens Jr., who would be celebrating his 78th birthday on Aug. 15. Ollie served 20 years in the U.S. Army and pulled three tours of duty in Vietnam.
Ollie and I had a lot in common — our likes, dislikes, love for Chevy cars, love of family, patriotic responsibilities, personalities and love for Elvis.
Ollie loved our mom's old-fashioned cooking and often wrote home about how he missed it. While on his many trips home Mom would make sure to have those foods ready — fried chicken, pot roast, pork chops, mashed potatoes, fried liver with gravy, chicken and dumplings, fresh lima beans with tomatoes, corn and potatoes and of course homemade biscuits. I have shared many of these recipes with you in previous columns.
Rest in peace, brother — as I always say, "All gave some, and some gave all."

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Living free from worry
author: GREGORY BLACKSTON
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Living free from worry

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GREGORY BLACKSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 250
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Matthew 6:33-34."But seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness, and all these things shall be added to you. Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about its own things. Sufficient for the day is its own trouble."
In a world filled with uncertainty, Jesus offers a life-changing perspective: focus on God's kingdom first, and stop worrying about tomorrow.
To "seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness" means placing God's priorities ahead of our own. It is a daily choice to pursue His will, His ways, and His purposes. When we do this, Jesus promises that "all these things" — our basic needs of life — will be provided.
Jesus also addresses one of life's greatest challenges: worry about the future. He reminds us that tomorrow has its own problems and should not rob us of today's peace. Worry adds stress but accomplishes nothing. Faith, however, produces calm and confidence because it trusts God with what lies ahead.
Three Practical Steps:
Start with God each day — Begin mornings with prayer and Scripture, keeping your focus on His kingdom.Release tomorrow's concerns — Choose trust over anxiety; handle today's responsibilities, and let tomorrow rest with God.Rest in His care — Believe that as you prioritize Him, He will supply what you truly need.
The heart of Jesus' teaching is simple but powerful: when God is first, worry loses its grip. Today, choose to trust Him fully, live faithfully, and embrace His peace for today while leaving tomorrow in His hands. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
